Development Objective:
This operation seeks to ensure that the needs of vulnerable chronically food insecure households are
adequately addressed. To that end, the development objective is to contribute to the Government's
efforts to maintain adequate coverage of the Ethiopia Productive Safety Net Program (PSNP) in 2009,
thereby ensuring that the Project Development Objectives of the PSNP can be met.

Short Description:
The Project is an emergency operation under the Global Food Crisis Response Program (GFRP), which
was endorsed by the Board on May 29, 2008, and will be financed through new IDA Grant. It would
provide Additional Financing to the World Bank PSNP APL II Project (P098093) as part of the Ethiopia
Food Crisis Response Program, supporting the Government's efforts to ensure that the PSNP can provide
adequate coverage of food-insecure households in 2009.

Type of Operation:
New Operation [X] Additional Financing [ ] Existing Financing (restructuring) [X]

The Program would be financed through new IDA resources in an amount equivalent to US$137.5
million, and redeployment of IDA-resources (credits and grants) from 12 of Ethiopia's ongoing Projects
in a total amount equivalent to US$137.5 million.
Development Objective:
The Project seeks to increase the likelihood that crop production in 2009-2010 will remain on or near the
growth trend of recent years. To that end, the development objective is to contribute to the Government's
efforts to ensure aggregate availability of supply of chemical fertilizers for the 2009-2010 production
season adequate to meet smallholder farmers' priority demands.


Short Description:
The Project is an emergency operation under the Global Food Crisis Response Program (GFRP), ), which
was endorsed by the Board on May 29, 2008, and will be financed through the cancellation of grants and
credits from 12 projects as well as new commitments. Two components are proposed: First, a large
Fertilizer Component (about US$249.6 million) would ensure availability of a significant share of the
fertilizer demand for the 2009 season. The Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development will use the
Project funds to allocate foreign exchange to the domestic importer(s) for paying the foreign fertilizer
suppliers. Fertilizer distribution and sales to farmers will be mainly through private entities, in particular
farmer cooperatives and their unions. Most fertilizer is expected to be used on staple food production
where it is a critical input determining food crop yields. Second, a small but important Monitoring and
Evaluation (M&E) Component (about US$0.4 million) would track the fertilizer imports, the various
steps along the input distribution system, and enable an assessment of the impact of the project for the
beneficiary farm households.

          A. THE "F-CRISIS": FOOD, FERTILIZER, AND FOREIGN EXCHANGE

1.     Ethiopia faces a crisis that is broader, deeper and more complex than the food crisis in
almost any other country. The country's economy has been growing at double digit rates for the
last five years. Average agricultural gross domestic product (GDP) growth rates over this period
have also been at double digit rates and the sector still accounts for 44 percent of total GDP. The
growth has, however, not removed the long-standing problem of pervasive food insecurity and
severe vulnerability to shocks. This year the country is under threat from high inflation and a
widening trade deficit, coupled with failed March to May 2008 belg (small season) rains. The
resulting drought and local food shortages in several parts of the country affect some 12 million
people, and exacerbate the rise in food prices already under way due to global, regional1 and
domestic factors. Food price inflation is particular high, peaking at 91.7 percent for the 12 months
ending July 2008 and standing at 81.1 percent by September. Ethiopia has one of the highest food
price inflation rates in the world.

2.     This situation has caused severe hardships for the country and, especially, the most
vulnerable segments of the population. Of Ethiopia's population of about 77 million people
(2007, Central Statistical Agency (CSA) data), 7.3 million chronically food insecure people receive
regular support from the Productive Safety Net Program (PSNP), and of these 4.4 million people
have required supplementary food or cash assistance from the PSNP in addition to normal levels of
support to ensure adequate food consumption until the next harvest. In addition, another estimated
4.6 million rural people had been pushed into food insecurity by June 2008. Today (October 2008),
this number has increased to 6.4 million people dependent on emergency food assistance. The
urban population has also been severely affected by the high inflation; the Government has
estimated that 75,000 children suffer from severe acute malnutrition; and emergency food storages
are virtually empty. The country is eagerly awaiting the meher (main) harvest which is peaking in
October to December. Fortunately, the rains over the last few months and available forecasts
provide the basis for cautious optimism for this harvest, at least in parts of the country.

3.     Much attention has been paid over the last few months to meeting immediate needs for
food. According to the UN, donors have committed US$772 million in assistance related to the
food crisis since March 2008. The PSNP has advanced resources to increase the support to its
worst affected beneficiaries and raise the wage rate to compensate for part of the loss of purchasing
power due to inflation. The Government has imported about 300,000 tons of wheat which it sold in
urban areas at the cost of purchasing (which is below domestic market price) to ease the situation
for the urban poor.

4.     Food production in the coming season is critical, and the Government and partners are
seeking to ensure that inputs and advice are available to farmers in a timely fashion. Some
donors have made commitments to fill the 2009 funding gap for the PSNP created by advancing
resources into 2008 to meet urgent needs. The Government and Development Partners (DPs) have
also started a design process for the next phase of the PSNP. This new design will have improved
linkages to the broader Food Security Program and other relevant government services in rural


1 Crop failures, high food and non-food prices, conflicts, trade disruptions, and inadequate availability of water and
pastures have led to food insecurity in other parts in the Horn of Africa as well.



                                                             5

areas, all with a view to creating an integrated package of services that will provide a sustainable
path to graduation for chronically food insecure households.                      With regard to growth of the
agricultural sector, the Government and the DPs are strengthening existing programs and enhancing
the focus on agricultural growth. For instance, in recent years the agricultural extension system has
been significantly strengthened, and now consists of about 70,000 extension workers throughout the
country. Extension workers interact with farmers through a network of farmer training centers and
cooperatives at the local level. Cooperatives provide their members with training and other services,
including marketing of inputs and outputs. The Government with support of DPs such as FAO,
GTZ, and USAID and relevant stakeholders has launched new initiatives to boost crop production
through improved seeds, including through seed distribution and production of breeder, pre-basic,
basic and certified seeds, as well as multiplication of seeds at the community level.

5.       Nevertheless, at least two critical gaps still remain:

    · First, due to the food crisis the PSNP provided supplementary food and cash assistance to
         4.4 million existing beneficiaries to ensure their consumption until the next harvest. In
         addition, food price inflation in 2008 has left the purchasing power of the cash transfer
         severely diminished, and this needs to be addressed through an adjustment upwards in the
         nominal value of the transfer.             These two unforeseen cost overruns have drained the
         program's resources.           While some donors have committed additional resources, there
         remains a financing gap for 2009.
    · Second, the country is short of foreign exchange needed to import fertilizer2 for the 2009-
         2010 cropping season (see Section B for details). The growth in crop production in recent
         years (prior to the current season) has been due in part to increased use of imported
         fertilizer. Low application of fertilizer next year would most likely result in low yields,
         increased poverty among the 6 to 7 million of small-holder farm households who regularly
         apply fertilizer, and continued or worsened food insecurity.

6.      The proposed Ethiopia-Food Crisis Response Program aims to address these two gaps
under the Global Food Crisis Response Program (GFRP) and in accordance with OP/BP8.00.
The broad goals of the proposed program are to ensure Ethiopia's food security in 2009 by helping
to address the needs of chronically food insecure households and increasing the likelihood that crop
production will remain on or near the growth trend of recent years. The total proposed financing
amount is SDR184.35 million (equivalent to US$275 million) for two Projects under the proposed
Program:
         · A PSNP Additional Financing Project of SDR16.75 million (equivalent to about
               US$25.0 million) would support the Government's efforts to ensure that the PSNP can
               provide adequate coverage of food-insecure households in 2009.
         · A Fertilizer Support Project of SDR167.6 million (equivalent to about US$250.0
               million) would provide the necessary foreign exchange to fertilizer importers to support



2The overall government and donor program also addresses needs to pay attention to other complementary inputs.
Seeds, in particular, are also of significant concern. However, since the value of the seed sector is much smaller than
that for fertilizer and since seeds are largely produced locally, many solutions are being found without major external
assistance or importation.



                                                            6

               the importation and subsequent distribution and sales of a significant share of the
               fertilizer demand for the 2009-2010 season.

7.       The proposed operation is urgent because of the timing of PSNP implementation and
the schedule of Ethiopia's agricultural production cycle. Financing for the PSNP needs to be
provided well ahead of the start of the 2009 program in January. In order to ensure that transfers
can be provided to beneficiaries early in the season ­a critical feature of the project design­ the
Government will need to begin disbursing resources to woredas in early December 2008.
Similarly, international procurement of the first batch of the fertilizer needed for 2009 must be
completed immediately, followed by actual importation and distribution and sales to farmers. The
timing of Ethiopia's agricultural production cycle is shown in Box 2 below.

 Box 1: The Agricultural Production Cycle in Ethiopia

 The urgency of the fertilizer operation under the Food Crisis Response Program is a result of the country's
 agricultural cycle. The two growing seasons in Ethiopia are belg (small rains) and meher (main rains).
 Ethiopia's agriculture is primarily driven by meher season production, which accounts for more than 90
 percent of the value of annual grain production. Cereals, pulses, and oilseeds dominate the crop sector,
 accounting for more than 70 percent of the production value; another about 10 percent is from coffee.
 Major crops are concentrated in the Central, Western, and Northwestern highlands of Ethiopia. Besides the
 availability of inputs, the performance of meher crops, or 90 percent of the value of agricultural output,
 depends crucially on kiremt rains from June through September. As shown below, the agricultural cycle
 dictates the procurement and distribution process of fertilizers, and pace of the project. To show an impact,
 the project has to become effective in early December, to allow minimum time for the logistics and
 distribution of fertilizers to farmers for the 2009 belg and meher season.


                                                         Kiremt rains                       Meher harvest



            Belg rains                              Belg harvest                          Minor pastoral rains


   February   March         April       May    June    July      August  September  October    November    December  January



           Distribution of fertilizers                                               Procurement and purchase of fertilizers

                                                                         Project preparation, appraisal,
                                                                                and negotiations

Assisted Development Project, the Post Secondary Education Project, and the Rural Capacity

                                    B. MACRO-ECONOMIC CONTEXT

Recent Developments

9.     Ethiopia has made some impressive development gains in the past few years.                   Its
economy has grown at a robust rate of between 8-13 percent annually for five consecutive years--
raising the living standard of millions of its people from a very low base. The poverty headcount
ratio has declined from 44 percent in FY00 to 39 percent in FY05, and has likely continued to fall
given the high levels of growth. The country's physical and social infrastructure has expanded
rapidly: between FY00 and FY07, the federal paved road network has increased by 43 percent;
power generation capacity has nearly doubled; primary school enrollment has increased from 5.2
million to 13 million; and most health indicators have shown steady improvements.

10.    However, the development process has been accompanied by growing macroeconomic
imbalance. Although most countries in the world currently face a difficult macro environment, the
situation in Ethiopia is unusually severe. This is the first time in the last two decades that Ethiopia
has confronted the twin challenges of high inflation and low international reserves. The inflation
rate is at a historical peak, with the twelve month average inflation reaching 37.2 percent for the
period ending in September 2008. The twelve month end-of-period inflation rate stood at 59.7




                                                            8

percent5--substantially higher relative to its own past as well as to other countries in the region.
International reserves have gradually depleted and barely covered 1.2 months of imports of goods
and nonfactor services at the end of June 2008 (see Table 2).

Table 2: Selected macro indicators

11.     Food price inflation is particularly high. Food price inflation, which stood at 81.1 percent
in the 12 months ending September 2008, has far exceeded overall inflation (see Figure 1).
However, there has now been a modest decline since the inflation peak in July 2008 (91.7 percent).
The high food inflation is mainly attributed to the rise in the cereal prices which have increased by
157 percent during the 12 months ending September 2008.

12.     Ethiopia's high inflation has been caused by a combination of several factors. Growth
in supply has lagged behind growth in domestic demand. The Government strategy to invest
heavily in infrastructure and social services as a way to stimulate growth in the private sector has
created rapid expansion in domestic demand and overall GDP. While the business environment has
improved, the supply response has not kept pace with the double-digit demand growth. This has
laid the ground for rising trade deficits and inflation. Two exogenous shocks have exacerbated the
situation in 2008. The steep rise in global prices has increased Ethiopia's import bills, and affected
domestic inflation (especially fuel). The failure of the belg rain and consequent reduction in
production caused shortages of food in some areas and contributed to the general rise in food prices.
An accommodative monetary policy and significant borrowing by public enterprises fueled
aggregate demand, raising prices and increasing the demand for imports.                          Finally, with the
relentless price rise, inflationary expectations have taken root in recent months.6


5This inflation measure is slightly down from its peak in July 2008 (64.1 percent).
6How much Ethiopia's inflation is globally induced and how much is the result of domestic policies has been a subject
of great debate in the country. For two different views on this subject see "Explaining Food Price Inflation Policy



                                                           9

13.                The foreign exchange shortage, which is the third such episode in the last one decade,
has been caused by a number of inter-related structural factors. In recent years Ethiopia
growth process has become highly import-dependent, with import-growth elasticity being close
to 3. While some of the import dependency is explained by the need to build large infrastructure
(e.g., six hydropower dams are at various stages of construction), there has also been considerable
increase in import of consumption goods. The latter is explained by Ethiopia's small and stagnant
manufacturing sector (relative to the size of the rest of the economy)--thus increased demand for
manufacturing product has resulted in either increased imports or shortage in domestic market (and
thus higher prices). Since the domestic savings rate is low and falling, increased imports have
translated into large and growing current account deficits. While these structural constraints have
contributed to the large external imbalance of Ethiopia, the situation became overwhelming during
2007/08, after the food, fuel and fertilizer prices in global market started to rapidly escalate.

14.                The social impact of the current crisis is expected to be considerable. The price of the
consumption bundle that the poor consumes is estimated to have risen by 78 percent in urban areas
and by 85 percent in rural areas during the last two years. While the overall income of farmers has
risen faster than the increase in the general price level,7 given that nearly 50 percent of rural
households are net food buyers, the net impact of inflation is likely to modestly reduce welfare in
rural areas and to do so markedly in the urban areas.8 In addition, smallholders could suffer

8 The discussion on the social impact of food inflation is based on the latest rounds of household surveys in 1999/00

(about 10 percent of own production), net buyers were unlikely to be selling because of distress sales after the harvest.



                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   10

significant income losses, if fertilizer were not available ­ the simulated impact of the unavailability
of fertilizer is an increase in the rural poverty headcount of as much as 5 percentage points.9

Government Response to the Macroeconomic Crisis

15.    In recognition of the seriousness of the problem, Government has undertaken a
number of actions to reduce aggregate demand and to cool down the overheated economy.
Specific measures include:

    · Considerable adjustment on the fiscal front. The Government has announced a budget for
         FY09 that includes a reduction in the fiscal deficit to 3.2 percent of GDP (from 4.3 percent
         of GDP in FY08), a decline in the total federal expenditure to 19.6 percent of GDP (from
         21.3 percent of GDP in FY08), and a lowering in the domestic borrowing requirement to 1.5
         percent of GDP (from 2.4 percent of GDP in FY08). The Government has further indicated
         that it will reduce domestic borrowing further, if the funds of the proposed emergency food
         crisis operation become available to assist with the urgent needs to finance fertilizer imports
         and the safety net activities (see Table 3). While there is no evidence yet to confirm a
         slowdown in the investment program of the public enterprises, given the sharp decline in
         money supply growth (see bullet-point below) and severe shortage of foreign exchange,
         they are being forced to reexamine their investment plans. It is however too early to assess
         whether the Government will be able to halve the public sector domestic borrowing during
         FY09 from around 5 percent of GDP in FY08, as had been suggested by the IMF.

    · Elimination of fuel price subsidy. The Government has recently eliminated the fuel subsidy
         by fully adjusting the domestic prices to import parity level. The prices of gasoline, diesel,
         fuel oil, and kerosene have been adjusted upwards by 6 percent, 39 percent, 32 percent, and
         50 percent, respectively. This measure alone is expected to reduce off-budget expenditure
         by nearly US$200-250 million annually. The Government has also indicated that, in the
         future, fuel prices will be adjusted at a monthly frequency.

are projections.
Source: 2008 Article IV staff report, IMF, and MOFED.

    · Modest tightening of monetary policy. The National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) has raised the
         minimum reserve requirements on commercial bank deposits twice (from 5 to 10 percent,
         and then to 15 percent), and has increased the minimum time and saving deposit rate from 3
         to 4 percent since July 2007. The authorities have agreed to contain the money growth
         target for FY09 to below 20 percent, lower than the 22.7 percent growth achieved during
         FY08. In a recent discussion, the Government has indicated that the money supply growth
         may be further reduced to a 14-17 percent range. The authorities have also agreed with the
         IMF to limit direct central bank financing of the budget.

    · Flexibility in the exchange rate. During the discussion with the IMF Article IV mission in
         May 2008, the authorities have agreed that more flexibility in exchange rate movement
         could in principle be beneficial, but were anxious to avoid sharp corrections of the exchange
         rate--not least, because they could fan inflationary expectations.

    · Measures to mitigate the impact of inflation. To soften the impact of inflation on the most
         vulnerable population, the Government has imported 300,000 tons of food grains (around
         2 percent of domestic crop production) using its own resources and has been selling it to
         urban poor at a subsidized price. The Government has removed valued added tax, turnover
         tax, and surtaxes on some food items. It has also increased the cash transfer in its safety net
         programs from ETB6 to ETB8 per day and is contemplating further adjustment.

Future outlook

16.     Ethiopia's economy is expected to significantly slowdown in the coming years due to the
macroeconomic difficulties at home and financial turmoil abroad. With widespread shortage of
foreign exchange, most economic activities dependent on imported inputs have already begun to
slowdown (e.g., construction and infrastructure projects and a number of manufacturing activities).
The volume of export of top three commodities, namely coffee, oilseeds and chat, registered
negative growth during FY08. The excessive real appreciation of the local currency is likely to
further dampen exports and exacerbate the external imbalance. The recent fall-out from the global
financial crisis and the impeding recession in developed countries are expected to result in lower
remittances, reduced demand for Ethiopian exports and lower unit prices for exports of coffee and
other commodities. While some of these impacts will be offset by the decline in global oil prices,
the net effect will be increased downside risks to growth.




                                                        12

17.     The IMF forecasts lower growth, high current account deficit and increasing pressure
on public finance for Ethiopia.10 Buffeted by global crisis and domestic problems, Ethiopia's
economy is expected to grow at 6 to7 percent rate in the medium-term, healthy by global norm, but
considerably below its performance of the recent past. The current account deficit is estimated to
be between 11-12 percent of GDP in the medium-term. The country is expected to face an external
financing gap of around US$1 billion in the next three years, which would require greater external
assistance from key donor partners. The slowdown of the economy and reduced imports are likely
to lower the already falling domestic revenue­GDP ratio to around 12.5 percent.                           Since the
Government is committed to keeping the fiscal deficit low (around 3% of GDP) and to reduce
domestic borrowing, the impact of the crisis would be felt through reduced growth of public
expenditure, especially in the non-social sectors.11

18.     The recent Debt Sustainability Analysis (DSA) undertaken in July 2008 concluded that
Ethiopia's risk of debt distress remains moderate because of the large financing needs of the
public enterprises over the next ten years. Ethiopia reached its HIPC Initiative completion point in
2004 and benefited from debt relief under the MDRI in 2006. The debt relief provided under both
initiatives helped to lower the debt ratio to less than 10 percent of GDP at the end of 2006/07.
Although the current debt burden indicators remain below the policy-dependent thresholds, three
stress tests breach the threshold for the Net Present Value (NPV) of debt to exports ratio when the
debt stock is measured inclusive of public enterprises.

IMF's Involvement in Ethiopia

19.     At the request of the Government, the IMF has been undertaking semi-annual
surveillance missions to Ethiopia. The authorities have responded to IMF advice and several
recent policy moves are in line with recommendations in the Article IV staff report. Ethiopia has
also expressed interest in a rapid-access component of the "Exogenous Shock Facility." In light of
ongoing strains on the balance of payments and further increases in inflation, an IMF staff visit in
December will review the needed policy response. The Bank is working closely with the Fund and
the authorities to restore Ethiopia's macroeconomic balance (see para. 22).

Status of Dialogue on Structural Issues

20.     The current macroeconomic problems point to structural weaknesses in the Ethiopian
economy. The imbalance between rapidly growing demand and sluggish supply is at the core of
the growing trade deficit and high inflation. The policy discussions on this problem between the
Bank and the Government have been centered on improvements in three areas: (i) the investment
climate and to attract more foreign investment into the manufacturing sector; (ii) reforming the
services sector including financial and telecommunication services; and (iii) raising the allocative
efficiency of the land market.

21.     The Government recognizes the need for a coherent and credible structural reform
program to address the country's macro problems. The Government has implemented certain

10See the latest IMF Staff Report for the 2008 Article IV Consultation for Ethiopia (June 2008).
11The bulk of the social sector spending through block grants to woredas is expected to be protected by the Protection
of Basic Services project--a multi-donor project to support decentralized public service delivery in basic education,
primary health, water supply, agriculture and rural roads.



                                                          13

structural reforms in recent months, which though modest, signal commitment to address the
structural constraints underlying the macro problems. For example, the Government has recently
liberalized entry for private operators in the domestic civil aviation sector, allowed the entry of a
new domestic bank whose business model is based on extensive use of information technology and
greater focus on retail lending (unlike the existing set of private banks that have mimicked the
business model of the public sector bank), and has set-up a modern commodity exchange for bulk
trading by the private sector.

22.    The Bank is working closely with the Ethiopian authorities on a sustainable, medium-
term framework designed to restore macroeconomic balance. Recently, the Government has
set up a `technical committee,' headed by the State Minister of Finance and Economic
Development, to identify the structural constraints facing the economy and to suggest policy
options to eliminate those constraints. The policy recommendation of the committee is expected to
be informed by various analytical works undertaken by the World Bank and the Government in
recent years (see Box 3). The World Bank is also bringing in various international experts to
Ethiopia to help the Government learn from the experience of other successful developing
countries. The Government is expected to share the roadmap of its structural reform program with
the World Bank in the form of a development policy letter in December.

 Box 2: Analytical Underpinning of Ongoing Policy Discussions

 The ongoing policy dialogue between the Government of Ethiopia (GoE) and the World Bank is
 underpinned by a number of economic and sector works carried out by the World Bank, other donor
 partners (e.g., IMF), and the Government in recent years. Some of these studies include:

 Policy Note on Structural Origins of Ethiopia's Macro Problems (2008):            This Note examines the
 structural roots of Ethiopia's macroeconomic problems and proposes a number of reform options. The
 Government has set up a `technical committee' to study the Note and to come up with a medium-term
 `reform program' that will provide a lasting solution to the country's macroeconomic difficulties.

 Macroeconomic assessments: Most recently, this includes the IMF's Article IV Consultation carried out in
 July 2008. The results of a Country Economic Memorandum (2007) - Ethiopia: Accelerating Equitable
 Growth has also shaped the policy dialogue.

 Public expenditure management: A series of public expenditure reviews have been instrumental in
 identifying reforms necessary for improved aggregate fiscal management and allocative efficiency. Most
 recent reviews include: (i) Ethiopia Review of Public Finance (2008); and (ii) Ethiopia Agriculture and
 Rural Development Public Expenditure Review 1997/98 - 2005/06. These analyses are currently being
 updated and expanded.

 Private and financial sector development: Two recent studies underpin the dialogue on private and
 financial sector issues: an Investment Climate Assessment (2008) - Toward the Competitive Frontier:
 Strategies for Improving Ethiopia's Investment Climate and a Policy Note (2008) on Making Finance Work
 for Ethiopia.

 Sector work: The Bank has also undertaken a number of sector work that have informed the ongoing policy
 discussions: Impacts of Land Certification on Tenure Security, Investment, and Land Markets: Evidence
 from Ethiopia (2008); Explaining Food Price Inflation (2007); In Makeda's Footsteps: Towards a Strategy
 for Pro-Poor Tourism Development; and Ethiopia-Rural Investment Climate Assessment (draft, 2008).

 Government strategy: The Bank's dialogue is also underpinned by the GoE's own development strategy - A
 Plan for Accelerated and Sustained Development to End Poverty: 2005/06 - 2009/10 - and the Annual
 Policy Reviews.



                                                     14

                                                         C. SECTOR CONTEXT

The Agricultural Sector

23.     Ethiopia's agricultural sector is a major contributor to the economy and is central to
food security and poverty reduction. Any slowdown in agricultural growth will affect the
country's overall GDP growth. Agriculture accounts for an estimated 44 percent of national GDP,
almost 86 percent of exports, and 85 percent of employment. Nearly 90 percent of the poor depend
on agriculture for their livelihood. Additionally, agriculture determines the country's overall food
security at an aggregate level and is also crucial for reducing the food deficit for about 15 million
persons who are chronically or transiently food insecure.

24.     Ethiopia has substantial potential for increased agricultural growth. The World Bank
estimated in 2005 that doubling cereal yields in the more food secure areas and increasing cereal
yields by 50 percent in the food insecure areas was well within the realm of the possible. This is
underlined by a strong agricultural growth trend of the past five years. According to official data,
recent growth of the agriculture sector has been very strong, averaging about 11 percent per annum
since the 2003 drought (see Figure 3). Supported by several consecutive years with good weather,
Ethiopia's cereal production has shown a strong performance (see Table 4).

25.     Recent developments have been supported by a number of factors. Weather has been
favorable since 2003, but other factors have also played a crucial role. The Government has
strongly emphasized agriculture in its overall development strategy, the Plan for Accelerated and
Sustained Development to End Poverty (PASDEP), which calls for "Accelerating Market-based
Agricultural Development." The focus of this strategy is on Ethiopia's more than 13 million
smallholder farm households,12 which produce around 98 percent of Ethiopia's agricultural output.


12According to the 2007/08 CSA Agricultural Sample Survey, the average household has 5.23 members and only about
0.9 hectare of crop area. The average household total holding including grazing land, woodland, and other land is only a
bit more than 1 hectare; less then 1.5 percent have holding of 5 hectare or more.



                                                                               15

The Government's commitment to agricultural development is reflected in its emphasis of
agriculture in the budget.          Including rural infrastructure, expenditure for agriculture and rural
development has been around 25 percent of total spending, one of the highest shares in the world.13

26.     The agricultural sector has shown signs of transformation. Much of the spending, both
directly and through the productive safety net, has been on infrastructure, including irrigation and
water and soil conservation measures. Investments in agricultural research have increased and land
tenure security has improved significantly with the provision of land certificates to millions of
smallholders. Given the focus of the proposed Fertilizer Support Project, particularly noteworthy
are also the investments in the public agricultural extension system.                        This system has been
expanded with the objective of playing a central role in the transformation of Ethiopian agriculture
from its current subsistence orientation into a market-oriented production system. The system has
increased rapidly from around 15,000 extension workers in 2002 to about 70,000 today. Farmer
training centers have been built in many kebeles (administrative villages) and training has been
provided to thousands of farmers. In addition, the extension services make use of individual, group
and mass media approaches to deliver knowledge. A crucial aspect is the delivery of "packages" to
farmers. Regular packages, for example, aim at enabling farmers to adopt improved seeds and
commercial fertilizer together with improved management and soil moisture conservation practices.

27.     Government policy emphasizes agriculture. Not only has public spending on agricultural
investments and services increased rapidly and accounted for about 18 percent of the overall
budget14, but a number of supporting policies have also been put in place.                          For instance, an
important recent development supported by the Government is that of farmers' cooperatives and
their amalgamation into cooperative unions. The Government's aim is that cooperative services are
extended throughout the country to supply inputs to smallholders and market the output. The
support for cooperatives has been in place since 1994,15 but received renewed attention in the last
few years.      As of 2005-06, cooperative coverage was already estimated at 35 percent of all
kebeles.16 Given the strong government support, the number and membership of cooperatives have
grown rapidly since then.17


13The food security issues and vulnerability of the country has resulted in food security spending making up almost
half of expenditure for agriculture and rural development.
14This is based on actual figures for the 2007/08 budget year, including (capital) expenses for Natural Resources.
15See Proclamations 85/1994, 147/1998, and 402/2004.
16Only 17 percent of households living in a given kebele actually participated actively in a cooperative (Spielman
2008), but cooperatives are serving also non-members.
17In fact, the five-year-plan of the Federal Cooperative Agency (2006) states as one of its objective to "make 70
percent of the society user of the cooperatives' services" and to "increase the cooperatives' input marketing coverage
from its present level of 70 percent to 90 percent."



                                                          16

28.     Overall, the role of the cooperatives appears to be positive. The cooperatives are serving
to amalgamate smallholders for purposes of finance and marketing of inputs and outputs. Since
most cooperatives are relatively new, however, and given the mixed experience with cooperatives
elsewhere, several concerns have been raised. In particular, there is concern that cooperatives and
their unions receive disproportionate support relative to non-cooperative private entities. This
could limit their independence and accountability to members, and also reduce contestation in the
economic sphere that would keep them efficient.               Nevertheless, the cooperatives have clearly
played a constructive role in the increased access to fertilizer in recent years and the subsequent
increase in production.

29.     The recent growth in agriculture, although impressive, is from a low base. Ethiopia's
agricultural sector continues to be of subsistence nature; land is fragmented, often highly degraded
and predominantly rain-fed.18 The country's grain economy is quite insular and poorly linked to
international markets. Food grains are hardly imported except as food aid. Food grains are also not
exported. The country is not a natural exporter given domestic consumption and high costs of
transport. Domestic cereal prices are currently above their import parity prices,19 indicating poor
price transmission from international markets. Even though Ethiopia has established an export ban
on food grains established in early 2006, this is of limited significance in this environment.

30.     Ethiopia remains highly vulnerable to external and domestic shocks.                         The recent
performance of agriculture is in some respects puzzling; production of food grains has increased
steadily and substantially over the past five years, yet the country remains highly vulnerable to
external shocks, in particular droughts, and the number of people affected does not appear to be
declining. Shocks have time and again disrupted promising longer-term developments and have
taken a toll with not just immediate, but also more sustained negative effects. Even a small shock
of 10 percent lower rainfall in a particular year is estimated to reduce growth 4-5 years later by one
percentage point (Dercon 2004, World Bank CEM 2007). Analysis indicates that recent growth has
been due largely to expansion of area onto increasingly marginal lands. Increased use of fertilizer
has obviated the decline in yields that would be expected from expansion onto marginal areas, and
has facilitated the modest increase in yields shown in Table 4.

Food Security and the Productive Safety Net Program

31.     Addressing structural sources of chronic food insecurity requires long-term
interventions. Given the high levels of chronic food insecurity in Ethiopia, and following a severe
drought in 2002/2003, the Government with DPs developed the New Coalition for Food Security, a
long-term policy framework for reducing hunger and food insecurity in Ethiopia. As part of this
initiative, it launched the Food Security Program, which combined a series of complementary
interventions designed to enable food insecure households to acquire sufficient assets and income to
"graduate" out of food insecurity and improve their resilience to shocks.


18 Grain production is characterized by the dominant (meher) rains from around June to October and with harvest
around November and December; and secondary (belg) rains between March and May with harvest around May and
June. Of course, this is a general description and there exist variations among different agro-ecological zones in
relation to production cycles.
19See Ethiopia Commodity Exchange (EXC) Market Bulletin Nr. 15, 2008.



                                                       17

32.    The shift from food aid to cash transfers is an essential part of the Government's
strategy. The Government decided that an alternative to food aid was needed to support the
consumption needs of chronic, predictably food-insecure households, as well as to address some of
the major underlying causes of food insecurity. Hence, as part of the Food Security Program, the
Government started implementation of the PSNP in 2005. The PSNP replaced the emergency
humanitarian appeal system as the chief instrument for assisting initially 5 million chronically food-
insecure people in rural Ethiopia. It was scaled up to reach 7.3 million people in 2006. The PSNP
provides cash and in-kind resources to chronically food insecure households through labor-
intensive public works as well as through direct support to labor poor households (including the
elderly, sick and female headed households). The focus of the public works program is on soil and
water conservation activities, developed within an integrated watershed management planning
framework. The PSNP operates in rural areas in approximately one third of the country. Given its
scale and focus, PSNP public works represent a unique opportunity to contribute to environmental
transformation in Ethiopia, by promoting, financing, and implementing sustainable land
management measures at an unprecedented scale.

33.    The World Bank is supporting the Government's strategy, including by providing
support to the PSNP through a three-phase APL, which is currently nearing the end of the
second phase. The implementation of the current APL II is rated "satisfactory" (see Annex 1 A for
a review of progress in implementation and project impact). Evidence to date indicates that the
PSNP at its current scale and scope, in spite of the crisis suffered in 2008, is having a substantial
impact on beneficiary livelihoods as measured by income and assets.

34.    A consortium of donor partners is equally part of the current efforts to strengthen food
security. The World Bank APL II Project is part of a much larger Government program supported
by a consortium of partners including CIDA, DFID, IrishAID, EC, RNE, SIDA USAID, and WFP,
who together have committed cash and in-kind resources valued at around US$1.2 billion during
the current phase of the Program from 2007-2009. The donor group has pooled its financing and
several partners have provided their support as co-financing to the World Bank APL II Project. At
its current scale, the PSNP represents one of the largest social protection initiatives in Africa.

Fertilizer and Complementary Agricultural Inputs

35.    Efforts to enhance agricultural growth complement the focus on food security and
social protection. Key elements of the growth strategy include improved access to fertilizer and
seeds, agro-chemicals, water, etc., and the closely related rural financial and agricultural extension
systems. Fertilizer is applied to approximately 40 percent of total farmland under crop production,
and is heavily concentrated on a few cereals (wheat, teff, and maize).20                            Improved seeds are
purchased for less than 5 percent of the total cultivated cereal area. Approximately one percent of
the total cultivated area in Ethiopia is irrigated. The limited use of modern technology is consistent
with the low average yields in cereal production of less than 1.5 tons/ha.

36.    Modern agricultural inputs are a crucial ingredient to sustain agricultural growth
based on improved productivity. Fertilizers require significant financial resources, in particular


20This figure refers to `commercial fertilizer' (for definition and data see CSA Agricultural Sample Survey). In
addition, natural fertilizers are applied, but only to around 15 percent of the total cultivated area.



                                                              18

after recent price hikes, and ­ together with seeds ­ are the most important short-term determinants
of the next year's harvest.21 Fertilizers, where applied, can easily make up a third to a half of total
purchased inputs, if field services such as oxen power or labor are purchased, or even two thirds or
more of total input costs otherwise. Moreover, unlike seeds which are produced locally, fertilizer is
dependent on international prices22 and on the availability of foreign exchange.

37.      Utilization of fertilizer at less than 40 kg per hectare of cultivated area is still low by
global standards, but growing rapidly. The use of chemical fertilizer has increased considerably
from the time of its introduction in Ethiopia in the late 1960s and early 1970s. It rose to an
estimated 400,000 tons in 2006/07 and more than 450,000 tons in 2007/08. Forty-four percent of
poor small-holder households used fertilizer in 2005.23 Many of the few large-scale commercial
farms can import their own fertilizer from retained export earnings, whilst the fertilizer for which
the Government allocates foreign exchange to enable its importation is primarily used by millions
of smallholder farmers with an average crop area of under one hectare.

38.      Ethiopia has to import all chemical fertilizers, making the supply dependent on the
country's foreign exchange reserves.                    An estimate of the fertilizer demand of Ethiopia's
smallholder farmers24 each year is submitted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development
(MOARD)25 to the NBE based on which NBE sets aside the foreign exchange needed.                                     A
Government committee then floats several tenders and allocates the necessary foreign exchange to
importers able to document the lowest price from a foreign supplier.

39.      A number of international fertilizer companies are competing to supply Ethiopia's
fertilizer market. A study (Development Studies Associates 2006) analyzing the period from
1995/96 to 2004/05 lists more than a dozen suppliers, on average four per year.                             More are
competing in the bidding process.26 Traditionally, much of the fertilizer (only Diammonium
Phosphate (DAP) and urea are used) are imported from the Middle East market.27 The study
concludes that this competitiveness stems from their location advantage (proximity to Ethiopia).

40.      A number of commercial entities, in particular cooperatives, are engaged in fertilizer
import and distribution. Recently, cooperative unions, the parastatal Agricultural Input Supply
Enterprise (AISE), and few private companies have participated in the import of fertilizer. The

21For estimates of supply response and economics of fertilizers see Annex 2 G.
22These are still quite high, despite a significant reduction in prices over the last few months.
23This is based on a farm household survey interviewees responding on use of fertilizer with "often" or "always".
24The demand estimate also includes some demand from the few remaining state farms. Commercial farmers with
export commodities can purchase their fertilizer directly using their foreign exchange without having to rely on the
Government's mechanism to allocate foreign exchange for fertilizer.
25The process begins with Development Agents (i.e., extension agents) at the farmer level estimating the demand for
fertilizer and other agricultural inputs and associated credit, and aggregates upward through the woreda-level
Bureaus/offices of Agriculture, Zonal Administrations, Regions, and finally the Federal level.            It takes into
consideration the existing stocks.
26 In order to improve its efficiency in the import of fertilizer, the Government has been reflecting on the
recommendation of the technical team advising the new fertilizer facility set up at the African Development Bank in
response to recommendations of the Africa Fertilizer Summit in Abuja, and now intends to procure fertilizer in bulk
rather than in batches of 25,000 tons. See procurement arrangements for proposed Fertilizer Support Project in
Annex 2 C.
27For instance, Jordan Phosphate and Hydro-Agri (supplying from Saudi Arabia) had a market share of more than 50
percent for DAP and urea respectively.



                                                             19

domestic distribution of fertilizers is mainly through the cooperative system, including much of the
fertilizer imported by AISE.28

41.     Policies shaping the fertilizer market have changed in recent years, and several key
deficiencies have been addressed. While previously the state dominated the fertilizer market
including through direct distribution by extension agents,29 reforms over the last few years have: (a)
reduced the direct role of the state and increased that of the cooperatives; (b) made the allocation of
foreign exchange and importation of fertilizer more open and transparent; (c) shifted extension
agents back to their advisory role; and (d) eliminated fertilizer subsidies and piloted the elimination
of credit guarantees (in high-potential areas, in 2008).30 These are positive developments, although
the system is still highly concentrated and farmers have limited choice in their source of fertilizer.

42.     There is no evidence of rent-seeking behavior and farm gate prices seem to reflect
border prices plus transport costs and small margins, but farmers complain about
inefficiencies related to the timing, packaging and other aspects of the distribution system.
These inefficiencies are largely related to capacity constraints such as with respect to the logistics
of fertilizer transport, storage, handling, etc. Moreover, improvements are needed in the rural credit
system, the extension system, and the provision of seeds and other complementary inputs. For
example, the rural financial sector serving the farming community is negligible31 and the seed
market is underdeveloped with a consequence of low seed production, thus dampening the yield
increases achievable with the fertilizer.

43.     Remaining inefficiencies in the fertilizer market should be addressed once they are
clearly understood.32 As remaining inefficiencies involve long-term institutional issues, they
cannot be addressed quickly and will require sustained work. As the Independent Evaluation Group
(IEG) (2007) report states: "Based on the lessons from the past, barriers to fair market competition
are not necessarily obvious. To complete liberalization it would be important to continuously

28Last year, AISE's business in distribution was largely limited to those areas not served by the members of importing
cooperative unions and only about 15 percent of its sales went outside the cooperative system.
29 A Bank-financed National Fertilizer Support Project (NFSP) closed in 2002 having failed to achieve its main
objective of facilitating creation of a competitive market with participation of private distributors and stockists.
Policies introduced during the course of implementation of the NFSP discriminated against private seed production and
the private retailing of fertilizer (and seed), and assigned the task to the public sector with implementation by extension
agents (which included administering credit).
30The credit guarantees provided by Regional Governments constitutes an implicit fertilizer subsidy as the interest rate
is below commercially sustainable rates and the regional governments are covering for defaults. However, there exists
no explicit fertilizer subsidy in Ethiopia and the government has no intention to change this.
31Greater access to credit through the rural financial systems would strengthen farmers' ability to access fertilizers from
distributors on a cash basis outside the cooperative system.
32A recent IEG (2007) report, which confirms the unsuccessful NFSP and market developments, also refers to some of
the positive decisions, i.e. those "to reduce collateral, interest rates, and service charges, most at uniform levels for all
importers". But it also states that "while steps appear to be in the right direction, care will be needed to ensure that
these and other actions truly provide for equal treatment." The issues noted by IEG persist today. For instance, credit
guarantees by Regional Government to cooperatives advantage the cooperatives over other private sector entities
interested in participating in the distribution system, and the absence of competition could raise costs to farmers. Yet in
many African countries without Ethiopia's tightly structured cooperative system, the markets are too thin to support a
robustly competitive network of private distributors, and the advantages of the more competitive structure are not
obvious. The substantial effort on monitoring and evaluation under the project will help elucidate the strengths and
weak points of the present Ethiopian system and provide guidance on its evolution in the future. The monitoring and
evaluation will also provide transparency to the distribution of fertilizer imported in the coming year.



                                                              20

monitor the fertilizer market to ensure the conditions needed for open competition and private
sector development." The proposed operation builds in resources for such monitoring.

44.    Despite a sharp price increase in fertilizers compared to last year, the current domestic
demand appears to be high. The international export price of DAP, for example, has more than
quadrupled from about US$260 per ton on average in 2006 to US$1,177 per ton in August 2008.
Since then, the price decreased slowly to about US$900 in October 2008. The international price of
urea has more than tripled from US$223 per ton in January-December 2006 to more than US$800
per ton in August 2008. However, largely caused by the recent financial crisis and drop in energy
prices, the price dropped to only US$350 in mid-October 2008. If demand for fertilizer for the
2008/09 season were to remain constant, the total value of fertilizer consumed would increase from
US$267 million in 2007/08 to about US$340 million at current spot market prices. However,
MOARD expects future demand to exceed that of last year as domestic crop price increases have
been even higher than fertilizer prices. MOARD `lowest demand' scenario is for 550,000 tons,
which amounts to a total cost of US$443 million under spot-price assumptions plus international
costs of shipment and handling (see also Annex 2 F). The bulk of the fertilizer will have to be
imported during the next few months to assure availability for the next planting season.

45.    Together with fertilizer seeds are the most crucial short-term agricultural input. The
production and market for improved seeds in Ethiopia is small and the gap between the use of high-
yielding varieties and Government targets ­ as well as farmer demand as determined by the public
extension system ­ is substantial. In a recent assessment of the PASDEP (MOFED 2008) the
Government states that "The supply of inputs, particularly improved seeds has not kept pace with
demand". According to the CSA Agricultural Sample Surveys, only about 4 percent of the total
crop area is planted with commercially produced improved seeds.33 The short-term availability of
seeds is further limited by the failure of the belg rain, which affected not just food production but
also production of certified seeds.

46.    The Government has taken a number of steps to improve availability of seeds. Several
important steps have been taken in the last few years. In particular, an important decision was to
decentralize the public research infrastructure in order to, among other things, make research more
responsive to Ethiopia's diverse agro-ecological zones. The organization of the Government-owned
Ethiopian Seed Enterprise (ESE) is also reflecting this trend of decentralization as it has established
local branches. The aim is not just to reduce costs and to make production of seeds more profitable,
but also to share experience with and support the emergence of local seed companies and
commercial seed-growing farmers and, thereby, to more directly satisfy the diverse needs of
farmers. In parallel, the changes in terms of seed quality control and the introduction of the concept
of quality declared seed can provide more opportunities for the local private sector. In addition, the
proclamation on plant breeder's rights signifies a clear message to the commercial sector that it has
an important role to play in Ethiopia. It aims at increasing access to foreign varieties (important for
export horticulture) and at stimulating plant breeding at home.

47.    Given the significant gap between demand and supply, in particular this year, the
government has now launched a new strategic plan to address this problem. Involving all


33The total area using improved seeds is much higher as many farmers `reuse' their own (or their neighbor's) grain for
seeds.



                                                        21

stakeholders including public research, farmer cooperatives, extension, private seed companies,
etc., this plan aims at boosting production of breeder, pre-basic, basic and certified seeds. The
success of the Government's more recent initiatives remain to be seen. While they signal steps in
the right direction, more will need to be done. In particular, the role of the private sector in the
production of hybrid varieties and of the private sector and farmers in seed multiplication needs to
be further strengthened. Seed companies have been complaining about issues such as limited
access to irrigated land in good locations and access to finance. Since the production of seed is
largely done domestically, the Government is able to address them with its own resources. Other
donors, including FAO, are providing technical and other support.

48.      Other complementary inputs are also crucial. This includes, in particular, measures with
somewhat longer-term impact34 such as agricultural extension, rural finance, land administration
services, irrigation and drainage, roads and infrastructural services. As mentioned above (see
para. 22), substantial developments are taking place in many of these areas.


                         D. THE GOVERNMENT AND DONOR STRATEGY

49.      Government and DPs coordinate their response to the food crisis through the
Development Assistance Group as well as other institutions. The Sector Working Group for
Rural Economic Development and Food Security and its technical committees, in particular the
technical committees for food security and for agricultural and rural growth, are actively
coordinating the response. For instance, in addition to their longer-standing commitments, FAO,
GTZ, USAID, and others are responding to the crisis by importing seeds, planting material or other
agricultural inputs and/or providing technical assistance to increase the supply response to these
inputs. Japan has also continued its long-standing support to provide some fertilizer.

50.      The Government, with support from its DPs, is addressing the impact of the food crisis
through a broad range of measures. The Government is simultaneously seeking to: (i) address
the macroeconomic imbalance and weak foreign exchange position (see Section B); (ii) strengthen
safety nets for the poor; and (iii) maintain supply of inputs, and particularly fertilizer, for next
season's crop.

51.      Mitigating the impacts on the poor has focused on both urban and rural areas. A new
urban support program, launched in 2007 and scaled up in 2008, has distributed subsidized grain to
poor urban households with the additional aim of mitigating food price inflation. The Government
is currently importing 300,000 tons of wheat and distributing it in urban centers at cost to flour
mills, traders, and consumer associations. Additionally, the Government has removed turnover tax
and value added tax on all grains.35 The Government also launched an updated Humanitarian
Appeal in June to cover the food and non-food needs of 4.6 million drought-affected persons



34Another important short-term complementary input are agro-chemicals. However, their use in Ethiopia is currently
rather limited. According to one estimate, pesticides are applied on about 14 percent of the cultivated area. The total
market size is estimated to be very small.
35The Government has also undertaken a number of measures in recent months to contain overall inflation, including a
modest tightening of monetary policy, increasing the reserve requirement, commitment to lower the growth rate of
broad money supply, and reducing the fiscal deficit.



                                                          22

outside of the PSNP. About US$261 million have been provided by donors in response to this
request (see Table 5).

52.     Within the PSNP the Government worked with DPs to provide immediate additional
support to 4.4 million drought-affected beneficiaries of the Program to protect their consumption
needs until the next harvest. The cost of this has been around US$67 million. Government was
able to mobilize financing for this through various sources. A US$25 million contingent grant
under the Drought Risk Financing component of the World Bank PSNP APL II Project, designed
for this purpose, was disbursed.36 With the agreement of donor partners, program resources already
pledged for the 2009 PSNP were drawn down on an accelerated basis.

53.     There remains a residual financing gap for the PSNP in 2009. This financing gap has
been made worse by the need to adjust the value of the transfer for the 2009 PSNP program
following the huge erosion in purchasing power resulting from the recent food price inflation. The
purchasing power of the ETB8 program transfer (approximately US$0.80) was reduced by 58
percent through June, 2008. The Government and donor partners have agreed to make financing
available in order to cover a potential increase in the wage rate to ETB12. This would represent a
transfer value 50 percent above current levels and would increase the need for program financing
by a further US$97 million. This factor, alongside the cost of providing additional support through
the Program in 2008, has led to the cost overrun within the PSNP. Several of the DPs supporting
the PSNP have responded to this cost overrun and provided additional resources, both cash and in-
kind. A cumulative financing gap of US$25 million remains.

                                                       23

54.    The focus on the medium- and long-term strategy to boost agricultural production is
being further strengthened. Government and donors alike are sensitive that the short-term efforts
to address the food crisis should not deflect attention from the longer term agenda.       In fact,
substantial resources have been allocated to agricultural development. In particular, the
Government, both at the federal and regional (including woreda) levels is allocating significant
resources to this area (see Table 6). In addition, a number of donors have committed significant
resources (see Table 7) and more are envisioned as discussed in the Government-donor Sector
Working Group for Rural Economic Development and Food Security.
