55.    Part of the longer-term strategy is to foster improved commercialization and market
development. The commercialization of agriculture is a central piece of the Government's strategy
of agricultural development. This is also reflected in the approaches to increasing food security.
The PSNP has since its inception adopted an approach of sourcing the program's grain requirements
from the local market rather than bringing in food-aid from abroad. When this has not been
possible due to local market limitations, regional procurement in Africa has been the preferred
solution. This is one of the outcomes of working closely with WFP and other donors. Over the
long-run and given the correct market conditions, this can be an important stimulus for agricultural
production. At the same time, the World Bank is working with WFP and others on fostering market
developments and linkages.




                                                24

56.     Incremental activities in response to the food crisis include Government and donor
activities to boost availability of seeds and strengthen agricultural extension. For instance, the
Government has recently developed a new strategic plan to boost production of breeder, pre-basic,
basic and certified seeds. Of crucial importance also is the agricultural extension system, which
now consists of about 70,000 agricultural extension workers throughout the country, and the
Government will further strengthen the system to improve training on advice on fertilizers and
complementary inputs. It will also continue its support for cooperatives, so that these organizations
can effectively provide their members with training complementary to agricultural inputs. Finally,
improving the quality of water and soil resources is also vital to increase crop responses to fertilizer
and reduce the risk of crop loss, and Government and DPs will strengthen capacity-building
activities in this area.

57.     However, incremental resources for agricultural activities in response to the food crisis
are limited, especially beyond the resources provided in response to the humanitarian appeal.
Most alarmingly, they fall short of meeting needs to ensure availability of fertilizers for the next
production season. For this reason, the Government has requested that the World Bank and the
African Development Bank (AfDB) redeploy resources from the current portfolio. The request to
AfDB is for about US$64.3 million. In a recent development, the European Commission (EC) also
indicated that it has been requested and is considering supporting Ethiopia with the import of
fertilizer. While the funds are not yet firmly committed, the EC is considering channeling the funds
through IDA to harmonize donor efforts. Notwithstanding these requests made to donors, the
Government has made contingency plans to finance foreign exchange for the importation of
fertilizer up to the amount of close to US$300 million to meet the estimated demand for fertilizer
import.


       E. RATIONALE FOR THE PROPOSED PROGRAM AND BANK STRATEGY

Rationale

58.     There is an immediate need to minimize the risk of a repeated food shortage. In the
short-term, this can be achieved by ensuring adequacy of resources to: (i) continue to effectively
support food-insecure households through the PSNP; and (ii) import critical agricultural inputs,
primarily fertilizer. Unless the livelihoods of food-insecure households are protected and unless
Ethiopian farmers have adequate supply of fertilizers, the food shortage Ethiopia is currently
experiencing is almost certain to recur on a much larger magnitude, even with good rains. Over the
longer term, complementary efforts to boost agricultural productivity and reduce vulnerability to
shocks must be further strengthened.

59.     Within the broader context of mitigating measures addressing the food crisis, two
significant gaps remain. PSNP resources have been exhausted due to the additional needs created
by the current 2008 food crisis. The consequent gap for the 2009 program needs to be filled
immediately. This would ensure that funds could be channeled on a timely basis through the
regional governments to local governments for distribution to beneficiaries as needed by the
Program. Similarly, fertilizer application is seasonal and Ethiopia is currently not able to afford
adequate amounts of fertilizer imports without additional support. Contracting of fertilizer for the
2009 crop season and the actual imports need to be well under way this calendar year to make



                                                 25

fertilizer available to farmers in the upcoming crop season. The benefit of addressing Ethiopia's
fertilizer requirements today versus addressing extreme food shortages 6 to 9 months from now (at
much higher cost), is high.

The Bank's Broader Strategy

60.      The World Bank's broader strategy is to support the Government in assisting
chronically food-insecure households in escaping their poverty trap and to raise overall
agricultural output. The proposed Program is intended to prevent derailing this longer-term
strategy by the current crisis and to allow the Government to continue to effectively support food-
insecure households and promote agricultural growth.37

61.      The Bank is committed to continue support to the overall Food Security Program. The
Bank together with the Government and other DPs are committed to continue supporting the Food
Security Program, of which the PSNP is a part. In the new phase (APL III) of donor support for
PSNP (starting in FY10) increased efforts will be made to achieve integration of PSNP activities
(which focus on protection of household assets in times of stress and building of communal assets
including through a sustainable watershed management concept) and other livelihood activities that
help to build productive assets of households. It is now well recognized that only with a strategy
that effectively combines the two, i.e. provision of safety nets and livelihood enhancement, can
food-insecure households find a sustainable path out of poverty. In addition, the Bank is supporting
the FSP to secure the livelihood of the most food insecure households, and the strengthening of
pastoralists' resilience to external shocks through the Pastoral Community Development Project.

62.      The World Bank is also assisting the Government in strengthening sustainable
agricultural growth through a number of investment operations. To enhance agricultural
productivity, the Bank is supporting: (i) irrigation and market development with its Irrigation and
Drainage Project; (ii) agricultural services and technology (extension and research) strengthening
with its Rural Capacity Building Project; and (iii) watershed management and rural land
certification and administration with its Sustainable Land Management Project and Tana-Beles
Integrated Water Resources Development Project.

63.      The World Bank together with other DPs plan to step up its assistance through an
agricultural-growth program. The agricultural growth strategy focuses on broad-based, small
farmer led productivity increases in areas with good agricultural potential, together with greater
efforts to address diversification and markets in partnerships with the private sector.38 Additionally,
in areas of high agricultural potential and good market access, the emphasis is on promoting higher
value products (especially through contract farming arrangements), value addition, and integrated
supply chains for meeting the potential of export and expanding urban markets.39




37 In addition to the direct response to the food crisis, Ethiopia is also addressing macro-economic challenges, in
particular very high inflation and the large balance-of-payment gap, as described in Section B.
38The current projects such as Rural Capacity Building Project, the Irrigation and Drainage Project, and the Sustainable
Land Management Project provide support in this area.
39Projects such as the recently approved Tana Beles Integrated Water Resource Sector Project provide specific support
in this area.



                                                           26

CAS Alignment

64.     The operation is broadly consistent with the CAS. The PSNP remains a core component
of the World Bank strategy as articulated in the current Country Assistance Strategy (CAS, World
Bank, 2008).      Although the Fertilizer Support Project proposed under the Program was not
explicitly anticipated in the lending program under the CAS, the CAS squarely recognizes the risks
Ethiopia faces and states that: "The Bank will build flexibility into its lending portfolio so that it is
better able to help Ethiopia cope with external shocks." The current crisis constitutes such a shock.
In addition, the focus areas of the CAS supported by the proposed Program include increasing
agriculture productivity and reducing exposure to chronic food insecurity and shocks.

GFRP Alignment

65.     The proposed operation is timely and well positioned under the GFRP framework. It is
fully in line with the GFRP objectives as it will (i) reduce the negative impact of high and volatile
food prices on the lives of the poor in a timely manner. It will also support the other objectives,
namely, (ii) support government in the design of sustainable policies that mitigate the adverse
impacts of high and more volatile food prices on poverty, and (iii) support the first step of a larger
strategy of broad-based growth in productivity and market participation in agriculture to ensure an
adequate supply response as part of a sustained improvement in food supply. As specified in the
GFRP framework document, short-term measures must be balanced with medium-term measures
such as those intended to improve the domestic supply response. Discussion of further measures
relevant to the medium term is underway, and these will be articulated in the context of other
operations, including a possible DPL in late FY09, the third phase of PSNP, and the proposed
agricultural growth program. Hence, this proposed operation specifically focuses on addressing the
immediate financing gap in PSNP and the short-term foreign needs to ensure fertilizer availability
in 2009-2010.


                 F. THE PROPOSED FOOD CRISIS RESPONSE PROGRAM

Program Objectives

66.     This Program seeks to ensure that the needs of chronically food-insecure households
are adequately addressed, and to increase the likelihood that crop production in 2009 will
remain on or near the growth trend of recent years.40 To that end, the development objective of
the PSNP Additional Financing Project is to contribute to the Government's efforts to maintain
coverage of the chronically food insecure through the PSNP in 2009. A key indicator of success
includes the number of beneficiaries that continue to be covered under the PSNP. The development
objective of the Fertilizer Support Project is to contribute to the Government's efforts to ensure
availability of adequate supplies of fertilizers for the 2009-2010 crop season. Key indicators of
success include (i) the quantity of fertilizer imported and distributed to farmers, (ii) the timeliness
of import and distribution of fertilizer and complementary inputs to end users; (iii) fertilizer
application as share of total cultivated areas; and (iv) estimates of the costs and contribution of the
fertilizer to production and economic welfare.


40According to official statistics, the recent growth rate in crop production has been 11 to 12 percent per year (see
Table 4).



                                                          27

67.     More details on the results indicators and the detailed description of the two Projects are
provided in Annex 1 and Annex 2. The following section provides a summary.

PSNP Additional Financing Project

68.     Consistent with the parent APL II Project, additional financing for the PSNP would be
used to provide cash and in-kind transfers to food insecure households. Since 2005, the PSNP
has established a track record of providing transfers to 7.3 million chronically food insecure people
through a labor-intensive public works program for households with able-bodied members and as
direct support grants to labor-poor, elderly or otherwise incapacitated households. The public
works program aims to create productive community assets, with a focus on soil and water
conservation. The PSNP operates in the most food insecure rural areas in around one third of the
country.

69.     The objective of the PSNP Additional Financing Project is to fill the PSNP financing
gap that has emerged as a result of the food price inflation and drought in 2008, which have
caused a cost overrun in the Project (as described in paragraphs 51and 52). The aim would be to
make financing available to the PSNP immediately, which is vital for ensuring that resources start
to flow to woredas in November so that beneficiaries can be paid on time at the start of 2009.
Additional financing would allow the PSNP to continue to operate in 2009 as designed, providing a
similar level of support to food insecure households as has been provided through 2008. It would
also ensure that this support is provided on a timely basis.41

70.     Funds would be channeled as Additional Financing through the existing World Bank
APL II Project. Progress towards achieving the Project Development Objective is satisfactory.
Implementation of the project as well as project management are satisfactory and continue to be
strengthened.42 Evidence to date indicates that the PSNP at its current scale and scope, in spite of
the crisis suffered in 2008, is having a measurable impact on beneficiary livelihoods as measured
by income and assets.43 Given that the current project is proceeding as desired there are no
proposed changes in the design, and/or scope of the project. There are no changes applicable to the
institutional arrangements, implementation mechanisms, financial management, disbursement
arrangements or closing date. As the additional funds will help address a cost overrun in the project
and thereby allow the project to meet its original objectives, the original PDO remains valid and the
relevant results indicators and target values remain the same.

Fertilizer Support Project

71.     The objective of the Project is to contribute to the Recipient's efforts to ensure an
aggregate availability of supply of chemical fertilizers for the 2009-2010 production season
adequate to meet smallholder farmers' priority demands. The proposed instrument for the
Fertilizer Support Project is that of an Emergency Recovery Operation processed under the


41As this is the last year of the current phase of the PSNP, the next APL (APL III) would provide the required financing
for the PSNP from 2010 onwards.
42ISR ratings with regards to the PDO and Implementation have consistently been rated "satisfactory".
43See Annex 1 A for a full treatment of current project performance and impact.



                                                            28

guidelines for a Rapid Response to Crisis and Emergencies OP/BP 8.00. In line with OP8.00 the
proposed Program supports "measures to mitigate or avert the potential effects of imminent
emergencies or future emergencies or crisis in countries at high risk."

72.    The project, to be implemented by the MOARD, will have two components. First, a
large Fertilizer Component (about US$249.6 million) would ensure availability of foreign exchange
for the importation of a significant share of the fertilizer demand for the 2009-2010 season.
Second, a small but important Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) Component (about US$0.4
million) would track the fertilizer imports, the various steps along the input distribution system, and
enable an assessment of the impact of the project for the beneficiary farm households.                          The
Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) of MOARD will implement both components; it also
functions as the secretariat of the national Fertilizer Foreign Procurement Committee (FFPC) that
leads the process to allocate foreign exchange for the fertilizer importation.

Fertilizer Component

73.    The Fertilizer Component is a quick-disbursing component to support the importation
of fertilizers. Recognizing both the inherent risks involved in working in emergency situations,
including the risks and lost opportunities associated with a delayed response, and the critical
importance of speed, flexibility, and simplicity to an effective rapid response, this quick-disbursing
component is designed to finance one single commodity (i.e., fertilizers) under a positive list of
goods, required to immediately address the country's food crisis.

74.    MOARD has estimated, through extension staff, the quantity of the two types of
fertilizers (DAP and urea) demanded by farmers. The total estimated amount44 is about 550,000
tons of DAP and urea for the 2009 cropping season. Based on the prospect of receiving support
from IDA, the Government has initiated the process for the country to import initially 150,000 tons
of DAP and 75,000 tons of urea. The first shipment of these imports is expected to arrive in
Djibouti starting in the second half of January, in time for distribution and sale to farmers for the
2009 belg season.        The financing of this Component is expected to also contribute to the
importation of fertilizer under the next tender process(es) using the same procedures.

75.    The Bank's Procurement Guidelines will apply.                       The quick-disbursing component
supports the provision of foreign exchange for the importation of fertilizer using acceptable
procedures that satisfy the requirements of transparency, economy and efficiency (Annex 2.C,
paragraph 8). Agreement has been reached with the Government on the form of contract which is
prescribed to be used for the supply of fertilizer, and although it is recognized that these contracts
are entered into between an independent importer/distributor and the foreign supplier, which the
Government is not a direct party to, and the Bank will not conduct prior or post reviews of these
contracts, the Bank is being provided with copies of the contracts between the importer/distributor
and the foreign supplier for verification purposes (see paragraph 78 below). The task team has
reviewed the national procedures for the importation and distribution of fertilizer by local
importers, and discussed with the MOARD how the Bank's Procurement Guidelines apply in the
current situation where bulk fertilizer purchase is leading to cooperation rather than competition


44MOARD has three different estimates. 550,000 tons is the most conservative estimate, and the one used to discuss the
securing of foreign exchange for the importation.



                                                        29

between importers. Procurement arrangements to assure transparency, economy and efficiency of
the current procurement process would ensure: (i) open competition among suppliers and control
mechanisms on the procurement by the qualified importer(s) and its contractual arrangements with
other domestic distributors; and (ii) the allocation of foreign exchange and establishment of Letters
of Credit (L/Cs) to the lowest evaluated responsive bidder(s); and (iii) monitoring and verification
of the actual importation and distribution of fertilizers.

76.     MOARD regulates the procurement process of commercial importer(s) and allocates
foreign exchange for the importation. MOARD acts as a Secretariat for the FFPC, which ensures
the regulation of the tendering process, and allocation of foreign exchange for fertilizer imports to
the qualified importer(s) with the lowest evaluated responsive bids from foreign fertilizer suppliers.
For a first batch of fertilizer, MOARD has advertised on October 3, 2008 in the local press inviting
qualified and licensed fertilizer importers who have adequate funds (in ETB) to submit bids from
foreign suppliers. The tender was extended and bid opening took place on November 11, 2008.
The importers were to use bid documents prepared by MOARD based upon the Bank's standard
bidding documents for the importation of fertilizers. The bid documents have been reviewed,
revised, and agreed with the task team to include the Bank's provisions on fraud and corruption and
right to inspection and audit of the supplier(s). Given this season's option to procure in bulk,45 only
AISE has emerged as importer. Other potential importers have made contractual arrangements with
AISE to import on their behalf, rather than deciding to compete.46

77.     Given the emergence of a sole importer for the first batch of fertilizer and the large size
of the procurement, the Government agreed to include control mechanisms for AISE.47 In
particular, this includes the following requirements that: (i) AISE advertises internationally48; (ii)
AISE's bid evaluation report is approved by FFPC/MOARD and the recommendation of
FFPC/MOARD is sent to the Bank; (iii) MOARD will allocate the necessary foreign exchange to
the AISE's commercial bank for paying the foreign fertilizer supplier on the condition that AISE
and its suppliers will be subject to the Bank's provisions on fraud and corruption as well as the
Bank's right to inspection and audit;49 and (iv) MOARD forwards to the Bank copies of the
document allocating foreign exchange to AISE, the contract between AISE and the other
importers/distributors on whose behalf it is acting, and the contract between AISE and its foreign
supplier(s).

78.     IDA disbursement for the Component would be in full upon effectiveness of the project.
Upon award MOARD will instruct NBE to sell the necessary foreign exchange to the commercial
bank handling the financial transactions between the importer and foreign supplier for paying the
fertilizer supplier(s).     The Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE) has been functioning as the
commercial bank of the importers, and is (currently relatively high) bank handling these

79.     The actual import of fertilizer, as well as their distribution and sales to farmers, will be
handled by the importer. The commodities will arrive on a pre-determined schedule through the
port of Djibouti.         From Djibouti the fertilizers will be transported by truck into the major
warehouses of the importers, including those on which behalf the importer is acting, and wholesale
traders of fertilizer and further down the supply chain to primary cooperatives and retailers and
eventually farmers.

80.     Application of fertilizer would be by the final beneficiaries, primarily small-holder
farmers. While no subsidies are provided and no detailed targeting takes place, almost all of the
fertilizer imported with support from the proposed Project (under the FFPC/MOARD tender
procedures) would be consumed by small-holder farmers. Only about 2 percent of Ethiopia's
agricultural output is produced by large-scale commercial farms, and many of these have their own
foreign exchange reserves to import fertilizers.51 About half of all smallholders might use fertilizer;
these smallholders, who live mostly outside the most marginal areas, will be the main final
beneficiaries of the fertilizers. Traditionally, a bulk of the input is used in Oromia and Amhara
Regional States, with about 50 percent and 30 percent, respectively, of total consumption, followed
by the Southern Nations Nationalities and People's Region (SNNPR) (9 percent) and Tigray (4
percent).52

Usage of the Counterpart Funding

81.     The proposed operation is designed in such a way that it will not result in additional
public spending by the Government. It has been agreed with the Government that the bulk of the
local currency equivalent that will be generated through this operation (i.e., US$249.6 million to be
used for import of fertilizers) will be used to lower the domestic borrowing of the government--so
that no new money is created in the system.53 This arrangement is expected to have neutral or
positive fiscal impact.

Monitoring and Evaluation Component

82.     MOARD's Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) will also be responsible for the
implementation of the M&E Component. The M&E activities will be implemented with the

objective to: (i) provide timely information about fertilizer import and distribution for MOARD and

83.     The Government and its DPs will also monitor the fiscal impact of the Project, and
ensure that domestic borrowing is reduced. No new instrument is required for this as there are
regular assessments undertaken jointly by the Government and donors including the annual Public
Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA); the annual Public Finance Assessment (PFA),
the semi-annual Joint Budget Assessment Report (JBAR); and the biannual IMF Article IV
consultation. In addition, there are major operations such as the Public Sector Capacity Building
Program (PSCAP) and the Protection of Basic Services Project (PBS) that strengthen the public
financial system including its monitoring.

84.     The Government requested to include a small activity to support the environmental
and social assessment and the preparation of the environmental management plan under the
M&E Component. The activity would finance a consultant to assist the Government in carrying
out this activity within two months after Project effectiveness (see also para. 0).

Fertilizer Support Project is proposed to be financed through a combination of a new IDA grant in
the amount of about US$112.5 million and the redeployment of IDA resources from Ethiopia's
existing IDA portfolio in a total amount of about US$137.5 million, about US$15.0 million of
which is grant and US$122.5 credit.

Redeployment from Existing IDA Portfolio

88.    The overall size of the Ethiopia IDA portfolio consists of 28 projects with a
commitment of US$2.7 billion and about US$1.8 billion in undisbursed balances. The average



                                                    33

age of the portfolio is about 3 years. In light of the urgent current need, the Government has
proposed IDA resources be redeployed from 12 ongoing projects/programs for an estimated amount
of US$137.5 million, accounting for about 7 percent of the undisbursed balance of the portfolio (see
Annex 3 with details by project).

89.    The redeployments proposed by the Government are based on the following criteria:
(a) project savings due to exchange rate movement or changes in project costs; (b) revised
financing plans where additional donor financing or Government funding is available to reduce the
original IDA financing requirement; and (c) major restructuring, involving changes in the
development objective and/or outcome indicators, designed to improve the performance of problem
projects. The Government has avoided reallocating funds from several projects in energy and roads
sectors (comprising nearly US$1 billion in commitments), as many ICB contracts, dependent on
IDA financing, are already signed or in tendering process even though a significant amount is not
likely to be needed in the next 1-2 years. An overview of the changes proposed to the ongoing
projects is provided in Table 9 below.

90.    The restructuring of 8 of the 12 projects involve no change to development objective,
outcome indicators, or project design. Some cost savings are due to the appreciation of the SDR
against the ETB. Other cost savings arise from the projects themselves with about US$73 million
or nearly 60 percent of the proposed reallocation from projects with closing dates within the next 12
months. It is unlikely that this amount can disburse within the current implementation period and
the projects are on track to achieve their broad objectives.

93.     The proposed restructuring of the portfolio also fits well with the country strategy,
which stresses streamlining the portfolio to: (a) focus on a small number of operations that would
supply the bulk of the resources for the priority sectors, complemented by a few projects to
introduce innovation or to support one-off activities; (b) move toward sector-wide, programmatic,
and multi-donor interventions as much as possible; and (c) ensure that each intervention is
resourced adequately. Currently the portfolio is large with 28 projects. Because many older
operations have not closed in a timely manner, the number of projects in the portfolio has increased
significantly in the last few years.            The GFRP provides the Government and the Bank an
opportunity to bring a number of operations to timely closure, and move the overall structure of the
portfolio to the direction set out in the CAS. The Government is also keen to promote greater donor
harmonization by encouraging donors to support the Government's own sector-level plan in a
programmatic fashion, rather than continuing with a large number of projects.                                                               For instance,
Ethiopia is the first country to sign a country-level memorandum of understanding with donors for
