                                        H. APPRAISAL SUMMARY

Economic Analysis

94.     The economic benefits of the PSNP Additional Financing result from the impact of
transfers on households and from the value of community assets created through the public
works component. First, the PSNP contributes to the reduction of extreme hunger and
malnutrition. The provision of grants to chronically food-insecure households ensures that short-
term consumption shortfalls are met, avoiding the sale of productive assets, which are central to
both improving current food-insecurity (such as avoiding selling oxen that are used for farm
production) and to reducing the inter-generational transmission of food insecurity (by avoiding the
need to remove children from school to supplement household income or to reduce consumption
that can lead to increased malnutrition). A recent study on the PSNP found that between 2006 and
2008 real income changed by 59.1 percent and 52.5 percent for public works and direct support
beneficiaries respectively. At the same time non-PSNP beneficiary household income, in the same
communities, fell by 20 percent in real terms. The study finds that this difference in income growth
is attributable to the Program.56 It finds a similar, although less marked impact on assets.

95.     Second, by providing households with predictable transfers over several years,
program support is expected to lead to an increased willingness to adopt higher risk/return
strategies with regard to household production decisions. This allows increased investment in
inputs and seeds and also an increased readiness to access other opportunities for livelihood
diversification available through credit.

96.     Third, the Program supports the rehabilitation of the environment by adopting an
integrated watershed management planning approach in the public works component that focuses
on soil and water conservation measures. These include terracing, bunding, gully control, area
closures, reforestation, small scale irrigation, and water harvesting.                      It is expected that these
measures will, in turn, lead to improved agricultural productivity.

97.     Finally, the PSNP has reduced isolation and improved access to basic public services
through the building of rural feeder roads, repair and construction of schools and health clinics, and
by making safe drinking water available. These activities are integrated into the larger woreda
development planning process. Infrastructure such as schools and health posts have had significant
impacts, with one in four households stating that children not previously attending school now do
so as a result of schools built or extended under the PSNP. The access roads under PSNP now
constitute the largest road-building program in Ethiopia, with 92 percent of households in PSNP
woredas reporting that PSNP roads have benefited them.57




56The study confirms that the difference in income is statistically significant at the 5 percent level. Source: Devereux et
al. (2008); "2008 Productive Safety Net Program Assessment".
57"PSNP Public Works Impact Assessment, preliminary finding", October 2008, M.A Consulting.



                                                           36

98.      The economic benefits of the Fertilizer Support Project are also positive. Fertilizer use
has significant production and income impacts. This also holds for Ethiopia where fertilizer
application, while still at low levels, has increased rapidly. Fertilizer is estimated to be applied on
about 45 percent of cultivated area.58 Many farmers have been applying fertilizer for years and
fertilizer consumption has increased, without access to any significant subsidy, indicating the
benefits of doing so. If the project does not provide the necessary foreign exchange to import
fertilizer, millions of farmers who have used this technology for many years will not have the
choice whether to apply it or not. The economic analysis in Annex 2 G assesses how, given
established fertilizer technologies, price changes might affect the profitability of fertilizer use. It
also makes a more comprehensive assessment of the net returns of fertilizer use. In addition to
price incentives based on the number of units of output required to purchase one unit of fertilizer
nutrient, these net benefits largely depend on the yield response per unit of fertilizer nutrient.
Aggregate and farm-level methodologies are discussed. For a summary see Box 4.

99.      An assessment of the price ratio between fertilizer/nutrient and agricultural output
shows that current price ratios are more favorable than in the past. Output prices have
increased even faster than fertilizer prices ­ and projections of these price ratios are also well within
historical level for most assumptions. Given fertilizer nutrient-grain price ratios of 4-7 for maize in
Ethiopia that have prevailed over the past decade, the value cost ratio to farmers comfortably
exceeds the minimum of 2 generally considered necessary for wide adoption of fertilizer.

100. Many parameters including the domestic fertilizer demand estimates are subject to
significant uncertainties.           Precise estimates of future fertilizer demand in Ethiopia are very
challenging. Future prices do not only depend on a standard demand and supply framework, but
also to a significant extent on farmer's forward looking expectations, which are critically dependent
on (unpredictable) rainfall patterns, domestic and international price levels and their volatility, and
market information. The last couple of years and in particular also the last few months have show
substantial price fluctuations in world markets. This means significant uncertainties about the
development of fertilizer prices and quantities, and how they will prevail by the time farmers
making a decision about input use. A deterioration (increase) in the cereal-to-fertilizer ratios would
reduce (increase) domestic demand for fertilizer, and this might imply that domestic demand is less
than MOARD's most conservative estimate of about 550,000 tons.59 However, even if the 2009
aggregate fertilizer demand was lower than this estimate, additional financing support would still be
needed (see Annex 2 F for more details).

 Box 3: Summary of Economic Returns and Risks to Fertilizer Use in Ethiopia

 The economic analysis, as outlined in Annex 2 G, analyzes changes in fertilizer-output price ratios and
 documents production impacts at the aggregate and at the household level as well as using farm models. It
 draws from secondary sources and data, complemented by a farm level analysis, using current data on input
 and output prices.



58While no recent representative household survey on fertilizer use is available, 45 percent of smallholders used
fertilizer in 2005. Combined with the fact that fertilizer use has increase rapidly since then and a 45 percent share of
cultivated land under fertilizer, more than half of all farmers in Ethiopia are likely to have used fertilizer this year.
59550,000 tons is a 25 percent increase in terms of import quantity over 2007/08. However, according to MOARD's
record, stocks in the last (2007/08) season declined by about 50,000 tons, so that the actual projected utilization
increase is only about 12 percent.



                                                             37

 The price of cereals has increased faster than that for fertilizer, making its application more profitable than
 in the recent past (which already showed increased fertilizer use in Ethiopia).

 At the aggregate level, fertilizer production elasticities are estimated to be in the order of up to 0.12. A
 hypothetical 10 percent decrease in fertilizer application would therefore result in a 1.2 percent production
 loss in agricultural output. But the production impacts under Ethiopia's food crisis scenario are far from
 marginal.    The project will support about 50 percent of total national fertilizer consumption, which
 otherwise would not be available. In the without project scenario, due to the non-availability of fertilizer,
 aggregate agricultural output could decline by as much as 6 percent,

 At the household level, a comparison of households with and without fertilizer use show that cereal yields
 under normal rainfall conditions tend to be systematically higher when fertilizers are used. Historic survey
 data shows that the average production impact at the household level can reach up to 40 percent.

 At the farm level, using crop models for the "typical" farm households in relatively high potential areas in
 the Amhara region, the above findings are confirmed.             Under favorable rainfall patterns, fertilizer
 application could generate significant financial benefits. Simulations under current input and output prices
 show that these are in the order of about US$200 for the farm household, or about ETB40 per family labor
 day. By contrast, assuming bad rainfall patterns with a production loss of about 20 percent, the use of
 fertilizer will result in financial losses of up to ETB120 per family labor day.

 In summary, fertilizer use increases production and is profitable under current price scenarios (and trends).
 However, fertilizer use also increases risks. For example, under poor rainfall conditions, with 20 percent
 rainfall below the median rainfall level, the use of fertilizer becomes economically unprofitable, in
 particular for teff. Farmers take this risk into account. The majority of the fertilizer is applied in more
 reliable rainfall zones.


101. Supply response to fertilizer application (or, in the scenario at hand, to non-
application) and its profitability have been shown to be positive for average years in many
studies. On-farm yield response to fertilizer on maize, one of the most commonly fertilized crops
average about 15 kg in East and Southern Africa. A household level analysis based on limited
sample data from Christiaensen and Demery (2007) suggests that average output value minus
fertilizer and credit costs is about 40 percent higher with than without fertilizer. Farm-model
analysis based on data from the Amhara Region show average returns to fertilizer use of ETB40 per
family labor day. At the aggregate level a 10 percent decrease in fertilizer use has been estimated
to lead to a decrease in total agricultural output of about 1.2 percent. This suggests that the impact
of not importing a significant share of fertilizer demanded (e.g. assuming about half of total
consumption) would reduce agricultural growth by perhaps 6 percentage points, a halving of the
current double-digit agricultural growth rate.

102. There are, however, also significant risks associated with the application of fertilizer,
mainly arising from weather-induced shocks. As is shown in Annex 2 G, these shocks reduce
production impacts and can result in negative returns to fertilizer use. Already in years with a
20 percent shortfall in rainfalls, returns to fertilizer use have been shown to be negative. This risk
is significant; however, about two thirds of the farm population resides in reliable rainfall zones
where most of the fertilizer is used.

103. Other risk, as discussed above, stem mainly from price risks. For example, MOARD's
demand estimate might be excessive or, given the recently decreasing international fertilizer prices,
MOARD might be inclined to import an even greater amount. This could results in an increase of



                                                        38

fertilizer stocks and, consequently, inefficiencies. However, the risk is mitigated given the foreign
exchange constraints and resistance from importers and distributors to engage in fertilizer tenders in
the light of overstocking.

104. Delays in the domestic fertilizer distribution system can result in inefficiencies in
fertilizer application.     Some evidence from household surveys in recent years suggests that
inefficient use of fertilizer may lead to negative profits (World Bank, 2006). Growing use of
fertilizer in more marginal areas, lagging adoption of improved seed, late delivery of fertilizer, and
poor extension have been identified as factors affecting efficiency. Over the past three years, the
Government has made concerted efforts to reduce these inefficiencies, especially in massively
scaling up extension, improving timeliness of fertilizer delivery, and developing a five-year action
plan to increase use of improved seed. Further progress can be made, including through careful
monitoring and evaluation under the proposed Project.

105. The macro-economic impact is positive as the operation will help to ensure that
agricultural production will remain near its trend and will reduce domestic borrowing.
Preventing agricultural production in the next crop season from significant decline due to non-
availability of fertilizer will have a positive impact on food availability and will tend to reduce food
inflation. The poor net-consumers of food, in particular, will therefore also benefit from the
proposed Project. In addition, the Project's impact on decreasing domestic government borrowing
means that no new money is created in the system and that the operation is fiscally neutral or
positive.

Technical

106. The Project poses no technical challenges per se. The PSNP has been under satisfactory
implementation since 2005.         There is a Program Implementation Manual (PIM) and related
Operational Summary and detailed subject-specific guidelines on beneficiary targeting, community
based participatory integrated watershed management, financial management, procurement, and
monitoring and evaluation.       The PIM is periodically revised to reflect lessons learned during
implementation. There is a functioning M&E system with a strong emphasis on impact evaluation.
Government continues to conduct annual training programs on the different guidelines using a
cascade training approach. Perhaps most significant of these has been the annual community based
participatory integrated watershed management training, which is delivered annually to over 11,000
Development Agents. The Program continues to receive strong technical input and supervision.
Several joint Government-donor working groups focus on the development of different elements of
the Program, including capacity building, monitoring and evaluation, public works, and pastoralist
safety nets. There are bi-weekly joint coordination committee meetings and bi-annual joint review
and implementation support missions.

107. With regard to the Fertilizer Support Project, the importation, distribution, and on-
farm application of fertilizers is well established in Ethiopia. While many different aspects are
associated with this process, ranging from the transport logistics and communications to applying
the right nutrient amounts and ensuring the supply of complementary inputs, these are not new and
have been undertaken for many years. The modifications of the procurement procedures discussed
and agreed with the Government do not pose any technical difficulties.                Efficiency in the
distribution system could be improved as capacity constraints exist and it is expected that the M&E


                                                   39

Component will generate additional knowledge to further develop and improve the importation,
distribution, and application of fertilizers.

Fiduciary

108. With regard to the PSNP Additional Financing Project, just as with the PSNP parent project,
the overall financial management responsibility rests with MOFED. The Bureaus of Finance and
Economic Development (BOFEDs), at the regional level, and the Woreda Offices of Finance and
Economic Development (WOFEDs) are responsible for recording and reporting the financial
transactions of the program. MOFED has around 800 accountants and cashiers for the PSNP,
particularly at woreda level to improve program financial management. The team continues to
observe some weaknesses particularly concerning delays in financial reporting and submission of
audited program accounts. Further details are presented in Annex 1 D.

109. PSNP Procurement involving major packages under ICB is handled at federal level but most
of the procurements are for small value public works and purchases that are conducted at Regional
and woreda level. A procurement manual with clear guidelines has been prepared for the PSNP and
procurement training provided at every level. However procurement at all levels has been subject to
delays and procurement performance remains moderately satisfactory. Procurement efficiency
under APL II has improved after the recruitment of a qualified and experienced Procurement
Specialist under the Food Security Program Department (FSPD) and the recruitment of Regional
Procurement Coordinators at the regional level.

110. With regard to the Fertilizer Support Project, the team reviewed the financial
management and disbursement arrangements. The FFPC under MOARD regulates fertilizer
imports and allocates the necessary foreign exchange to the importer who has obtained the
evaluated lowest bid from a foreign supplier.       The Agricultural Products Marketing Sector
(Department) of MOARD, which is the secretariat of FFPC, supervises the procurement process by
reviewing the bid evaluation and allocates foreign exchange subject to obtaining a conformed copy
of the supply contract after signature for subsequent follow up to verify the quality and quantity of
fertilizer imports. MOARD will be responsible for implementing the Project and will ensure
compliance with accounting and internal control, financial reporting, and external audit
requirements. For more details see Annex 2 D.

111. The arrangements for fertilizer procurement have been found to generally meet the
requirements for transparency, economy and efficiency.            The Government through FFPC
regulates fertilizer imports and allocates the necessary foreign exchange to the lowest bid(s)
received by a domestic importer from a foreign supplier. The Bank's procurement guidelines
apply.    Several provisions have been introduced to ensure transparency and adequate control
mechanisms are in place, including that the Bank has reviewed the bidding documents, and the
Bank's policies on Fraud and Corruption, as well as the right to inspection and audit, apply. The
selection of consultants to undertake the study under the M&E component will be according to the
Bank's Guidelines and MOARD has the capacity to implement this process. For more details see
Annex 2 C.




                                                 40

Social and Poverty Impact

112. The proposed Program is expected to have significant positive social and poverty
impacts. It targets large parts of the population that are believed to be most vulnerable given the
food and macro-economic crisis and the various measures in place or planned outside of this
project: the 7.3 million chronically food-insecure people under the PSNP and the millions of
smallholder farmers relying on fertilizer to boost their agricultural production and ensure food
security and income.

113. The PSNP Additional Financing Project will help to ensure that the livelihoods of the
PSNP beneficiaries are not threatened by the funding gap that has been created by the
current food crisis. This funding gap threatens to weaken the safety net in (early) 2009 just as the
beneficiaries have struggled to overcome the crisis this year. Ensuring that all of the necessary
households continue to be covered adequately by the program will therefore make a very important
contribution to reducing poverty now, as well as avoiding destitution in the future.

114. The social impacts of the Fertilizer Support Project are also expected to be highly
positive. Without access to fertilizer, the millions of small-holder farmers who regularly apply
modern production technologies to boost agricultural production and, hence, feed their families and
generate income, would be deprived of their choice.                    The consequence would be decreased
profitability and more severe poverty and, in many cases, food insecurity, malnutrition, and
increased dependence on food aid.               Likely more than half of Ethiopia's smallholders, about
6.7 million households with around 35 million, are threatened by the country's lack of foreign
exchange to import fertilizer. While most of these smallholders are slightly better-off than the
PSNP beneficiaries, as they do not live in the most marginal area but in areas with reasonable
production potential, they are nevertheless poor. The simulated impact of the unavailability of
fertilizer is an increase in the rural headcount of as much as 5 percentage points.60

115. The social impact of Ethiopia not having sufficient fertilizer for the 2009 production
season extends beyond the farmers that actually use fertilizer. A reduced agricultural
production in the country would affect everyone through food shortages, the negative impact on
food inflation and Ethiopia's trade balance. This holds in particular the poor, about half of which
might be net buyers of food.61

116. The Project is unlikely to cause any adverse social impact. The project will not seek to
target distribution of the fertilizer to any particular group, since no subsidy is involved. Farmers
will procure through their cooperatives and other existing channels of distribution and will be able
to make purchasing decisions, including on the fertilizer quantities, taking into consideration prices
and other factors.




60This is a rough estimate based on an average US$200 loss from not applying fertilizer, as detailed in Annex 2G. Note
that household impacts are likely to vary with a number of variables including land holding size and weather patterns.
61Based on data from 2000, Ethiopia's poor are 22.3 percent urban (net buyers) and 30.1 percent smallholders net
buyers. See World Development Report (2008).



                                                          41

Environmental and Safeguard Policies

117. One of the key objectives of the PSNP is to address the underlying causes of food
insecurity, to which land degradation is universally agreed to be a major contributor,
particularly in highland areas. Thus the design of the PSNP public works program is intended to
have environmentally positive impacts. Indeed, these activities, which include, for example, soil
and water conservation, land reclamation and improvement of community infrastructure, are
expected to constitute a vehicle for significant environmental transformation and enhanced
productivity.

118. It is nonetheless common knowledge that past mass-mobilization efforts in
environmental rehabilitation in Ethiopia have frequently failed or have been abandoned, as a
result of which the environment has returned to its degraded state. Such adverse outcomes occur
particularly if their locations or designs do not follow good environmental practice, or if they are
incompatible with optimum overall management of the watershed.

119. To address such issues, the approach to the environmental performance and
sustainability of the public works program is three-pronged:

(i)    Public works are derived from a community-based approach to integrated watershed
       management, a process which forms the basis of the awareness-creation and training
       program, supported by a budget to provide technical and material inputs. Moreover, the
       PSNP public works are also viewed as contributing to the Nile Basin Initiative;

(ii)   Standards to be followed in the design and implementation of the individual public
       works are established in Community-Based Watershed Management guidelines published
       by the MOARD, which are made available to concerned woreda staff and Development
       Agents; and

(iii)  The process of selection and screening of public works for possible negative
       environmental impacts is in accordance with Ethiopia's Environmental Impact
       Assessment proclamation. The process is documented in the Environmental and Social
       Management Framework (ESMF) produced by the Government. The ESMF, produced by
       Government and disclosed under APL II, is incorporated in the awareness-creation and
       training programs. Responsibilities for its implementation and monitoring are designated at
       federal, regional, woreda and kebele levels in the ESMF: Implementation Guidelines. In
       addition, joint government-donor 6-monthly public works reviews are conducted, which
       include monitoring of ESMF implementation, followed by corrective measures if required.

120. With regard to the on-going PSNP, three safeguard policies were triggered at the time
of project approval including EA Policy OP 4.01, Pest Management Policy OP 4.09, and the
International Waterways Policy OP 7.50. Of these the most significant to ongoing
implementation is EA Policy OP 4.01, which has been addressed by the development, disclosure
and implementation of an ESMF. This is designed to ensure that public works involving any form
of physical relocation of residents or involuntary loss of assets or access to assets are not approved
under the PSNP. Public works within, or in the vicinity of, a cultural heritage site, including
community sites of cultural importance, are avoided whenever possible. If the site cannot be


                                                  42

avoided, the matter is referred to the regional EPA for further examination and subsequent
modification or disapproval of the public works. In addition, the ESMF screening process, which is
mandatory for all public works, assesses and minimizes potential impacts such as increased
pressures on human settlement, disturbance to religious sites, increased social tensions over asset
allocation, and the capacity to enforce measures such as the prohibition of open grazing. In order to
address projects that might include the renovation or extension of medical clinics in the public
works program, the government's Waste Management Guide for Rural Health Clinics is published
and disclosed, in accordance with OP 4.01. In addition, as mentioned above, the government Guide
for Integrated Pest Management in Small-Scale Irrigation Schemes is published and disclosed, in
accordance with OP 4.09. Regarding OP 7.50 (International Waterways), the government and
World Bank notified the concerned countries in accordance with this policy, covering the five-year
period of APL I and APL II. Being limited to small, community-level schemes, water abstraction
rates are still well within the notified levels.

121. The environmental impact of the Fertilizer Support Project is expected to be positive.
Ethiopia's soils are nutrient-depleted in many areas and lack the capacity to generate sufficient
biomass to serve the needs of the population and its livestock. While better farming and land
management practices have to be at the center of a strategy to overcome this situation, a sharp drop
in fertilizer in the coming production season would lead to further nutrient-depletion with negative
consequences on productivity and, hence, overexploitation of marginal lands and other natural
resources. Fertilizer applications are still at low levels in Ethiopia and other agro-chemicals are
even less frequently used by small-holder farmers.

122. Adverse environmental impacts are likely to be small, but possible.                 In particular,
improper storage, use and application of pre-treated seeds and other planting materials and
inorganic fertilizers may lead to adverse environmental and health impacts. There exist a critical
mass of capacity within MOARD and at the federal, regional, woreda and kebele levels to manage
the environmental safeguard and provide effective extension support to farmers and pastoralists in
the application of inorganic fertilizers and pre-treated seeds.    At and below the woreda level
throughout the country there are well-trained subject matter specialists and development agents
(extension agents) whose principal responsibilities include serving as the link between research and
farmers, bringing innovative technologies to farmers, and advising farmers on the rational use of
agrochemicals including inorganic fertilizers as well as adoption of integrated pest management
approaches.      The guidelines on the application of fertilizers prepared by MOARD and its
collaborating agencies such as the Federal Environmental Protection Authority (FEPA) serve as a
useful tool in delivering extension service to farmers on the proper use of fertilizers.

123. From an environmental and social safeguard standpoint, the proposed Fertilizer
Support Project is Category B. This suggests that environmental and social impacts of the
project, for the most part, will be minimal, site-specific and manageable to an acceptable level. The
proposed Program triggers two safeguard policies: The Environmental Assessment Policy (OP
4.01); and the Pest Management Policy (OP 4.09), predicated on program objectives to increase
agricultural production and productivity.

Since this project is being processed under rapid response procedures of OP/BP 8.00,
MOARD in collaboration with FEPA will undertake a quick environmental and social
assessment and prepare a management plan acceptable to the Bank within two months after


                                                  43

effectiveness of the Fertilizer Support Project. A consultant will support the Government in its
efforts (see para. 84). The preparation will include consultation of key stakeholders including
farmers, farmer cooperatives and their unions, and other importers. This assessment will assist in
determining whether OP 4.10 is triggered. It will have, as attachment, simple guidance notes for
safe management of the fertilizer consignment expected to arrive in the country, compliance
monitoring arrangements and mechanisms, relevant institutional capacity building measures as well
as relevant environmental awareness creation and training programs.                 The Project will be
implemented in accordance with the provisions of the Environmental and Social Management Plan.


                                     I. BENEFITS AND RISKS

124. The benefits and risks of the proposed operation have to be judged within the wider country
context and the broader Bank's commitment to assist the Government in its efforts to achieve
immediate and long-term food security and agricultural growth.

Benefits

125. The provision of timely, flexible support to Ethiopia will assist the Government with an
immediate response to the food crisis.           As discussed in Section H, the provision of quick
disbursing financing will enable the Government to: (i) continue support through the PSNP, at
current levels, to the most vulnerable food insecure households, thereby ensuring that there is not
increased destitution as a result of the current crisis; and (ii) ensure that necessary amount of
fertilizers are available for the next agricultural production season. This will increase the likelihood
that a recurrence of the current food crisis in 2009 will be avoided. Moreover, given that domestic
food prices are currently well above their import parity price ­ with lack of foreign exchange
appearing to be the main obstacle to arbitrage imports ­ the proposed operation might have a
dampening immediate effect on food inflation.

126. The impact of the Program in terms of economic returns, on social aspects and poverty,
and on the environment is expected to be overwhelmingly positive. The PSNP is a well
established safety net program in its fourth year of implementation. Independent impact evaluations
have shown that the program is having a demonstrable and significant effect on beneficiary-
household income and assets. Ensuring that all of the necessary households continue to be covered
adequately by the program will therefore make a very important contribution to reducing poverty
now, as well as avoiding destitution in the future.

127. Similarly, without timely access to fertilizer, millions of smallholder farmers will be
faced with reduced agricultural production, reduced income and the risk of food insecurity,
malnutrition, and increased dependence on food aid. The primary beneficiaries of the Fertilizer
Support Project are smallholder farmers.62 While they do not belong to the poorest strata of
society, i.e. those being supported under the PSNP, these farmers are still poor and vulnerable and
are likely to fall into poverty without access to fertilizer and related production-enhancing
agricultural practices. Reduced agricultural production will also lead to overall increased food



62Smallholder farmers make up about 98 percent of agricultural production in Ethiopia and almost all fertilizer
procured through the FFPC/MOARD tender procedure is used by smallholders.



                                                    44

shortages and food inflation with negative impact for all Ethiopians, in particular poor net-food
buyers.

128. The Fertilizer Support Project will have a monitoring and evaluation component that
will increase the understanding of the economics, inefficiencies, and capacity limitations of the
fertilizer system under the current rapidly changing setting, in particular of prices.        This is
particularly important as past analyses have pointed to economic inefficiencies of fertilizer use,
including those that are closely related to a lack of improved seeds and other complementary inputs
such as credit and irrigation as well as a poor agricultural extension system. However, tremendous
changes have occurred just over the last few years, and the policy and institutional issues are
complex.

129. In terms of its macro- and fiscal impact, the Fertilizer Support Project will be inflation
neutral and fiscally positive. The PSNP Additional Financing, at US$25 million, is a relatively
small component, which may contribute to some additional pressure on prices in PSNP
administrated areas, though the overall impact is likely to be modest. Since the bulk of the money
will be used for import of fertilizers, it will therefore not put added pressure on domestic aggregate
demand. But, to the extent this operation will contribute to an expectation of better harvests in
2009, it can be expected to have a moderating effect on inflationary expectations. In terms of its
fiscal impact, the proposed project will be positive by helping the Government to borrow less from
domestic sources.

130. The project will contribute to addressing recurrent food insecurity in the Horn of
Africa by helping to strengthen food production in Ethiopia over the coming seasons. Decent
crops in the areas of greater and more reliable rainfall within the region will make it easier to
supply the least food secure areas, mainly the pastoral areas of Ethiopia, Somalia and Djibouti, both
through local market transactions and through locally sourced food aid. This is particularly
important, given the difficult situation and high levels of food insecurity not just in Ethiopia, but
also neighboring countries.

Risks and Mitigation

131. Country Risks. The proposed Program will be implemented in an overall risky country
environment. In particular, Ethiopia is in a difficult macro-economic situation and while the high
risks from this are being mitigated through active engagement between the Government and the
Bank as well as the IMF, the risks remain substantial. The uncertain global financial situation
contributes to this risky environment in Ethiopia. Other substantial country-level risks include
those related to weather shocks and their impact on the overall economy and food security, as well
as governance and security issues. These risks have to be taken into account and are being mitigated
through continuous engagement. More program-specific risks relate to the following:

132. Timing and Delays. The impact of the Fertilizer Component is dependent on ensuring that
the bulk of the fertilizers are procured by December 2008, and there are some risks from delays.
The risks of delays from the Ethiopian administration are low due to a strong Government support
and established import and distribution procedures.          There is risk of delays in the fertilizer
distribution system as the capacity of the stakeholders involved is limited. However, given the
urgency to increase production, there will be a concerted effort by the Government working with


                                                    45

the distribution sector to ensure timely availability of fertilizer to farmers. The existing distribution
system will be used, and significant organizational changes are neither required nor practical. The
procedures with respect to the distribution system will be closely monitored as part of this
operation, so that mitigating measures can be taken should problems be observed.

133. Economics of Fertilizer Use. Prices of crops and agricultural inputs including fertilizer
have increased to historically very high levels, and are still changing rapidly. This price risk
translates into two main outcomes. First, farmers applying high-priced fertilizer may not achieve
the productivity level nor obtain the output prices necessary to be profitable. Second, due to high
input prices and uncertainty of output prices farmers might not demand the expected fertilizer
amounts.    Potential mitigation activities include price information dissemination through the
Ethiopia Commodity Exchange (ECX) and information collected under the M&E Component
disseminated; and, as the fertilizer imported is tendered in batches, later batches can be reduced
accordingly.

134. Inadequate M&E System. A M&E system is important not just for assessing the success of
the operation, i.e. `ex-post', but reliably tracking the import and distribution of fertilizer (and
complementary inputs) on a timely ("real-time") basis is also crucial to make possible policy
adjustments during the 2008/09 implementation season and, hence, for the success of the operation
itself. Experience from other projects show that there is a risk that the M&E system might be of
limited scope, rigor, and independence. However, this risk was discussed and the Government
made a firm commitment to the M&E Component during negotiations, mitigating this risk. In
particular, risks would be mitigated by agreeing on a representative rural household survey
capturing major features of the distributional and cost-benefit structure of the fertilizer and input
market supply system, including those of the cooperatives.

135. Weather. A drought would seriously affect the supply response to fertilizer application. In
this case, the purchase and application of fertilizers may have little production effect in marginal
areas and negative welfare impact for farmers that purchased fertilizer. While DAP remains in the
soil for longer and will still have some positive impact in the following season, the impact of urea
will be largely lost. Clearly, this risk exists and is taken into account by farmers every production
season. An overview of the most recent rainfall patterns and forecasts is presented in Box 4.




                                                   46

Box 4: Rainfall Patterns in Later 2008

Over the last few months, performance of rains in most parts of the country has improved, though some parts
of the country have seen continuing drought, including Somali, belg benefiting lowlands of Oromia, Afar
and pocket areas in Eastern Tigray. Satellite based crop estimates such as the Netherlands-based EARS
Earth and Environment Monitoring, and monitoring reports from the field, indicate that harvests from the
meher production season will likely be average for most of the western parts of the country, while a below-
average harvest is anticipated in the country's eastern parts. This, together with FEWS NET rain forecasts
until December 2008 provide the basis for cautious optimism for the country's overall situation; however,
unusual rains during the time of harvest, as experience in later October and early November raise some new
concerns. For most of the meher-dependent crop producing areas, located in the Central, Western, and
Northwestern highlands, forecasts indicate normal to above-normal rainfall conditions. While these rains are
secondary for agricultural production, they can be crucial for the replenishment of water points, which in
turn are critical in Ethiopia's main crop producing areas.




The forecasts also indicate the geographical spread and risks. The forecasts show that agro-pastoral areas in
Southern Ethiopia may face severe challenges due to poor rain, potentially increasing humanitarian needs.
As Ethiopia's agriculture is largely rainfed, the rainfall patterns are crucial for Ethiopia's food security ­ and
are also so for the success of the fertilizer operation proposed under the Food Crisis Response Program.
However, no weather forecasts for the 2009 kiremt rains are currently available.

Source: FEWS NET Ethiopia.


136. Experience indicates that usually only parts of the country are affected by a serious drought
and the risk of an overall negative impact for all farmers using fertilizer and for the country as a
whole is only modest. This risk is mitigated through a number of ongoing Government and donor
initiatives that are addressing weather risks. Measures being developed, tested, and extended
include drought-resistant seed varieties, index-based weather insurance, and the improvement of
meteorological data and its dissemination. However, the development and implementation of these
measures requires time and their impact in the next season will be limited. A drought would also
have a large impact on the food insecure households supported under the PSNP. Should this occur,
mitigation would be partially sought, as has been the case this year, through a scaled-up response
under the PSNP itself.

137. Food-price inflation. Further high domestic food price inflation would have a significant
impact on the PSNP as the value of transfers to food insecure households would be eroded.
However, domestic cereal prices are already significantly above import parity prices.                         The



                                                       47

Government has stated its intention to continue a process, already started, of importation of cereals
until prices fall towards import parity. Moreover, the harvest over the next months should also
contribute substantially to a downward pressure on price increases. Finally, the Fertilizer Support
Project is a major risk mitigation measure to address the prospects of food inflation induced by
shortages next year. Therefore the risk of further significant domestic cereal inflation is mitigated
and modest.

138. Risk to Ongoing IDA Portfolio. Risk stems from redeployment of IDA resources from
ongoing projects. This risk is being mitigated through the careful design of the reallocations
themselves as well as a firm Government commitment to provide sufficient domestic budget funds
for project activities that are necessary to achieve the project objectives. This commitment will be
formalized as part of this operation and closely monitored by the various task teams.




                                                  48

                          ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


 ANNEX 1 A: BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE FOR US$25 MILLION ADDITIONAL
                                     FINANCING FOR PSNP

A. Introduction

1.      This Annex provides the background and rationale for US$25 million Additional Financing
for the Productive Safety Net Project APL II (PSNP, Project ID: P098093, Credit number: H2660),
as part of the Emergency Food Crisis Response Program. The proposed additional grant would
meet the financing gap that has emerged following the program response to the twin shocks of food
price inflation and drought in 2008. There would be no change to the original design and ongoing
activities of the project.

B. Project data and performance

2.      The PSNP APL II was approved on January 9, 2007, with a grant amount of SDR118.5
million. It is the second project in a series of three APLs. Key project data and performance are
summarized below.

                         Key Project Data & Performance of PSNP APL II
Key Project Data                               Project Performance
Grant Amount: US$175 million equivalent        Development Objectives: Satisfactory
Effectiveness date: 04/05/07                   Implementation Progress: Satisfactory
Closing date: 06/30/10                         Financial Management: Marginally Satisfactory
Current disbursements: US$132.55 million       Procurement: Marginally Satisfactory
Remaining balance: US$53.19 million            Environmental Safeguards: Marginally Satisfactory

3.      The development objective of the overall PSNP series is to contribute to reducing
household vulnerability and improving resilience to shocks. This will be achieved through
reform of the humanitarian emergency system to a development-oriented program which (i)
provides timely, predictable and adequate transfers to beneficiary households, thus allowing
effective consumption-smoothing and avoiding asset-depletion; (ii) creates productive and
sustainable community assets and contributes to large-scale rehabilitation of severely degraded
areas; (iii) stimulates local markets through demand linkages; and (iv) establishes more effective
responses to drought shocks to avoid increasing destitution among affected households. The second
APL aims to consolidate the progress made under APL I and continues to strengthen technical
capacity in all aspects of program implementation.

4.      There are three project components:

a) Component 1: Safety net grants which provide transfers to chronically food insecure
    households through (i) labor-intensive public works for those households with available labor.
    Sub-projects to be undertaken are determined locally by the beneficiary communities through
    an annual, participatory planning process that focuses on integrated watershed management, and
    (ii) direct support, which provides grants to households who are labor-poor and cannot
    undertake public works. Beneficiaries include, but are not limited to, orphans, pregnant and
    lactating mothers, elderly households, other labor-poor, high risk households with sick



                                                  49

                          ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


    individuals (such as people living with HIV/AIDS), and the majority of female-headed
    households with young children and no other available adult labor.

b) Component 2: Drought risk financing, which aims to provide timely resources for transient
    food insecure households in response to shocks within existing program areas. The component
    is financed using a contingent grant, which will provide resources for scaling-up activities under
    Component 1 in response to localized or intermediate drought in PSNP woredas.

c) Component 3: Institutional support, which supports institutional strengthening activities,
    including related management costs. It also provides funding for M&E activities, as well as
    transparency and accountability initiatives.


5.      The World Bank APL II Project is part of a much larger Government program
financed and supported by a consortium of partners including CIDA, DFID, IrishAID, EC, RNE,
SIDA, USAID, and WFP, who together have committed cash and in-kind resources valued at
around US$1.2 billion during the current phase of the Program from 2007-2009. At its current
scale, supporting around 7.3 million beneficiaries, the PSNP represents one of the largest social
protection initiatives in Africa. The donor group has pooled its financing, both in cash and food.
Several partners have provided their support as co-financing to the World Bank APL II Project.

6.      Progress     in   implementation       is   positive.  The    "Development     Objective"   and
"Implementation Progress" have been consistently rated as "satisfactory" in all previous ISRs. The
IEG rating for APL I was "satisfactory" and the QAG rating for quality at entry for APL II was
"satisfactory". These ratings reflect (i) the underlying progress in delivering transfers to
beneficiaries on a timely and predicable basis, and (ii) the value of outputs under the public works
program, which are increasingly assessed as being of good quality. In 2008, 80 percent of public
works projects are estimated to have reached satisfactory technical standards and sustainability
ratings.63 In the case of both transfers and public works there is a consistent improvement in
implementation over time.

7.      Yet challenges clearly remain. Despite dramatic improvements in the timeliness of
transfers, delays still exist in distribution of resources to beneficiaries. In the case of public works
securing operations and maintenance for all projects such as roads and water projects remains a
challenge. These issues are the subject of ongoing dialogue with Government and are being actively
addressed in improved project management procedures and training. Challenges in implementation
are also evidenced by a number of "marginally satisfactory" ratings in the last ISR. With regard to
financial management, although there have been notable improvements year-on-year and there are
currently no overdue audits, delays in receipt of IFRs and audit reports, and lack of consistent
follow-up on recommendations of audit reports remain a concern. Procurement is also subject to
delays. But again this has shown improvement. The rating for environmental safeguards reflects
delays in implementing environmental screening for all public works projects. This has steadily
improved and the related rating is likely to be upgraded during the ongoing PSNP Mid-term
Review.




63"2nd 2008 Public Works Review, PSNP"; FSPD, Government of Ethiopia



                                                    50

                             ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


8.       Key project legal covenants have been complied with, although as noted above, in the
case of financial management this is often with some delay.

9.       There is strong evidence of program impact. Although the full impact assessment for the
project is not due until January, 2009, interim assessments based on household surveys and a
sampling of public works projects provide important insights. The outcome indicator for the
project is "the % change in beneficiary household assets and income". Between 2006 and 2008 a
recent study found a change in real income of 59.1 percent and 52.5 percent for public works and
direct support beneficiaries respectively.              At the same time non-PSNP beneficiary household
income, in the same communities, fell by 20 percent in real terms. The study finds that this
difference in income growth is attributable to the program.64 It finds a similar, although less
marked impact on assets.

10.      With regard to public works, the initial findings of the ongoing public works impact
assessment are encouraging. Most soil and water conservation projects are found to be effective,
ranging from 69 percent of check dams, to 100 percent of water-retaining trenches and area
closures. Infrastructure such as schools and health posts have had significant impacts, with one in
four households stating that children not previously attending school now do so as a result of
schools built or extended under the PSNP. The access roads under PSNP now constitute the largest
road-building program in Ethiopia, 92 percent of households in PSNP woredas reporting that PSNP
roads have benefited them.

11.      The positive evidence on implementation and impact is supported by household
perceptions of the program65. Citizens widely acknowledge that (i) the program is fair in
identifying beneficiaries and allocating support; 87 percent of respondents reported that the PSNP
selection process was fair; (ii) the program is transparent and inclusive in its operation; 74 percent
of respondents either "strongly agreed" or "somewhat agreed" that they had been provided with
good opportunities to provide input on PSNP selection decisions; and (iii) it is efficient and helpful
to communities in the projects it supports; 97 percent of respondents considered previously
completed PSNP projects useful to the community. In sum, overall satisfaction with the PSNP is
very high; some 83 percent of respondents report being either "strongly" or "generally satisfied"
with the program. It is important to note however that beneficiary perceptions confirm the
challenges in implementation noted above; only 60 percent of beneficiaries report receiving their
payments on time and possible evidence of underpayment of transfers will be subject to further
study.

C. Causes of the cost overrun

12.      There are two causes of the cost overrun; both are related to the impacts of the food
price inflation and drought which hit Ethiopia in 2008. These are discussed below and are
summarized in the table below.

64The income analysis discounts income received from the PSNP directly, which is therefore not included in these
calculations. The difference in income is statistically significant at the 5 percent level. Source: Devereux et al. (2008) ;
"2008 Productive Safety Net Program Assessment"
65Source: Urban Institute/ Birhan Research & Development (2008); "Financial Transparency & Accountability
Perceptions Survey"



                                                             51

                            ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT



13.     Firstly, food price inflation in Ethiopia, as noted in the program document has been
exceedingly high. Food price inflation, which stood at 81.1 percent in the 12 months ending
September 2008, has far exceeded overall inflation. However, there has now been a modest decline
since the inflation peak in July 2008 (91.7 percent). The high food inflation is mainly attributed to
the rise in the cereal prices which have increased by 157 percent during the 12 months ending
September 2008. The largest increases are among the cereals that have been relatively cheaper and
consequently, largely consumed by low income households.66 The price of maize rose 261.1
percent in the 12 months ending July, 2008. The impact at household level of this unprecedented
food price inflation was greatly exacerbated by the ultimately failed March to May 2008 belg (small
season) rains, which resulted in drought conditions throughout the southern and eastern parts of
Ethiopia, as well as areas in the highlands. The combination of these twin shocks had a devastating
impact on household food security, much of it concentrated in existing program areas.

14.     In order to support households in coping with these shocks, Government and donor
partners agreed that further support should be given to existing PSNP beneficiaries to ensure
their food consumption until the next harvest in October, 2008. Additional transfers were given
through the program to affected households, mostly in-kind although some were provided in cash.
This was given to all affected beneficiaries, but was concentrated in "hotspot" areas, designated as
such based on evidence of severely deteriorating food security and rapidly rising malnutrition. A
total of 4.43 million of the Program's 7.35 million beneficiaries received additional support in
2008. The cost of this was US$67 million67. Government was able to mobilize financing for this
through various sources. The US$25 million contingent grant under the Drought Risk Financing
component of the World Bank PSNP APL II Project, designed for this purpose, was disbursed.
With the agreement of donor partners, program resources already pledged for the 2009 PSNP
program were drawn down on an accelerated basis.

15.     Secondly, while the longer term impact of food price inflation on the program is still being
assessed, there is an immediate impact in 2009. The daily cash transfer provided through the
program, currently set at ETB8 (approximately US$0.8) has suffered enormous erosion in
purchasing power as a result of food price inflation.                  The ETB8 transfer was established in
December 2007 for the 2008 Program. Purchasing power was reduced by 58 percent between
December 2007 and June 2008, more than cutting it in half. It has been agreed that in order for
the Program to meet its objectives some adjustment in the value of the transfer must be made.
In adjusting the cash transfer several factors need to be taken into account. While restoring
purchasing power to previous levels is a primary concern, the potential impact on labor markets,
inflation, and overall program affordability also need to be considered. Critically, the danger of
overshooting long-term prices must also be factored-in given the uncertainty over long-term price
trends and several factors suggesting that domestic food prices will fall in the coming months68.


66Poor rural farmers in Ethiopia are on average net purchasers of grain. "Ethiopia Poverty Assessment", 2005; World
Bank.
67Of the total cost US$17.6 million was provided directly in cash transfers and the remainder was used to finance the
purchase of 87,154 tons of grain, which was then used for transfers.
68The two primary arguments supporting the case that there is likely to be downward pressure on grain prices are (i) the
November/December Meher harvest is predicted to be adequate and will likely lead to price reductions, and (ii)
Government has indicated it will continue to import grain from abroad with the stated objective of reducing prices



                                                          52

16.     A recent study commissioned by the Government and donors has balanced these differing
considerations. It suggests that long-term prices will trend down, towards import parity, which is
well below current price levels. Based on a recommendation linking the purchasing power of the
wage rate to projected import parity prices, the Government and donor partners have agreed to
make financing available in order to cover a potential increase in the transfer value to ETB12, 50
percent above current levels. An adjustment in the transfer value to ETB12 would require an
additional US$97.3 million of program financing.

17.     The impact of these additional costs on the Program budget is shown in the table below. The
total budget for the coming year is US$288.3 million and 324,373 tons of grain; a total equivalent
cash budget of US$473.1 million. Existing commitments, including from IDA have provided much
of the financing needed for this.69 Several donor partners have mobilized additional resources
specifically in response to the cost overruns highlighted above.                  Almost all of the required
resources in cash or food have now been mobilized for 2009, but there is a residual financing
requirement of US$25.3 million.

D. Rationale for the Additional Grant & Expected Outcomes

18.     The objective of the PSNP Additional Financing Project is to fill the PSNP financing
gap that has emerged as a result of the combined impact of food price inflation and drought
in 2008, which have caused a cost overrun in the project. The causes of the cost overrun were
outside the control of the project. The additional grant will allow the project to continue to function
as designed in 2009, providing a similar level of support to food insecure households as has been
provided through 2008. It would also ensure that this support is provided on a timely basis.




down to import parity. Ahmed, H, EDRI (2008): "The Implications of Inflation on the Purchasing Power of the
Productive Safety Net Cash Transfer".
69This includes the IDA resources currently undisbursed from the Project, as indicated in Table 1, for which the World
Bank has received a request for disbursement.



                                                          53

Without this additional financing, the current PDO would not be achieved, and the project's impact
indicators would be compromised.

19.     The option of accelerating processing of the next APL to meet the current financing
gap was considered and rejected. The additional grant would provide financing for 2009 while
APL III would provide financing from 2010 onwards. The program requires financing immediately
and any further delay in securing funds would directly undermine project performance in 2009. A
number of design questions related to APL III will be discussed and agreed with Government
during the course of 2009. It is important that the necessary time be given to this dialogue to ensure
that APL III is appropriately designed.

E. Proposed changes

20.     There are no changes in the PDO, design, and/or scope of the project. As the additional
funds will help address a cost overrun in the project and thereby allow the project to meet its
original objectives, the original PDO remains valid and the relevant results indicators and target
values remain the same.

21.     There are no changes applicable to the implementation mechanisms, financial
management, disbursement arrangements, or closing date.                With the exception of the
unforeseen cost overrun, progress towards achieving the Project Development Objective is
satisfactory, and implementation of the project as well as project management are satisfactory and
continue to be strengthened.     Although there are no changes to the financial management or
procurement arrangements for the Project, Annex 1 C and 1 D provide fully updated annexes on
Procurement and Financial Management for the Project, reflecting current capacity and recent
performance in these areas.

22.     The Table below indicates how the Additional Financing would be incorporated into
the financing for the parent project. There are no changes to the institutional arrangements; the
project will continue to be managed by the Food Security Coordination Bureau in the MOARD.
The Natural Resource Department of MOARD will continue to be responsible for overall
supervision and monitoring of the public works component.            The Ministry of Finance and
Economic Development (MOFED) will continue to be responsible for financial management of the
project.

F. Consistency with CAS

23.     As noted in the main program document, the PSNP remains a core component of the
World Bank strategy in Ethiopia as articulated in the current Country Assistance Strategy (CAS,
World Bank, 2008). The CAS also recognizes the risks Ethiopia faces and states that "the Bank will
build flexibility into its lending portfolio so that it is better able to help Ethiopia cope with external
shocks." In the face of the shocks that Ethiopia has faced in 2008, Additional Financing to support
the PSNP is fully consistent with the CAS.

G. Benefits and risks

24.     The impact of the project on social aspects and poverty is expected to be
overwhelmingly positive. The PSNP is a well-established safety net program in its fourth year of
implementation.      Independent impact evaluations have shown that the program is having a
demonstrable and significant effect on beneficiary-household income and assets. Ensuring that all
of the necessary households continue to be covered adequately by the program will therefore make
an important contribution to reducing poverty now, as well as avoiding destitution in the future.

25.     The underlying risks of the parent project remain, although these have all been mitigated by
developments since approval of the project. The most substantial risks identified at the time of
project approval included (i) limited capacity of local and regional level implementers and (ii)
financing gaps given the size of the program and the need to commit such a large volume of
resources to a multi-annual program.

26.     Additional to the risks identified for the parent project, there are several risks directly
related to this PSNP Additional Financing Project. As highlighted in the program document
these are:



                                                    55

                         ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


27.     Timing and Delays. For the PSNP to function effectively program financing needs to be
made available before the start of each calendar year so that it can be channeled through the
regional governments to local governments for distribution to beneficiaries as the Program is
implemented. While this system now works relatively effectively it is still slow, and several years
of implementation have highlighted the importance of ensuring that resources are available as early
as possible to avoid downstream delays. Thus there is a risk that if Additional Financing is delayed
this will undermine the ability of the project to meet its objective of providing timely and
predictable transfers to households.

28.     Weather. A drought would seriously affect household-level food security in 2009. This
would have further implications for project financing as the impact on the poorest households
would again likely be mitigated by a scaling-up of the PSNP. Whilst no direct mitigation is sought,
the situation will continue to be closely monitored so that any mitigating measures are taken and
financing can be mobilized in timely manner. It is possible that financing for the proposed World
Bank APL III could play a part in such a response.

29.     Food-price inflation. Further high domestic food price inflation would have a significant
impact on the PSNP as the value of transfers to food insecure households would be eroded.
However, domestic cereal prices are already significantly above import parity prices. The GoE has
stated its intention to continue a process of importation of cereals until prices fall towards import
parity. Moreover, the coming harvest in the next month should also contribute substantially to a
downward pressure on price increases. Therefore the risk of further significant domestic cereal
inflation is largely mitigated and remains modest.

                  ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT

                 ANNEX 1C: PROCUREMENT ARRANGEMENTS


31.    General. Procurement under the Additional Financing for the second Productive
Safety Net Project (PSNP APL II) would be carried out in accordance with the World
Bank's "Guidelines: Procurement under IBRD Loans and IDA Credits" dated May 2004
and "Guidelines: Selection and Employment of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers,"
dated May 2004 and provisions stipulated in the legal agreement. For each contract to
be financed by the additional financing, the different procurement methods, estimated
costs, prior review requirements, and time frame are agreed between the Recipient and
the Bank in the Procurement Plan.

                         ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


regions. The PPR report covers only the FSPD while the RPCs reports provide procurement issues
encountered at the regions and woredas under PSNP II.

37.    The procurement risk under the proposed project is rated HIGH. Overall, the GOE
procurement oversight arrangements are nascent at the federal level and only being established at
the regional level. There is a shortage of procurement professionals, making it difficult to attract
and retain proficient procurement staff and the linkage between the three levels
(federal/region/woredas) is weak. Procurement records management is poor nationally and
procurement planning skills are lacking at the sub-national level. Arrangements are being made
under the PBS II to strengthen procurement oversight nationally.   The thresholds for prior review
for international competitive bidding (ICB) including the maximum contract value for which the
short list may comprise exclusively Ethiopian firms in the selection of consultants are presented in
the table below.

Table of Thresholds
           Category                Prior Review                ICB             National Short List
                                    Threshold            Threshold (US$)        Maximum Value
                                       (US$)                                          (US$)
 Works                              >=5,000,000            >=5,000,000                  NA
 Goods                              >=500,000               >=500,000                   NA
 Consultants (Firms)                >=200,000                  NA                    <200,000
 Consultants (Individuals)          >=100,000                  NA                       NA


38.    The Project Procurement Plan for PSNP II will be updated by the Recipient to provide the
basis for the procurement methods with the same prior review and ICB thresholds as for PSNP II.
The updated plans will be revised by the Recipient and agreed with the project team as appropriate
and posted on the project's database and the Bank's external website.

39.    The Procurement Capacity Enhancement Plan includes actions to be completed by
December 31, 2008:

        9.1.   recruiting RPCs in Amhara and Tigray regions;
        9.2.   project staff undertaking a tailor made procurement training;
        9.3.   establishing satisfactory procurement records systems; and
        9.4.   revising the TORs of the PSNP Procurement Specialist to ensure he can focus part of
               his input on providing procurement support to the regions.

40.    Frequency of Procurement Supervision. In addition to the prior review supervision to be
carried out from the Bank offices, the procurement post review of procurement actions carried out
during the semi-annual supervision missions as well as the annual roving procurement audits of the
existing project will be continued.




                                                  61

                         ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


  ANNEX 1 D: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND DISBURSEMENT ARRANGEMENTS

A. Introduction

41.    The objective or rationale of the PSNP Support Component of the Food Crisis Response
Program is to fill the PSNP financing gap that has emerged as a result of the food price inflation
and drought in 2008. This would allow the PSNP to continue to operate in 2009 as designed,
providing a similar level of support to food insecure households as has been provided up until 2008.
Specifically, financing would be used to provide cash and in-kind transfers to food insecure
households. Financing would be channeled through the existing World Bank APL project, allowing
it to continue to meet its development objectives. The PSNP has an established track record of
providing transfers on a timely basis, in cash and kind, to food insecure households. Resources are
provided through a labor-intensive public works program for households with able-bodies members
and as direct support grants to labor-poor, elderly or otherwise incapacitated households. The public
works program aims to create productive community assets, with a focus on soil and water
conservation. Evidence to date indicates that at its current scale and scope the PSNP, in spite of the
crisis suffered in 2008, is having a measurable impact on beneficiary livelihoods as measured by
income and assets.

42.    A financial management assessment was carried out in accordance with the Financial
Management Practices Manual issued by the Financial Management Board on November 3, 2005.
The objective of this Assessment is to update the previous Financial Management Assessment and
determine whether the implementing entities continue to have acceptable financial management
arrangements, which ensure that: (1) the funds are used only for the intended purposes in an
efficient and economical way, (2) the preparation of accurate, reliable and timely periodic financial
reports, and (3) safeguard the entities' assets.

B. Executive Summary

43.    The project's transactions will be managed as it is done now. The overall performance of the
project is currently satisfactory as per latest ISR rating. The performance of the project in financial
management was rated Moderately Satisfactory by the last FM supervision. The risk of the project
remains Substantial.

44.    The project's transactions will be managed as it is done now. The overall performance of the
project is currently satisfactory as per latest ISR rating. The performance of the project in financial
management was rated Moderately Satisfactory by the last FM supervision. The risk of the project
remains Substantial.

45.    Fiduciary arrangements of the implementing agencies meet the Bank's minimum
requirements under OP/BP10.02. It is adequate to provide, with reasonable assurance, accurate and
timely information on the status of the project required by IDA. However, concerted efforts should
be made in addressing reporting delays observed.




                                                   62

                          ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


C. Summary Project Description

46.    The development objective of the overall PSNP is to contribute to reducing household
vulnerability and improving resilience to shocks. This will be achieved through reform of the
humanitarian emergency system to a development-oriented program which provides timely,
predictable and adequate transfers to beneficiary households, thus allowing effective consumption-
smoothing and avoiding asset-depletion; creates productive and sustainable community assets;
contributes to large-scale rehabilitation of severely degraded areas; stimulates local markets through
demand linkages; and establishes more effective responses to shocks such as drought to avoid
increasing destitution among affected households. There are no changes proposed to the PDO. The
existing institutional framework, procurement and disbursement arrangements will be maintained.

D. Country Issues

47.    The recently completed Joint Budget and Aid review (JBAR) and the Fiduciary Assessment
(FA) show that Ethiopia has made significant progress in strengthening public financial
management (PFM) in recent years. The JBAR, which was conducted by the Bank in collaboration
with other donors, reviewed the PFM system using the Public Expenditure and Financial
Accountability (PEFA) framework.         Out of the sixteen indicators covered under this review,
fourteen were on the Government's systems for public expenditure planning, budgeting and
reporting. The remaining two indicators are means to assess donor performance. Ethiopia scored
high on seven of the fourteen indictors, i.e. macroeconomic management, including aggregate fiscal
discipline and minimizing fiscal risks. The JBAR observes satisfactory progress in budgeting and
accounting reform but notes that the adequacy and quality of budget reporting leaves room for
improvement and remain a key concern.

48.    The status of PFM reform and performance varies between regions. Southern Nation and
Nationalities Peoples Region (SNNPR) and Tigray regions have been the beneficiaries of
investment and local initiatives to support PFM reform. They both show improvement in the
overall public finance function and a consequential reduction in fiduciary risk. Few other Regions,
such as Amhara and Oromya, have also shown significant progress in PFM while others are at an
earlier stage of investment in PFM or have not yet commenced their plans and therefore
demonstrated less progress in PFM improvement.

49.    The Overview of the PEFA assessment report is as follows: An evaluation of PFM
performance in Ethiopia has been conducted in early 2007 based on an international reference
framework ­ the PEFA framework. The assessment was done at the federal and regional levels and
two separate reports were issued. Seven regions were included in the assessment. The assessment
report issued in April 2007, which is still in its draft form, observed significant improvement in the
area of financial management at regions, including budgetary transparency in recent years, robust
budget preparation, regular internal audit scrutiny and follow up of internal audit recommendations,
timeliness of in-year and annual financial reports, and mutual supportiveness of the federal and
regional Auditor Generals. Nonetheless, the report noted that the quality and nature of internal audit
is uneven throughout the regions. It also reported untimely clearance of suspense accounts and that
some regions are still experiencing significant delays in producing timely in-year and end of year
information. The report further identified capacity issues in reviewing annual budgets.
