50.    In the view of the above table, while the inherent risk is Substantial the control risk is
Moderate. The overall risk rating continues to remain Substantial

Strengths and Weaknesses of Financial Management

51.    As noted in various reports the country's discipline in executing budget and compliance with
the existing Government regulations are the major strengths in implementing the project. The
Government's existing arrangements are already being used in a number of projects, including
PSNP and PBS which is currently under implementation.

52.    The main weaknesses for the FM arrangements continues to be shortage of qualified
accountants and auditors (mainly at Woredas), delay in reporting, limited focus of internal audit,
and understaffing of the audit function. As part of ongoing dialogue during project implementation
staffing continues to be strengthened at the local-level to address this. The long process involved in
producing reports from Woredas to regions, and from regions to MOFED, may cause delay the
timely submission of financial reports to the DPs. The program continues however to experience
delays in the completion and submission of reports and audits of desired quality. Delayed



                                                      64

                        ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


submission of reports (both audited and unaudited) and inadequate follow-up on recommendations
of some projects are of major concern.

E. Implementing Entities

53.    The current arrangements will continue to operate. At the Federal level, MOFED will
continue to be responsible for the overall financial management of the project, the management of
the designated and the pooled local currency account. MOFED will also continue to be responsible
for producing regular financial reports and facilitating the annual audit of the PSNP account.

54.    At the regional level, BOFEDs continue to be responsible for ensuring that a suitable
accounting system covering both regional and Woreda levels is established. BOFEDs will continue
to collect and aggregate all financial data and information from Woredas on the Project, review the
effective use of accounting procedures by Woredas, and provide technical support and assistance to
Woreda finance personnel to help them develop the needed skills and competences to carry out
their functions. Each region will prepare monthly, quarterly and annual reports, which will be sent
to the federal level.

55.    At the Woreda level, a suitable accounting system is established for the disbursement of
funds for activities financed under the PSNP. The records of funds utilized will be maintained in
accordance with sound accounting practices that are capable of generating accurate and timely
information for verification. Woreda accounting personnel received training on how to maintain
accurate accounts for the funds utilized and the same type of training will continue in the second
phase of the Program. In case Woredas face difficulties in accounting or handling financial records,
the region will provide timely assistance and training to resolve such difficulties.

F. Budgeting

56.    The overall budgetary arrangements will also continue to prevail. The chart of accounts of
the Government accommodates the expenditures of the project. The capacity of the accounting
staff to fulfill budgeting needs of the project is adequate.      Although the overall budgeting is
satisfactory, it was noted in the last supervision report that budgets are prepared and reported on a
lump sum basis with no breakdown for without proper identification of the category such as public
works, direct support, capital and administrative. Further more, there was very much limited use of
variance analysis and that there is no use of the budget as a management control tool. These have to
be improved.

G. Accounting

57.    The current accounting standards in use in the project will be applicable. FM manual has
been developed and is in use by the project and this will continue to apply for the duration of the
additional financing.   The existing accounting software will be maintained in order to allow
production of all accounting and financial data required and the chart of accounts will facilitate the
preparation of relevant quarterly and financial statement including information on the total project
expenditures.




                                                  65

                          ANNEX 1: PSNP ADDITIONAL FINANCING PROJECT


58.    There is an overall improvement in the account recording at regions and Woredas; however,
there is still more to be done in maintaining the proper audit trail for consolidation works at Federal
level. In addition, MOFED and BOFEDs should undertake adequate robust reviews and check on
the reports submitted to them from Regions and Woredas respectively.

59.    The current project has recruited and maintains significant number of accountants and
cashiers at both Federal and Regional and Woreda levels. As of April 8 2008 there were about 775
staffs out of which 359 accountants and the rest were cashiers at regional and Woreda level. The
current staffing at all levels will continue to operate.

H. Internal Control and Internal Auditing

60.    The project's internal controls, including processes for recording and safeguarding of assets,
are documented in the Project FM Manual. These procedures will continue to be applicable.

61.    MOFED, BOFEDs and WOFEDs internal audit departments or units will perform post audit
reviews. However, the lack of effective and value-adding internal audit function at Federal,
Regional and sub regional levels was noted in the prior supervision mission.

I. Funds Flow and Disbursement Arrangements

62.    The current flow of funds and disbursement arrangements will continue to be applicable for
this new initiative. The existing banking arrangements: designated accounts (DAs) and pooled
local currency account at Federal level, separate bank account at regional and Woreda level will be
maintained for disbursement purposes in accordance with the project objective.

J. Financial Reporting

64.    The project will continue to prepare on a quarterly basis, the Consolidated Interim unaudited
Financial Report (IFR) and submit to the Bank within 60 days of the end of the quarter. The format
and the content are consistent with the Bank's standards.

65.    Although there have been steps taken by MOFED and FSPD to enhance the timeliness
reporting and auditing, and these have led to significant reductions in the delays in reporting, the
program continues to experience delays in the completion and submission of reports which are of
desired quality. Incomplete reports with inadequate documentation were repeatedly noted.

K. Auditing

66.    The current audit arrangement will also continue for this additional financing. This would
include the financial audit and the roving audit arrangements currently in place. MOFED will have
the project financial statement audited by Office of the Federal Auditor General (OFAG) or an
auditor assigned by OFAG and will submit the audit report to the Bank within nine months of the
end of the year. In addition to this, an independent audit firm will conduct a review of the financial
transactions of the program at the Woreda level. This is what is referred to a Roving audit which
will also continue. The coverage would be similar to the existing one which is forty Woredas each
year, 10 per quarter, including a resurvey of the previous five Woredas which has already been
covered. There exists a ToR for both audits.

67.    The transaction-testing Roving Audit for the year 2007 was not conducted on time, i.e. the
audit for the period from January 1 2007 to December 31, 2007 was not conducted as planned
which would include 10 Woredas per quarter. This is currently under implementation. The 2008
Roving Audit from January 1 2008 up to now is not yet started and auditors are not yet recruited.

68.    The financial audit report for the year ended 7 July 2007 was received and reviewed. The
audit report is qualified and the management letter revealed a number of internal control
weaknesses. An action plan is being requested so as to resolve the issues noted in the report.

L. Financial Covenants

69.    MOFED will submit the audited Program accounts to IDA nine months after the end of each
fiscal year. The fiscal year ends on 7 July of each year. The audited financial statement will include
all sources of funds for the Program, including other donors and the Government. MOFED will
submit quarterly IFRs to IDA sixty days after the end of each quarter period.

70.    The action plan below indicates the actions to be taken for the project to strengthen its
financial management system and the dates that they are due to be completed by.

                                                70

                                ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


                         ANNEX 2 A: DETAILED PROJECT DESCRIPTION

1.      The objective of the Project is to contribute to the Recipient's efforts to ensure an aggregate
availability of supply of chemical fertilizers for the 2009-2010 production season adequate to meet
smallholder farmers' priority demands. The proposed instrument for the Fertilizer Support Project
is that of Emergency Recovery Operation processed under the guidelines for a Rapid Response to
Crisis and Emergencies OP/BP 8.00. In line with OP8.00 the proposed Project supports "measures
to mitigate or avert the potential effects of imminent emergencies or future emergencies or crisis in
countries at high risk."

2.      The Fertilizer Support Project will be implemented by the Agricultural Marketing Sector
(Department) of MOARD, largely in accordance with established procedures. It will have two
components: First, a large Fertilizer Component (about US$249.6 million) will ensure availability
of foreign exchange for the importation of a significant share of the fertilizer demand for the
upcoming crop season.          Second, a small but important Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E)
Component (about US$0.4 million) will track the fertilizer imports, the various steps along the
input distribution system, and enable an assessment of the impact of the project for the beneficiary
farm households.

3.      Component 1: The Fertilizer Component will aim to ensure the timely import of
fertilizers for the 2009 production season.            The design of this quick-disbursing component
recognizes both the inherent risks involved in working in emergency situations, including the risks
and lost opportunities associated with a delayed response, and the critical importance of speed,
flexibility, and simplicity to an effective rapid response. It is designed to finance one single
commodity (i.e., fertilizers) under a positive list of goods, required to immediately address the
country's food crisis.

4.      MOARD has estimated, through extension staff, the quantity of the two types of fertilizers
(DAP and urea) demanded by farmers. The total estimated amount is about 550,000 tons of DAP
and urea for the 2009 cropping season. Based on the prospect of receiving support from IDA, the
government has initiated the process for the country to import initially 150,000 tons of DAP and for
75,000 tons of urea. The proposed Project will finance this first batch of fertilizer for the early 2009
season (belg and early meher). If (as expected) the costs will be lower than the US$249.6 million
allocated for this Component, the Project will also finance part of the next batch of fertilizer
targeted for the later meher season.

5.      The implementation would rely largely on the established procedures,70 which have been
found to be generally satisfactory by the Bank.              A national Fertilizer Foreign Procurement
Committee (FFPC) would oversee the tendering process for allocating foreign exchange needed to
import fertilizers. The Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) of MOARD, the implementing
agency of this Project, also functions as the secretariat of the FFPC.

6.      An important change compared to previous years is that MOARD is allowing for bulk
procurement.      This is a change from the practice in previous years. For example, in the last


70For more detail see also Annex 2 C on Procurement Arrangements.



                                                       71

                                  ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


(2007/08) season, about 12 cooperative unions and the parastatal AISE imported fertilizers were
competing for foreign exchange allocation and import market share, each one importing only
perhaps one or two shiploads.71 While this practice had the advantage of many importers including
small ones competing with each other, Ethiopia did not make use of its size. Many importers
competing have the disadvantage that each one is only handling limited amounts of fertilizer. The
consequence has been somewhat limited interest from foreign suppliers and high prices for each of
the small batches that are individually procured.              As one of the biggest fertilizer users in Africa,
Ethiopia can attract large suppliers that give a price discount in case large quantities are sold.

7.       This problem of fragmented import markets and hence, limited market power, also exists
outside Ethiopia and was discussed by the Agricultural Ministers of the African Union Member
States at the Conference for an African Green Revolution in Abuja, Nigeria in June 2006. The
Summit charged the African Development Bank with the responsibility of establishing the Africa
Fertilizer Development Financing Mechanism by 2007 and one of its activities is the establishment
of an African Fertilizer Procurement Facility (AFPF) that would consolidate orders to gain
leverage, realize scale efficiencies and make more affordable fertilizers available to small holder
farmers in Africa. Ethiopia is strongly committed to this process and, since the AFPF is not yet
established, decided to follow its principles on a national scale in the 2008/09 season.

8.       MOARD has advertised (on October 3, 2008) in the local media the tender for the allocation
of foreign exchange to cover the cost of the first amounts of fertilizer, i.e. 150,000 tons of DAP and
75,000 of urea under two different bidding procedures,72 amounting to about 40 percent of the
country's total estimated fertilizer demand for 2009.73               74   The bidding documents provided by
MOARD to interested importers specify that these large amounts will be procured on a lot by lot
basis.

9.       The consequence of the floating of a bulk tender as observed in the current process is that
importers tend to cooperate rather than only compete with each other. During this first tender of the
2008/09 season, AISE has emerged as the sole importer of these large amounts and is acting on
behalf of other importers/distributors, cooperatives and one private trading house.75 To account for
this fact, the task team agreed with the Government that qualified importer(s) (AISE) are asked to
float the tender internationally, i.e. to publish an advertisement in the Development Gateway's
dgmarket and UNDB online. The time of bid opening was extended by 14 days to November 11,
2008.




71While previously AISE and (mostly party-owned/affiliated) enterprises dominated the import of fertilizers, AISE's
market share has declined, other enterprises have gone out of the fertilizer business, and the market has been
increasingly dominated by cooperative unions.
72Procurement is on a lot basis, so that smaller market players can participate (see Annex 2 C).
73At current spot market prices, this amount is estimated to cost about US$180 million. If the cost is indeed lower than
total financing provided by the proposed Fertilizer Support Project, the Project will also finance the foreign exchange
for part of the next bulk procurement, planned for early 2009.
74Procurement is on a lot basis, so that smaller market players can participate (see Annex 2 C).
75This might or might not happen for the next tender to which the financing of the proposed Project would contribute.




                                                           72

                                  ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


10.      The importer, i.e. AISE,76 makes a public bid opening and then evaluates the bids within 4
days after bid opening. AISE has invited 2 representatives from the importers/distributors, on which
behalf it imports, to serve on its evaluation committee. AISE then submits its importer bid, i.e. the
evaluation report plus copies of bids from foreign suppliers, to MOARD/FFPC for review and
approval. MOARD will send a copy of the report and its review to the Bank. MOARD will, upon
its approval, instruct NBE to provide the necessary foreign exchange to the Commercial Bank of
Ethiopia (CBE), the bank handling the financial transactions between the importer and foreign
supplier for purposes of issuing a letter of credit under the fertilizer supply contract.

11.      The Bank's Operations Procurement Committee (OPRC) has reviewed the procurement
arrangements and found them to be satisfactory, meeting the test of transparency, economy and
efficiency. As the procurement of fertilizer is undertaken by commercial entities, the Bank will not
conduct prior or post reviews of any fertilizer supply contracts. However, the following provisions
will apply: (i) open competition among suppliers and control mechanisms on the procurement by
the qualified importer(s) and its contractual arrangements with other domestic distributors; (ii)
allocation of foreign exchange and establishment of L/Cs to the lowest evaluated responsive
bidders; and (iii) monitoring and verification of the actual importation and distribution of fertilizers.

12.      Given the emergence of a sole importer and the large size of the procurement, the task team,
followed advice of the OPRC, and worked with the Government to include control mechanisms for
the importer (AISE).77          In particular, this includes the requirements that: (i) AISE advertises
internationally; (ii) AISE's bid evaluation report is approved by FFPC/MOARD and the
FFPC/MOARD recommendation is sent to the Bank; (iii) MOARD will allocate the necessary
foreign exchange for the importation of fertilizer on the condition that AISE and its suppliers will
be subject to the Bank's provisions on fraud and corruption as well as the Bank's right to inspection
and audit;78 and (iv) MOARD forwards to the Bank copies of the document allocating foreign
exchange to the AISE, the contract between AISE and the importers/distributors on whose behalf it
is acting, and the contract between AISE and its foreign supplier(s).

13.      IDA disbursement for the Component would be in full on effectiveness of the project. Upon
award MOARD would instruct NBE to sell the necessary foreign exchange to the commercial bank
handling the financial transactions paying the foreign fertilizer supplier(s).79                 80The commercial
bank will in turn sell the foreign exchange to the importer. It will open the Letters of Credit (L/C)
for the selected importer(s) against payment to CBE by the importer(s) of the local currency
equivalent amount of the US$-denominated L/C. This transaction is between the CBE and the
importer; the NBE and Government are not involved, and will not extend credit. Pre- and post-


76These procedures would hold for any other importer that still wants to compete during the current tender or the
following tender that the proposed Project is likely to also (partly) finance.
77In case other importers will bid during this tender process or a possible next one that the Project might (partly)
finance, the provision would obviously also apply to them.
78Such provisions are not normally required under the quick-disbursing component to finance a positive list of goods,
and the inclusion of such provisions in this operation is not to be viewed as precedent setting.
79The Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE) has been functioning as the commercial bank of the importers, and is
AISE's bank handling these transactions.
80As the importers get the foreign currencies in exchange for the equivalent amount in ETB, this equivalent amount in
ETB is transferred to the treasury.



                                                             73

                                  ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


shipment inspections are included in the contracts between the importer(s) and their foreign
suppliers.

14.      As stated above, the Bank's Fraud and Corruption Provisions apply. Generally, quick-
disbursing components involve a large number of items in the positive lists, with several importers
(i.e., hundreds of small value imports by many local importers). In this operation, as there is only
one commodity with only few large imports totaling close to US$250 million, the Bank will ensure
(through a suitable disbursement condition in the Financing Agreement) that the contracts between
the local importers and their foreign suppliers include the provisions of (i) fraud, corruption,
collusion, coercion and obstructive practice; and (ii) the Bank's right to audit the importer's and
their foreign supplier's accounts and records relating to the performance of the import contracts.81

15.      The actual import of fertilizer as well as their distribution and sales to farmers will be
handled by the importer or importers, including the state-owned AISE and cooperative
unions/federations as well as trading companies. The delivery schedule for the fertilizers is pre-
determined by the demand and shipped through the port of Djibouti. Actual imports for the first
150,000 tons of DAP and 75,000 of urea are expected to arrive on numerous vessels between mid-
January and mid-April 2009. From Djibouti the fertilizers are transported by truck into the major
warehouses of the importers and wholesale traders of fertilizer and further down the supply chain to
primary cooperatives and retailers and eventually farmers. The main final beneficiaries of the
fertilizers are small-holder farmers82 and the bulk of the fertilizer is used in high-potential areas.
Traditionally, a bulk of the input is used in Oromia and Amhara Regional States, with about 50
percent and 30 percent of total consumption, followed by SNNPR (9 percent) and Tigray
(4 percent).83

16.      Component 2: Monitoring and Evaluation. M&E activities would be implemented by
Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) of MOARD with the objective to: (i) provide timely
information about fertilizer import and distribution for MOARD and the Bank, so that mitigating
actions can be taken, if risks such as low farmer demand materialize; and (ii) to evaluate the impact
of the Project on the final beneficiaries, i.e. farm households, and Ethiopia's overall crop
production and food security and inform future fertilizer policy. The M&E Component would track
the importation and distribution of fertilizers (and of complementary inputs) and assess the
efficiency of the distribution system as well as the revealed demand by the farmer beneficiaries, and
evaluate the impact of the Project on the farm beneficiaries. This would be achieved through a
combination of strengthening the already existing Government monitoring and reporting systems
and the commissioning of a survey by an independent international consultant, with TORs
acceptable to the Bank. The results framework and monitoring and evaluation arrangements are
discussed in more detail in Annex 2 B.

17.      The Government and its DPs would also monitor the fiscal impact of this Project, and
ensure that domestic borrowing is reduced. No new instrument is required for this as there are

81Such provisions are not normally required under the quick-disbursing component to finance a positive list of goods,
and the inclusion of such provisions in this operation is not to be viewed as precedent setting.
82Commercial farms with own foreign exchange reserves can import their own fertilizers without going through the
Government's foreign exchange window for fertilizer import.
83Basically no chemical fertilizers are used in the emerging regions. Data from DSA (2006).



                                                            74

                                 ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


regular assessments undertaken jointly by the Government and donors including the annual PEFA;
the annual PFA, the semi-annual JBARs; and the biannual IMF Art. IV consultation. In addition,
there are major operations such as PSCAP and PBS that strengthen the public financial system
including its monitoring.

18.     The Government requested to include a small activity to support the environmental and
social assessment and the preparation of the environmental management plan under the M&E
Component. The activity is to finance a consultant to assist the Government in carrying out this
activity within two months after Project effectiveness.

19.     Project Closing Date. The proposed Closing Date of the Fertilizer Support Project is June
30, 2010. This time frame will give the Project sufficient time to fully disburse the funds and
monitor and evaluate the distribution and application of fertilizers and complementary inputs
throughout the country.84

20.     Bank Supervision. The Bank's Project Task Team consisting of a Task Team Leader and
FM and procurement staff based in Ethiopia who would supervise the Project on a continuous basis.
Specialized experts on fertilizer and/or M&E would be employed for Components 1 and 2,
respectively. Two supervision missions are planned for early and late 2009 to assess progress of
overall project implementation.

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


Monitoring Arrangements

21.    The M&E system for the Fertilizer Component will consist of two elements: (i) monitoring
of fertilizer imports and distribution at critical steps along the input distribution system in terms of
quantities and timeliness, (ii) monitoring and evaluation of use and payoffs to fertilizer and
complementary inputs at the farm level,

Tracking fertilizer distribution

22.    As far as possible the existing MOARD system will be employed to track fertilizer
distribution from imports to wholesalers and cooperatives and their unions.               Much of this
information is already collected through the administrative system including trade statistics from
the customs office, and information collected by MOARD and its corresponding offices at regional
and woreda levels, including Development Agents (i.e. extension workers). For instance, MOARD
receives quarterly reports on the imports of fertilizer as well as quarterly imports from each of the
importers on their imports and the status of their stocks and sales.

23.    Nevertheless, given the importance of monitoring the demand at the farm level and of credit,
MOARD agreed to establish an additional monitoring through their system of Regional BOARDs
and WOARDs. This system would collect on a regular basis the amount of fertilizer sold to
farmers as well as the credit and credit guarantees provided (the table below provides an overview).
The format of the reporting was agreed during the Negotiations. To assist MOARD in these
enhanced monitoring and reporting efforts, MOARD will hire a short-term consultant under the
M&E Component, who would work part-time during the peak reporting period.

Broad overview of monitoring information to be collected through MOARD
      Level                   Dates                                  Data collected

 Imports            Targets specified in         Quantities of DAP and Urea

                    schedule/plans

Evaluating Adoption and Impacts

24.    At the end of the 2009 crop season, rural household survey data would be collected to
evaluate fertilizer use and beneficiaries at the farm level in order to inform future policy and
capacity building in the agricultural input sector. The survey would be designed to collect data on;


                                                    77

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


(i) farm level access to fertilizer in terms of source, timeliness and quality, (ii) quantitative
estimates of use of fertilizer by crop, (iii) the major beneficiaries of fertilizer use by farm size and
agricultural system/potential, and (iv) use of complementary inputs, especially improved seed. In
addition, the survey data would be combined with yield cuts in farmers' fields and recent data from
onfarm trials and demonstrations to provide an up to date assessment of payoffs to fertilizer use for
major crops and production zones.

25.    This survey would sample a cross section of woredas in high and lower potential regions,
measured in terms of both agro-ecological potential and ease of access to markets (see Attachment
to this Annex). The sample will be based on previous national household sample surveys in order
to provide panel data for better discrimination of impacts.

26.    The survey would be carried out by the Government commissioning an independent
international consultancy with a strong record in impact evaluation and knowledge of Ethiopia,
based on TORs and with consultants acceptable to IDA. Detailed draft TORs are available (see
Annex 2 B Attachment) and are being discussed with the Government.




                                                   78

                              ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


Annex 2 B Attachment: Draft Terms-of-Reference of Farm-household Evaluation Survey

A. Background

27.    In response to rising food prices, the Government of Ethiopia aims to increase the likelihood
that crop production in the 2009 agricultural season will remain on or near the growth trends of
recent years. It has requested IDA resources in the amount of US$275 million, out of which about
US$250 million is for a Fertilizer Support Project to finance the importation of fertilizers to support
production growth for the 2009 agricultural season.

28.    After the final disbursement of funds and distribution of fertilizers or other complementary
inputs along the value chain, a systematic assessment is required. The purpose of the evaluation of
the Project is to assess whether specific project objectives, have been met. The evaluation thus
requires up-to-date information about the fertilizer market and beneficial impacts of the project.

29.    Details about this Project and the specific M&E requirements are in the Project Document.

B. Expected tasks and outputs

The assignment would entail the following key tasks:
    · Original household survey data collection;
    · Other secondary data collection, to create pseudo-benchmarks; and
    · Analytical report summarizing major findings.


30.    Original household survey data collection. It is the consultant(s) obligation to assess the
best possible survey and underlying sampling strategy.          For example, to save costs and ease
logistical efforts it could be desirable to link the data collection strategy to other ongoing surveys.
Alternatively, it may be more feasible to carry out a new survey. The expected sample size of the
survey is in the order of 3,500 households. The consultants should also make an attempt to survey
a selected number of cooperatives. The survey does not need to be fully representative at the
national level, though it is expected that the consultants use appropriate stratification techniques,
and assure a high degree of geographical representation.

31.    Major data to be collected would include:
    · Standard household demographic variables, including those allowing an assessment of
        production and wealth benefits of fertilizer use, and those allowing an rudimentary
        assessment of environmental and health impacts;
    · Farmer's access to different types of fertilizers and variables allowing an assessment of the
        origin of fertilizer purchase;
    · Farmer's reporting timely delivery of fertilizers and variables allowing an assessment of the
        origin of timely or delayed delivery;
    · Area estimates allowing an assessment of adequate fertilizer doses;



                                                   79

                              ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


    · Data on cropping systems, effective use and quality of purchased goods, and other plot-
        specific data; and
    · Other variables of interest to be determined in consultation with MORAD.

32.    Other secondary data.       Similarly, it is the consultants obligation to collect appropriate
secondary data to eventually complement information from the new the household survey and
whenever feasible, create pseudo-benchmarks that would allow evaluating developments over time.
Appropriate secondary may be from the Annual Agricultural Sample Survey (AgSS) collected by
the Central Statistical Agency and other surveys, such as for example those conducted by the
International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) and the Ethiopian Strategy Support Program
(ESSP). MORAD, in conjunction with the World Bank's tasks team, would help to facilitate access
to this information.

33.    Major data to be collected would include:
    · Appropriate       information    that  allows    creating pseudo-benchmarks      and    tracking
        developments over time;
    · Data on production and yields, in particular for cereals, oilseeds and pulses, representative
        at the national level, and disaggregated whenever feasible;
    · Data on fertilizer imports and other information, documenting and summarizing the
        distribution along the value chain, as obtained through MOARD's progress monitoring and
        audit reports; and
    · Other information of interest, to be determined in consultation with MORAD.

34.    Analytical report. The analytical report should at the minimum cover the evaluation areas
described in the Project Appraisal Document. It is expected that a first draft of the analytical report
is shared with MORAD in early April 2009. The analytical report should be sufficient in depth and
have a well-written executive summary that clearly presents major findings.          The consultants
should, prior to final submission, substantially review major findings in consultation with MORAD,
MoFED, the World Bank, and if appropriate other agencies.

35.    Specifically, the analytical report should at the minimum cover the following areas:
    · An assessment of the quantity and types of fertilizer imported over the coming agricultural
        cycle. This information can be obtained from audit reports, customs authorities' data, and
        estimates as obtained through MOARD's progress monitoring and audit reports.
    · An assessment of the timeliness of import and distribution of fertilizer and complementary
        inputs to end users along the value chain. This information and subsequent analysis would
        come from the proposed household survey complemented with information, if appropriate,
        from selected primary cooperatives and MOARD's monitoring system.
    · An estimated of the costs and the potential contribution of the fertilizer to agricultural
        production and household economic welfare (cost-benefit analysis).         The consultant is
        expected to use appropriate quantitative techniques to provide these estimates.            The
        consultant is also expected to draw careful conclusions and point out limitations, in
        consultation with MORAD, since in an ideal environment an assessment of costs and
        benefits would benefit from a long-term perspective.

                                                   80

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


    · The consultant is also expected to assess, through appropriate data collection and analytical
        techniques, potential environmental and health impact of fertilizer distribution.       The
        consultant will also communicate with the evaluation team of the Productive Safety Net
        Component (PSNP) to explore synergies. However, these analyses can be rudimentary, and
        are not expected to be the main focus of the proposed consultancy.

C. Duration and payment of consultancy

36.    The expected duration of the consultancy is from November 2008 until June 2009.

37.    From November 2008 to February 2009, the consultant is expected to work on the rural
survey and collect other secondary data. From February to May 2009, the consultant will work on
the analytical report. A first draft should be submitted to MORAD in early April 2009, followed by
a final report in May 2009.

38.    The expected total cost envelope includes survey design, survey execution, collection of
secondary data, and final write-up of the analytical report. The payment schedule would be as
follows:
    · 10 percent upon submission of an Inception Report, which is expected two weeks after
        signature of contract;
    · 30 percent upon mutual agreement and finalization of survey design with MOARD's task
        team;
    · 30 percent upon submission of the cleaned unit record data to MORAD; and
    · 30 percent upon submission of final evaluation report.

D. Selection criteria

39.    The consultants (or the consultant firm) will be selected through (international) quality and
cost-based selection.
    · The consultants should demonstrate a clear understanding of Ethiopia's agricultural sector.
        They should have worked in similar assignments either in Ethiopia or in countries of similar
        geographical and economic setting.
    · The consultants must demonstrate experience in successful implantation of rural household
        surveys, and subsequent analysis of agricultural and other data specifically for monitoring
        and evaluation purposes.
    · The consultants should have minimum academic qualification of a Masters Degree in
        Economics, Agricultural Economics, or Rural Development with more than 8 years of
        working experience. A PhD will be considered as an advantage.

E. Reporting obligations

40.    The consultants will report directly to MORAD. If required, technical backstopping can be
provided by the Bank's task team.


                                                  81

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


41.    All reports and data shall be submitted in paper and electronic format to the MOARD, with
copies to the Ministry of Finance and Economic Development, and the World Bank's country
office.

                       ANNEX 2 C: PROCUREMENT ARRANGEMENTS

1.    General. The Fertilizer Support Project (FSP) is an emergency project under the Global Food
Crisis Response Program. Due to the risks and lost opportunities associated with delayed response,
and the critical importance of speed, flexibility, and simplicity the Fertilizer Support Project will be
implemented under OP/BP 8.00.         FSP includes a quick-disbursing import support component
designed to avail foreign exchange to finance the procurement of fertilizers under a positive list of
goods required to immediately address Ethiopia's food crisis as well as a small component for
Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) that will track the supply of fertilizers as well as assess the
impact of the project.

2.    Procurement of the required fertilizers. For the next planting season alone, fertilizers
requirements are estimated at 375,000 tons of Diammonium Phosphastes (DAP) and 175,000 tons
of Urea.    In anticipation of the foreign exchange support from Fertilizer Support Project for
fertilizer import, MOARD published a call for bids for allocation of foreign exchange from
interested local fertilizers importers in the local press on October 3, 2008 for the procurement of
150,000 tons of DAP and 75,000 tons of Urea. The Project team studied the MOARD procedures
for the allocation of foreign exchange for fertilizers import and presented the matter to the Bank's
Operations Procurement Committee (OPRC) whose deliberations were as follows:

3.    Quote: an exceptional meeting of the OPRC held on Tuesday, October 7, 2008, the following
points were discussed:

        ·       The OPRC agreed with the team's proposal on the procurement of the required DAP
        and Urea fertilizers following the provisions of Para 2.66 of the procurement guidelines
        (operations involving a program of imports). The OPRC explained that this paragraph
        normally applies to imports following ICB procedures or to smaller contracts procured by
        private or public entity following commercial practices that ensures economy and
        efficiency. Based on the teams' review and confirmation regarding the acceptability of the
        commercial procedures of the private sector, and given that this procurement is part of an
        emergency project under OP/BP 8.0, the OPRC recommends that the Operation
        Committee allows for adapting these provisions for the two large contracts of
        fertilizers envisaged under the project.

        ·       The OPRC concluded that even if this procurement involves private sector imports
        and the Bank is not financing the contracts between the local importers and the international
        supplier, the anti-corruption guidelines would apply. Accordingly, the provisions on Fraud
        and Corruption, and the Bank's right to audit and review, should be included in the bidding
        documents that were prepared by the government for the selection of the local importer(s).
        Additionally, in light of the perceived and potential risks related to these two large
        contracts, OPRC, on exceptional basis, agreed with the team's proposal to include the above
        provisions in the contract(s) between the local importer(s) and international supplier(s).
        Unquote

4.      The Operations Committee (OC) of the Bank at its meeting of October 9, 2008 endorsed the
recommendations of the OPRC.         Subsequently, the task team obtained information that other
importers including one commercial entity and several cooperative unions had delegated the state

                                                   83

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


owned Agricultural Input Supply Enterprise (AISE) to act as their Agent. It is thus apparent that
AISE could become the sole fertilizer importer and bid for the allocation of foreign exchange for
the large value fertilizer contracts as "lead importer". Therefore another meeting of the OPRC of
October 22, 2008 discussed the procurement arrangement again. OPRC members virtually:

      Quote agreed that the Bank will not prior review the process as this is still considered as
      an emergency operation of imports using commercial practices. What we have done is to
      introduce better competition, control mechanisms and separation of the evaluation of bids
      by the Agricultural Input Supply Enterprise (AISE) and the review and approval
      mechanism by the ministry/fertilizer procurement committee for the allocation of foreign
      exchange which will bought by the importer with equivalent local currency.

      The sector has confirmed that the following M&E mechanisms have been put in place.
      There is no prior or post review of 'procurement' or foreign exchange allocation process.

      Monitoring and Evaluation: M&E activities would be implemented by Agricultural
      Marketing Sector (Department) of MOARD with the objective to: (i) provide timely
      information about fertilizer import and distribution for MOARD and the Bank, so that
      mitigating actions can be taken, if risks such as low farmer demand materialize; and (ii) to
      evaluate the impact of the Project on the final beneficiaries, i.e. farm households, and
      Ethiopia's overall crop production and food security and inform future fertilizer policy.
      The M&E Component would track the importation and distribution of fertilizers (and of
      complementary inputs) and assess the efficiency of the distribution system as well as the
      revealed demand by the farmer beneficiaries, and evaluate the impact of the Project on the
      farm beneficiaries. This would be achieved through a combination of already existing
      Government monitoring and reporting systems and the commissioning of a survey by an
      independent international consultant, with TORs acceptable to the Bank. Unquote

5.      In order to increase transparency and competition for the expected large contracts for the
supply of fertilizers, AISE would publish the bidding opportunity in the dgMarket for a minimum
of 14 days.

6.      Due to fluctuating fertilizer prices, MOARD may have foreign exchange left over from the
Fertilizer Support Project support after allocating the foreign exchange to AISE to procure the
175,000 tons of DAP and 75,000 tons of Urea. This would necessitate another round of allocation
of foreign exchange under the Fertilizer Support Project. MOARD would follow its established
procedures for competitive allocation of foreign exchange that have been found satisfactory to the
Bank, and consistent with the OPRC recommendations above, including the risk mitigation
measures agreed between MOARD and the Bank following the procurement capacity assessment
reported on below.

7.      Selection of Consultants: Procurement of consultants under the Fertilizer Support Project
would be carried out in accordance with the World Bank's Guidelines: Selection and Employment
of Consultants by World Bank Borrowers" dated May 2004 (revised October 2006) and provisions
stipulated in the legal agreement. The procurement plan for the M&E component to be financed by
the Bank has been agreed with the Bank before credit negotiations; it indicates the selection



                                                  84

                              ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


methods, estimated costs, together with prior review requirements and time frame for
implementation.

8.      The M& E component of the Fertilizer Support Project will finance consultant services for
monitoring and evaluation; environmental and social impact assessment studies; technical
assistance to the Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) of MOARD; and for audit services.
The Impact Evaluation of Fertilizer Usage will involve household surveys to track and evaluate the
impact of the supply of fertilizers procured under the project. Contracts above US$100,000 will be
awarded through the use of the Quality and Cost Based Selection (QCBS) method in accordance
with paragraphs 2.1 ­ 2.3 of the Bank's Consultants Guidelines. Consulting Services for audit and
other contracts of a standard nature may be procured under the Least Cost Selection (LCS) method
in accordance with paragraph 3.6 of the Bank's Consultants Guidelines. Consulting assignments
costing less than US$100,000 may be procured through the Selection Based on Consultants
Qualification (CQS) method. Short lists of consultants for services estimated to cost less than
US$200,000 equivalent per contract may be composed entirely of national consultants in
accordance with paragraph 2.7 of the Consultants Guidelines. The Single Source Selection method
would be used in accordance with paragraph 3.9 of the Bank's Consultant Guidelines. Small
contracts such as for assisting in the preparation of the environmental and social impact assessment
study and management plan and the contract for the provision of technical assistance over a one
year period that can be undertaken by individual consultants would be procured in accordance with
Section V of the Consultants Guidelines.

9.      Institutional Arrangements: Fertilizers will be procured by the importer(s) selected and
allocated foreign exchange through the well-established procedures overseen by the Foreign
Fertilizer Procurement Committee (FFPC).           FFPC uses the Agricultural Marketing Sector
(Department) of MOARD as its secretariat. The foreign exchange would be channeled to the
National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) but the importer(s) would open Letters of Credit (L/C) in favor of
their supplier(s) at the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE).             The M&E studies will be
implemented by the Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) of MOARD, however the
selection of consultants will be carried out by the procurement unit in the Department of Finance,
Procurement and Property Administration of MOARD with the assistance of the Procurement
Specialist hired under the Bank financed Rural Capacity Building Project.

Capacity Assessment

10.     The fertilizer procurement is governed by a policy issued by the Council of Ministers and
implemented by FFPC supported by MOARD's Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) to
ensure transparency in allocating foreign exchange to licensed importers for the right quality and
quantity of fertilizers at the cheapest possible price. MOARD has for this purpose developed its
own standard bidding document (SBD) based on the Bank's SBD for the procurement of
commodities. It then monitors the performance of importers, mainly the AISE and cooperative
unions, allocated foreign exchange in procurement and distribution of fertilizers. The following is a
brief description of the procedures followed:

    MOARD determines the farmers' demand for DAP and Urea fertilizers;

    Ministry of Finance and Economic Development (MOFED), determines the amount of foreign
exchange available for importing fertilizers;


                                                  85

                              ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


   MOARD determines quantity of fertilizers that can be imported based on the amount of foreign
exchange available;

   MOARD prepares bidding documents and advertises in the local press the invitation allowing
25 days for licensed importers having adequate funds (in ETB) to submit bids to import fertilizers;

   Interested importers which are mainly Cooperative Unions/Federations and the state-owned
AISE, obtain and submit price offers from international fertilizer suppliers;

   Within six days of receipt of bids, the FFPC selects and announces, to NBE and the
participating importers, the winning importer that has submitted a bid with the lowest price offered
by international fertilizers suppliers; and

   The winning importer enters into contract with its international fertilizers importer and opens
L/C at its commercial bank.


Procurement Risks and Mitigation Measures

11.    Under the quick disbursing component of Fertilizer Support Project, the key
procurement risks include: (i) fraud and corruption in the process; (ii) reduced competition among
importers for reasons of inadequate capacity to perform the large contracts; (iii) the participation of
AISE, which is Government-owned; and (iv) over invoicing by importers thereby defeating the
principle of economy. The risk to Procurement Management under the FSP is rated HIGH. To
mitigate these risks, the following procedures have been agreed between the Recipient and the
Bank:

            MOARD prepared bidding documents for the procurement of fertilizers;

            The AISE, as an Agent delegated by other domestic importers of fertilizers, had
            purchased those bidding documents and issued to potential foreign suppliers of
            fertilizers;

            AISE would advertise extension of the bid submission date from October 27, 2008 to
            November 11, 2008 in the dgMarket, and national press of wide circulation and issues
            revised bidding documents;

            AISE will publicly open the bids from foreign suppliers, and submit its Bid Evaluation
            Report (BER) to the Foreign Fertilizer Procurement Committee (FFPC);

            FFPC will review AISE's BER and upon acceptance submit to the MOARD;

            The MOARD will review and approve the BER and the winning foreign supplier(s);

            FFPC notifies AISE of allocation of foreign exchange in a letter which includes the
            World Bank's provision for Fraud and Corruption and the World Bank's right to audit
            the AISE. This letter will also require AISE to submit two conformed copies of its
            contracts with foreign supplier(s) as per the draft contract contained in the revised
            bidding documents mentioned above;

            AISE will then sign contract(s) with its foreign supplier(s) and submit two conformed
            copies of each contract to MOARD; and




                                                86

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


              AISE will be buying the allocated foreign exchange by putting up the equivalent local
              currency (ETB) to the CBE selling the foreign exchange under authority of the National
              Bank of Ethiopia.


12.     Under the M&E Component, the procurement risks include: (i) the limited knowledge of
consultants' selection under Bank financing among MOARD staff; (ii) limited skills in procurement
planning; and (iii) poor procurement record keeping. The risk to procurement management under
the Fertilizer Support Project is rated HIGH. To mitigate these risks, MOARD would use the
services of the experienced Procurement Specialist working for the Bank-financed Rural Capacity
Building Project to: (i) support the Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) and the MOARD
procurement section in conducting the procurement of the M&E consultants; (ii) support the
selection planning; and (iii) set up a satisfactory procurement data management system. Fertilizer
Support Project project staff will be invited to the procurement training planned for the PSNP
project staff in November 2008. The Prior Review Thresholds for this component of Project have
therefore been set as per the table below.

 ANNEX 2 D: FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT AND DISBURSEMENT ARRANGEMENTS

A. Introduction

15.     This financial management (FM) assessment was conducted in accordance with the
Financial Management Practices Manual issued by the Financial Management Sector Board with
particular reference to the FM arrangements for emergency loans. The objective of the assessment
is to determine whether the implementing entity has acceptable financial management arrangements
to ensure that: (i) the emergency loan funds are used only for the intended purposes in an efficient
and economical way; (ii) the preparation of accurate, reliable and timely periodic financial reports;
and (iii) safeguard the entities' assets. Under OP/BP 10.02, borrowers (recipients) and project
implementation entities are supposed to have and maintain adequate financial management systems
which include budgeting, accounting, internal controls, funds flow, financial reporting and auditing
arrangements to ensure that they can readily provide accurate and timely information regarding
project resources and expenditures. These arrangements are deemed acceptable if: (a) they are
capable of correctly and completely recording all financial transactions and balances relating to the
project resources; (b) if they can facilitate the preparation of regular, timely and reliable financial
statements; (c) safeguard the project's assets; and (d) are subject to auditing arrangements
acceptable to IDA. As part of the FM assessment, the team visited the Federal Ministry of
Agriculture and Rural Development (MOARD) and the Agricultural Input Supplies Enterprise
(AISE).

B. Components

    1. Fertilizers Component: The import of fertilizers comprises the main part of the whole
        project covering a cost of about US$249.6 million. This is mainly to provide support
        through necessary foreign exchange, to public or private entities, including cooperative
        unions and state owned agricultural input supply enterprise, to import significant share of
        the demand of fertilizer for the 2009-10 season.

    2. Monitoring and Evaluation Component: This component will cover up to US$400,000 and
        is to support the monitoring system to track the imports, and the various steps along the
        input distribution system, to assess the impact of the Project for the beneficiary farm
        households.

C. Country Public Financial Management Issues

    1. The Federal Government of Ethiopia has been implementing a comprehensive Public
        Financial Management Reform with the full support of the developing partners including
        the Bank. For a number of years, the Expenditure Management and Control sub-program
        (EMCP) of the government's civil service reform program (CSRP) has been the main
        instrument of support to the Public Financial Management Reform. EMCP has developed a
        revised strategic plan to implement the nine components of the sub-program. Mobilization
        behind the EMCP (in terms of financial and human resources) is a key component of the
        Public Sector Capacity Building Program (PSCAP) and has now been considered a priority
        in order to achieve further improvement in all aspects of financial management. Recent
        reviews of the program show a marked improvement in budget formulation, cash


                                                  89

                        ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


   management, procurement, disbursement, accounting and reporting. Further support to the
   PFM is envisaged under the proposed Protection of Basic Services II (PBS-II) Project.

2. The improvements in the PFM reform have been further confirmed by the recently
   completed Joint Budget and Aid Review (JBAR) and the Fiduciary Assessment (FA) that
   have shown that Ethiopia has made significant progress in strengthening its public financial
   management in recent years. The JBAR, which was conducted by the Bank in collaboration
   with other donors, reviewed the Public Financial Management (PFM) system using the
   Public Expenditure and Financial Accountability (PEFA) framework. Out of the sixteen
   indicators covered under this review, fourteen were on government's systems for public
   expenditure planning, budgeting and reporting. Two indicators assessed donor performance.
   Ethiopia scored high on seven of the fourteen indictors, i.e. macroeconomic management,
   including aggregate fiscal discipline and minimizing fiscal risks. The JBAR observed
   satisfactory progress in budgeting and accounting reform but noted that budget reporting
   and quality needs improvement.

3. The Overview of the PEFA assessment report is as follows: An evaluation of Public
   Financial Management (PFM) performance in Ethiopia has been conducted in early 2007
   based on an international reference framework ­ the PEFA or Public Expenditure and
   Financial Accountability framework. The assessment was done at the federal and regional
   levels and two separate reports were issued. Seven regions were included in the assessment.
   The assessment report issued in April 2007, which is still in its draft form, observed
   significant improvement in the area of financial management at regions, including
   budgetary transparency in recent years, robust budget preparation, regular internal audit
   scrutiny and follow up of internal audit recommendations, timeliness of in-year and annual
   financial reports, and mutual supportiveness of the federal and regional Auditor Generals.
   Nonetheless, the report noted that the quality and nature of internal audit is uneven
   throughout the regions. It also reported untimely clearance of suspense accounts and that
   some regions are still experiencing significant delays in producing timely in-year and end of
   year information. The report further identified capacity limitations in reviewing annual
   budgets.

4. A country's FA completed in 2005 noted that considerable progress has been made in
   implementing PFM reforms in both federal and regional levels. Despite the progress made,
   there are a number of areas for improvement which include budget processes, internal
   controls and cash management. There is need for further improvements in financial
   reporting (reducing delays in in-year and annual financial reporting), internal audit, external
   audits and scrutiny of public finances.

                                 ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT

E. Implementation Arrangements

17.     The MOARD through its Agricultural Marketing Sector (Department) will be responsible
for the overall management of the project. MOARD will look after the technical implementation of
the imports. MOARD will be responsible for maintaining the designated account for the project.

18.     As noted in Annex 2. A (Project Description), the first phase import of fertilizers would
include the import of 150,000t DAP and 75,000t urea, the cost of which would amount to a
significant share of the fertilizer demand for the 2009-10 season the total amount of the IDA
Grant/Credit for the Project. The remaining will be used for the subsequent phase(s) of importation.

19.     The Government of Ethiopia (GoE) has an established arrangement to regulate the
importation of quality fertilizers to farmers through one qualified importer, a state-owned
enterprise, AISE on behalf of other licensed fertilizer distributors (see Annex 2. C: Procurement
Arrangements). All importers are expected to report to MOARD on quarterly basis on the imports,
sales and distributions they have made. The content of these reports is:

    1. Summary of fertilizer import status, depicting the amount procured, imported and the status
        of under shipment
    2. Fertilizer procurement status, depicting the name of the importer, the quantity procured,
        country of origin and the status of the floated date, the bid date, the LC date and the date of
        the import and,
    3. Fertilizer sales report by regions.

F. Fund Flows and Disbursements

20.     MOARD will open a Designated Account (DA) for this project at the National Bank of
Ethiopia (NBE). This DA will be used for both the fertilizer import and the M&E component.

Import of fertilizers:

21.     As noted above, the first phase of fertilizer import being initiated on about October 3, 2008
is estimated to cost most of the financing provided by the IDA Credit; the tendering process for the
second batch of fertilizer is expected to be completed before the first shipment of fertilizer arrives
in the country. Since the Government needs the foreign exchange to be provided to importers, the
task team determines in line with OP12.00 para. 5 that 100 percent advance amounting to the cost
of the first phase of fertilizers imports will be released to the DA on effectiveness of the
Credit/Grant. The procurement process is as outlined in Annex 2 C (Procurement Arrangements).

22.     The payment process for the import is envisaged as follows: A commercial bank opens a
Letter of Credit (L/C) for the selected importer(s) in favor of the supplier against remittance by the




                                                  92

                                  ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


importer of the local currency equivalent amount of the foreign currency-denominated L/C.85 This
is done once a contract agreement has been reached between the importer and the supplier. Payment
to the supplier is made on delivery of the fertilizers as stipulated in the L/C.

23.      The payment process to the supplier by the commercial bank is envisaged as follows:
Based on the contract agreement between the supplier and AISE, the commercial bank will pay the
agreed percentage to the supplier up on receiving the necessary documents from the supplier's bank
ensuring that the fertilizer have been loaded on the ship in the agreed quantity and quality. The
commercial bank will certify the documents received and once it has ascertained that all was done
as per the L/C, it will release the agreed percentage of the invoice amount to the supplier. The
remaining amount will be paid when the fertilizer arrives at the port of discharge and AISE assures
that it has received the same in good order.

24.      In effect therefore, the commercial bank buys foreign exchange from the National Bank of
Ethiopia and sells foreign exchange to AISE; and facilitates the payment to the supplier.

25.      MOARD will submit to IDA quarterly (as part of Interim Financial Report - IFR) a
Summary of the total eligible imports made from the DA, which is to be backed up by the source
documents received from AISE.

26.      Transfer of domestic currency proceeds into the government's treasury account: As noted
above, the Bank would disburse the loan proceeds into a DA. The DA would form part of the
country's official foreign exchange reserve at the National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE).                               The
government would promptly credit ETB equivalent to its central treasury account that is used to
finance regular budget expenditures. The Government would submit a written confirmation to the
Bank within 30 days of disbursements with supporting details.

27.      A Safeguards Assessment of the National Bank of Ethiopia (NBE) was done by the IMF in
2001. The 2008 IMF Article IV consultation report notes that the NBE has made progress in
implementing the recommendations. The task team is satisfied as to the effectiveness of these
controls.

28.      As discussed in para. 83 of the main part above, the Government, the IMF and Bank, and
other Development Partners will monitor through instruments such as the Public Finance
Assessment (PFA) and the semi-annual Joint Budget Assessment Reports (JBARs) the fiscal impact
of this transaction, i.e. the reduction in domestic borrowing.

The M&E component:

29.      Disbursements will be on the basis of IFRs. An initial advance equivalent to 6-months
estimated expenditure will be transferred to the DA. Funds will be transferred from the DA opened

Annex 2 D Attachment:        Agricultural     Inputs   Supplies   Enterprise  (AISE)    ­   Financial
Management Assessment Report

I. Background

39.      As per the project description in Annex 2 A and the procurement procedures in Annex 2C,
the procedure that the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MOARD) has adopted to
import the fertilizers needed by the country is through the FFPC/MOARD tender procedures.

40.      In the first tender procedure over 150,000 tons of DAP and 75,000 tons of urea, AISE has
delegated by other importers to import fertilizer into the country. Therefore this report is to assess
the capacity of AISE in financial management, inventory control and distribution. As part of the
FM assessment, the team visited the Agricultural Inputs Supplies Enterprise (AISE).

II. Establishment of AISE

41.      The enterprise was established on 13 Yekatit 1986 E.C as an autonomous public enterprise
by council of ministers regulation No. 177/1986 with an authorized capital of Br. 22,432,000 which
is totally paid up in cash & in kind. It has a limited liability. AISE is a financially independent
public enterprise. It runs the import business by the sales it makes and through the overdraft facility
it gets from the Commercial Bank of Ethiopia (CBE). It receives no subsidy from Government.

42.      The enterprise is under the privatization and public enterprises supervising agency. It is
managed by a board chaired by the state minister of the ministry of inland revenues. The board
members include representatives from the privatization and public enterprises supervising agency,
Ministry of justice and AISE. AISE has also an audit committee which reports directly to the
privatization and public enterprises supervising agency.

43.      AISE has 7 branches, more than 86 sales centers and 29 marketing offices through out the
country- located in the main regions of the country namely Tigray (Mekelle), Adama and Nekemt
(Oromia), Addis Ababa, Dessie and Bahir dar (Amhara) and Awassa (SNNPR).

III. Fertilizer import process

44.      The first phase of fertilizer import being initiated on about October 3, 2008 is estimated to
cost a large share of the amount of the financing provided by the IDA Credit. AISE has emerged as
the sole importer for this first batch of fertilizers.

45.      The payment process for the import is envisaged as follows: The CBE opens a Letter of
Credit (L/C) for the AISE in favor of the supplier against remittance by the importer of the ETB
equivalent amount of the foreign currency-denominated L/C. Payment to the supplier is made on
delivery of the fertilizers as stipulated in the L/C. In practice, this payment is normally effected
through the following process. The importer pays 30 percent of the invoice amount in ETB
equivalent to the commercial bank drawing from its regular Overdraft facility already established
with the commercial bank for its regular business purposes. For the remaining 70 percent the
commercial bank provides AISE "a merchandising loan" with collateral being the shipped goods.
The importer repays this amount when the goods are sold.


                                                     97

                               ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT



1. Budgeting

46.     AISE has a five year strategic plan and, based on that, develops its annual operational
budgets. The budget is prepared by management and presented to the board for approval. There is a
budget section under the finance department which notifies all departments and sections, the budget
for the year. This department is responsible for variance analysis. AISE's current market share is
about 45 to 50 percent of the country's fertilizer need and hence they have the experience to import
the stated fertilizers in bulk.

2. Accounting

47.     The account of AISE is semi-computerized. The enterprise is using a database system
centrally. Bank reconciliation is made on monthly basis.

48.     The finance department has currently 31 accountants, including the sales centers.

49.     AISE will maintain and keep the records of the import activities in its records. As evidence
of the eligible imports made, AISE will send to MOARD's Finance Department copies of the
source documents of the eligible imports. The source documents serving as an evidence of eligible
imports, to be sent to MOARD will include:

    1. Copy of Bill of lading, airway bill, etc
    2. Certified copy of the chamberized invoice (Commercial invoice)
    3. Country of origin certification
    4. Packing list

2. Internal Control and Internal Auditing

50.     AISE has satisfactory internal controls in place to ensure that the all funds are to be used for
the intended purposes. There is satisfactory level of segregation of duties and approval and
authorization regulations are clearly laid out. AISE has a finance manual serving as a guide to all
finance staff.

51.     AISE has an internal audit department performing post audit activities on all the financial
transactions of the entity. The internal audit department at AISE is adequately staffed for reviewing
the activities of the fertilizer import made through out the year. The internal audit department
produces quarterly report and submits the same to the audit committee. The audit committee
oversees the action taken by the respective departments. The internal audit department visits
selected sales centers on a monthly basis and produces a report based on their inventory control and
distribution. This is part of the report that the internal audit reports to the audit committee on a
quarterly basis.




                                                  98

                               ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


3. Inventory Control

52.     AISE has adequate inventory control procedure. The stock control section under the finance
department together with the purchase & distribution department are responsible for inventory
control. The inventory control procedure in AISE is as follows:

53.     Once the contract for import of fertilizers is signed with the supplier, the AISE procurement,
transit and distribution division will sign agreements with local transporters to deliver the fertilizers
from the port to the designated destinations. The agreement with the transporters is made before
arrival of the fertilizers so as to avoid delayed transportations. The agreement with the transporters
includes a clause which states that the transporters will be made liable for shortage of fertilizer bags
when received by the central warehouses.

54.     When the fertilizers are ready for dispatch from the supplier at the port of loading, an
inspection company will inspect the quality and quantity of the fertilizers and will send a report of
the status to AISE. Once the fertilizer reaches port of discharge (Djibouti port), an inspection
company along with the transistor of AISE, will inspect the fertilizer received and produce two
reports independently. AISE uses the Maritime inland transit services parastatal as its transistor.
Once the fertilizers are inspected, the maritime will produce a way bill and it gives a copy to the
inland transporter. The way bill indicates the quantity of fertilizer and the destination as to where
the specific vehicle has agreed to deliver. The fertilizers will then be distributed to the different
central warehouses where the store keeper of AISE and a representative of CBE will receive the
goods and produce a report of the safe arrival.

55.     The CBE has interest in the imported fertilizers since it is imported by 70 percent of
merchandizing loan as explained above. The stock is well controlled both by CBE & AISE. AISE
conducts surprise and end-of-year stock counts.

4. Distribution mechanism

56.     AISE will sell the fertilizers to the cooperatives through the different central warehouses
located in the main regions of the country namely Tigray (Mekelle), Adama and Nekemt (Oromia),
Addis Ababa, Dessie and Bahir dar (Amhara) and Awassa (SNNPR).

57.     AISE will make quarterly reports to MOARD as indicated below.

Reports to MOARD

 58.    The Government of Ethiopia (GOE) has an established arrangement to regulate the
 importation of quality fertilizers to farmers through either a state-owned enterprise or other
 licensed fertilizer distributors. All importers are expected to report to MoARD on quarterly basis
 on the imports, sales and distributions they have made. The content of these reports is:

    1. Summary of fertilizer import status, depicting the amount procured, imported and the status
        of under shipment




                                                   99

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


    2. Fertilizer procurement status, depicting the name of the importer, the quantity procured,
       country of origin and the status of the floated date, the bid date, the LC date and the date of
       the import and,
    3. Fertilizer sales report by regions.

5. Auditing

59.    AISE has audited its statements up to July 7, 2007. The audit report is not yet finalized but
the draft has been received. The auditors issued qualified opinion for the last three years due to long
outstanding liabilities shown on the financial statements.

63.                        The Government has three 2008/09 import quantity targets/scenarios, based on different
methods to estimate the `demand': (i) PASDEP targets: 756,000 tons; (ii) demand estimated by
DAs and aggregated through the Bureaus of Agriculture and Rural Development: 713,000 tons; and
(iii) a more modest demand based on an extrapolation of the last three years' demand: 550,000 tons.
The more modest estimate is a 25 percent increase in quantity over 2008, still a considerably high
increase compared to previous years.86 However, according to MOARD's records, total stocks in
2008 have decreased by about 50,000 tons, so that an import of 550,000 tons would relates to an
increase in fertilizer utilization of only about 12 percent.

64.                        The actual price to be paid for imported fertilizers depends on the development of
international fertilizer markets. The historical trends show that price changes for the import of
fertilizer in Ethiopia have been in line with the price increases of Sub-Saharan Africa in general
(see Figure below). In line with substantial fluctuations in world markets, there are uncertainties
about the development of fertilizer prices and quantities, and how they will prevail by the time
farmers making a decision about input use. A deterioration (increase) in the cereal-to-fertilizer
ratios may imply that the domestic demand for fertilizer is less than MoRAD's most conservative
estimate of about 550,000 tons. However, even if the 2009 aggregate fertilizer demand were lower
than this estimate, additional financing support would still be needed to match the historically high
level of fertilizer prices. Moreover, the actual demand will depend largely on the farmers' price
