                              ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


                 ANNEX 2 G: ECONOMIC ANALYSIS OF FERTILIZER USE

67.     The proposed emergency Project does not introduce new technologies or approaches, but
ensures that technologies that are established and have been practiced by Ethiopia's farmers for
many years can also be applied in 2009. In other words, the `without project' scenario would be
one where US$250 million worth of fertilizer demanded by farmers ­ most likely more than half of
total estimated demand ­ would not be available to them due to foreign exchange constraints.

68.     If the project does not provide the necessary foreign exchange to import fertilizer, farmers
will not have the choice whether to apply it or not. A lack of significant amounts of fertilizer would
be highly costly for the country and those farmers that regularly use fertilizer. This hypothesis is
supported by the fact that fertilizer is largely unsubsidized and has been applied by millions of
smallholder farmers for many years.

69.     The following analysis evaluates the profitability of fertilizer use in Ethiopia under present
and foreseeable price ratios.

Fertilizer-Grain Price Ratios

70.     The price ratios for urea and DAP fertilizers to an index of cereal prices in Ethiopia are
presented in the table below.       It shows that these price ratios are currently well below their
historical levels. Although prices of fertilizer are extremely high, domestic cereal prices have
increased even further. The Ethiopian relative prices diverge from those on global markets because
fertilizer prices are more closely linked to global trade than domestic grain prices, which react
strongly to domestic supply shocks (i.e. droughts, floods), regional factors (i.e. bumper harvests in a
few key producing zones), and are subject to price expectations by farmers.

71.     Fertilizer prices correspond quite closely to international markets as all fertilizer is imported
and there are no trade barriers or taxes other than foreign exchange distortions. Fertilizer prices at
farm gate, however, tend to lag behind international prices given the time difference between
international procurement and actually purchase by farmers ­ and the fact that most
importers/distributors, in particular the cooperatives, sell fertilizer at procurement costs plus
handling, storage, etc. costs and only a small profit margin. Ethiopia's grain market, on the other
hand, is rather isolated. There are virtually no exports and imports of grain except for those under
food aid.

72.     As the table below shows, the price of fertilizer relative to grain in 2008 had fallen by about
40 percent relative to levels in 2001 and 2002 despite the increase in fertilizer prices on global
markets. Hence, given today's fertilizer-output price ratios the application of fertilizer would be
more profitable than in previous years, in particular given the October 2008 significant drops in
international fertilizer prices, which get transmitted into the domestic market.




                                                  104

                                     ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT

73.      A similar price ratio measure is that between the price per kg of nutrient and the price per kg
of grain output (PN/PO). Using world prices this ratio is generally between 2 and 4 depending on
the crop (farmers receive higher prices for wheat than maize) and the nutrient (phosphate is usually
higher priced than nitrogen) and general level of development and infrastructure. The ratio during
the Green Revolution in Asia was around 2-3 for wheat, but most evidence suggests that the ratio is
more than double that in most African countries (Morris et al., 2007).

74.      Fertilizer-grain price ratios have been broadly within these ranges for Ethiopia and
somewhat more favorable than for most African countries. In the 2008 crop season, incentives are
estimated to have significantly improved since domestic fertilizer prices were based on 2007 world
prices before the major run up in world prices, while domestic grain prices have risen sharply since
then.

75.      Fertilizer prices in 2009 at the farm level are uncertain and will be based on the global
prices over the next few months and costs of transport. The long lead time of many months to
procure, import, and distribute the fertilizer and await the 2009 main harvest at the end of the year
also should be taken into account. Hence, projected farm-level fertilizer prices for 2009 have been
estimated under two assumptions:

    1. Upper-bound estimate--margins from FOB to CIF (lagged one year) and from CIF to farm
         level are fixed as a percentage of fertilizer prices--that is, margins are assumed to have
         increased in line with fertilizer prices due to higher freight charges and internal transport




                                                             105

                                 ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


         and handling costs.88 This likely represents an overestimate since many of the domestic
         costs of distribution are non-tradables not linked to fertilizer and fuel costs.

    2. Lower-bound estimate--margins from FOB to CIF (lagged one year) and from CIF to farm
         level are fixed in dollar value based on margins in recent years.89 These margins do not
         account for higher international and domestic transport costs in 2008 and 2009.

76.      For both estimates, grain prices in 2009 are assumed to be the same in dollar terms as
estimated prices for mid-2008 (US$550/ton for wheat and US$480/ton for maize).

77.      Grain prices in Ethiopia are also quite variable depending on local supply and demand but
much less related to global prices. Given the current food scarcity, use of constant grain prices is a
conservative assumption.90

historical trends (see Figure above)--a period when fertilizer use has been steadily increasing.
Under the upper-bound estimate, grain-fertilizer prices would become more unfavorable relative to
2008 but still within historical bounds, although only barely so for maize.

demand for fertilizer from 2008 levels, though the analysis is complicated by the fact that the actual
fertilizer demand would be depended on price expectations which are uncertain.

80.      Recent price movements provide increase confidence that price ratios will remain within the
band experienced in recent years and under which use of fertilizer has been profitable in areas with
reliable rainfall. For example, in the third week in October, global spot prices for urea fell by a
reported 35 percent. Measures undertaken by the Government to restrain growth in demand are
likely to result in moderation of increases in food prices in the coming months. Thus the change in
the relative prices of fertilizer and grain are likely to be in the direction to support profitable use of
fertilizer.

81.      The above analysis provides reasonable assurance that farmers in Ethiopia can apply and
profit from application of fertilizer. The following more detailed assessment draws on farm models
to provide another perspective.

Farm-level Production Impacts

82.      Baseline crop models are taken from the Economic and Financial Analysis of Ethiopia's
Irrigation and Drainage Project from 2007. The farm models typify the "average" farm in the Ribb
and Megech command areas,91 producing several crops and operating on an average of 1.5 hectares.
During the original field work it was found that only a few farmers in the area use chemical or
organic fertilizers. These are relatively high potential areas with good infrastructure and access to
markets, and are thus not representative of all areas. Yields also tend to be relatively high, but at
levels shown to be attainable in many other parts of Ethiopia, as well.

83.      Average cropping patterns are assumed to remain unchanged over the coming agricultural
season. In the wet agricultural season 45 percent of the land is used for teff, 20 percent for finger
millet, 13 percent for maize, 12 percent for noug, and 10 percent for rice production. In the dry
season, 20 percent of the farmland is used for vetch and 20 percent for chickpeas. The assumed
cropping intensity is thus 140 percent.

84.      The analysis further assumes two scenarios by comparing the "with" and the "without"
fertilizer situation. Fertilizer applied when rainfall is good can bring a yield increase of 100 percent
relative to the "no fertilizer" alternative. Higher supply responses are possible in Ethiopia (for a
summary see Byerlee and others, 200792), but require additional technological improvements, and
hence have not been assumed for the present purposes. When rainfall is unfavorable, yields decline
20% even if fertilizer is used.

85.      Historical data suggest a low elasticity of output to fertilizer prices, probably reflecting the
low average usage of chemical fertilizers by smallholders and their adherence to standard
recommendations if they do use it (Abarar, Morrissey, and Rayner 200493). Fertilizer prices in


91Fogera, Libo Kemkem and Gonder Zuria Woredas in the east of Lake Tana; and Dembia and Gonder Zuria Woredas
located in the Amhara region.

Ethiopia have risen less than cereal prices in recent years. Labor has been valued at ETB18 per
average family member working day.

86.     Import parity prices have been calculated for internationally traded commodities and
chemical fertilizers using World Bank commodity price data for June 2008. The current official
exchange rate of ETB9.68 per US$ been used, applying a 5 percent exchange rate premium
adjustment. Other commodities or inputs have been valued on the basis of the prevailing market
prices using CSA price survey data from June 2008. For non-tradable commodities market prices
have been converted to border prices by applying a standard conversion factor of 0.9.

87.     Under average rainfall patterns fertilizer use is profitable in high potential areas. While
tentative, the analysis confirms the earlier household level evidence, which is based on historic
survey data. According to the farm models and its assumptions, under average rainfall patterns,
fertilizer application in relatively high potential areas generates significant financial benefits at the
farm level. The gain to a farm household applying fertilizer is in the order of about US$200 (or
about ETB40 per family labor day).

88.     By contrast, assuming bad rainfall patterns with a production loss of about 20 percent, the
use of fertilizer will result in heavy financial losses at the farm level (or ETB120 per labor day).
This finding underscores the risks involved in fertilizer application for most households. Based on
historical patterns, Ethiopia faces a major drought on average every five years. The high-potential
areas where most of the fertilizer is applied are more rain secure. Nevertheless, the risk of drought
is significant

89.     The results were found to be sensitive to adjustments in output and fertilizer prices. An
assumed drop in domestic cereal prices of about 15 percent along with constant fertilizer prices as
of June 2008 would result in close to zero incremental returns at the farm level. Moreover, a
rudimentary sensitivity analysis suggests that the "switching" value for profitable use of fertilizer is


                                                   108

                                ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT


in the order of about 50 percent of the assumed production increase at the farm level. If production
increases are less than 50 percent, fertilizer application become unprofitable.

Fertilizer Profitability

90.      Fertilizer profitability is commonly expressed as a value-cost ratio (VCR) computed from
representative onfarm data comparing fertilizer treated plots to unfertilized plots as the ratio of the
value of additional yield obtained from fertilizer use to the cost of fertilizer used. A VCR of at least
two is usually considered as a minimum to provide an incentive for fertilizer use in rainfed
environments to cash-constrained small-scale farmers (Kelly et al., 200694). The VCR is in turn
determined by two components: (i) price incentives based on the number of units of output required
to purchase one unit of fertilizer nutrient, i.e. the fertilizer nutrient-grain price ratio (PN/PO)
discussed above, and (ii) the yield response per unit of fertilizer nutrient (O/N). While a discussion
of price ratios has been provided above, the following discusses yield responses of fertilizer at the
aggregate and at the household level.

91.      The fact that fertilizer use has a significantly positive impact on agricultural production at
an aggregate level has been shown by many studies. For example, the World Bank (2006)95 shows
that in Ethiopia the intensity of chemical fertilizer use is statistically highly significant, with an
aggregate production elasticity of about 0.12. This suggests that a hypothetical 1 percent decline
(increase) in the quantity of fertilizer would contribute, on the average, to a 0.12 percent decline
(increase) in total agricultural output. Consequently, a drop in fertilizer application by not just 1
percent but by 400,000 tons or considerable more than 50 percent is estimated to result in a
considerable more than (50 percent times 0.12 equal to) 6 percent drop in Ethiopia's agricultural
production value.96 This would imply a dramatic reduction, in fact halving, of agricultural growth
from the recent reported rate of more than 11 percent.

92.      The impact of reduced fertilizer availability would be mainly felt by the crop sector and, in
particular, the cereal sector. The elasticity with respect to crops or cereals rather than total
agricultural production is higher than 0.12. With a conservative estimate of crop supply response,
removal of 400,000 tons or more of fertilizer (worth about US$250 million) would result in a
reduction of about (16 million tons times 6 percent) one million tons of cereals, worth about
US$500 million (using the same production elasticity; 50 percent times 0.12 equals 6 percent).

93.      Evidence of a positive and significant production effect of fertilizer use appears to be robust
and with little change over time. For example, Yao (1996)97 finds a positive effect on fertilizer use
on aggregate agricultural production for Ethiopia during the 1980s, with production elasticities of




94Kelly, V., Factors Affecting Supply of Fertilizer in Sub-Saharan Africa, Agricultural and Rural Development Paper
23, World Bank, Washington, 2006.
95 World Bank. 2006. Ethiopia Rural Development Review. Washington DC. Unpublished.
96The impact of a reduction of fertilizer by 300,000 tons would likely be higher than the elasticity (i.e. changes on the
margin) suggests. As evidenced in Figure 1, the marginal productivity of fertilizer use per hectare falls as the
production level rises.

similar magnitude as those presented above. Maize has the highest production elasticity.98 This
analysis also finds that the positive impact of fertilizer can be offset by adverse weather-effects.
The finding that especially rainfall is a key determinant for production is among the single most
robust findings in the aggregate supply response literature for Ethiopia (see for example Abarar,
Morrissey, and Rayner, 2004)99.

94.     Supply response to fertilizer has also been studied through field trials. Following large-
scale demonstration of fertilizer by Sasakawa Global 2000 and the MOARD, which reached about 4
million farmers in the 1990s, Howard et al. (1999) carefully assessed fertilizer use and profitability
for farmers in Oromya Region who had participated in and "graduated" from the program. Yield
responses ranged from 16 to 32 kg of grain per kg of fertilizer nutrient for maize with improved
varieties and hybrids. This response is within the range for improved varieties of maize in East and
Southern Africa (Kelly, 2006; p. 51), although likely to be higher than farmers achieve under
normal field conditions.

95.     Another alternative method to assess the average production impacts to fertilizer at the
household level is to compare the net output values of households with and without fertilizer use.
We use data from Christiaensen and Demery (2007)100 where the yields are estimated using a
production function and the data are from 15 Ethiopian villages. The return is the value of output
minus any applicable fertilizer costs. Credit costs are here assumed to be in the order of about 10
percent of the estimated crop revenue. Yields in normal years tend to be systematically higher
when fertilizers are used. The average production impact at the household level can reach up to 40
percent.

Risks

96.     The above analyses shows the significant risks associated with the application of fertilizer.
For instance, in the analysis based on Christiaensen and Demery (2007), in bad years, with 20
percent rainfall below the median rainfall level, the use of fertilizer becomes economically
unprofitable, in particular for teff. Since nearly all agriculture is rainfed, there are significant risks
of drought, especially in the more marginal areas.

97.     Other evidence from household surveys in recent years suggests that inefficient use of
fertilizer may lead to losses, particularly in marginal areas, without use of improved seed, when
fertilizer arrives late, and when extension services are poor (World Bank, 2006101).        Over the past
three years, the Government has made concerted efforts to scale up extension, improve the
timeliness of fertilizer delivery, and make more improved seed available. For the present operation,
the Government and partners are seeking to reduce the risk of late delivery by securing the needed
foreign exchange in a timely manner and accelerating procurement.                  The fertilizer will be
distributed primarily in areas with more secure rainfall. Improvement in the seed sector is a long
term process and is under way. The planned expansion of the extension service is largely complete.

98.     The risks are present but not new, and farmers have applied fertilizers in the past despite
these risks. Indeed, contrary to common perceptions, Ethiopia tends to be a lower risk environment
for agriculture than many other African countries (World Bank, 2006102). About two thirds of the
farm population resides in reliable rainfall zones where most of the fertilizer is used. For these
farmers, the major risk is that fertilizer will not be delivered on time. Given current food scarcity,
and the modest increase in food supply projected for 2009, the risk of a sharp drop in domestic
grain prices is minimal.


101World Bank, Ethiopia: Policies for Pro-Poor Agricultural Growth. Washington, DC: World Bank, Washington,
2006, unpublished.
102World Bank, 2006. Ethiopia: Accelerating Equitable Growth. Country Economic Memorandum Update: Part II:
Thematic Chapters, Washington, 2006.

                                                     111

                             ANNEX 2: FERTILIZER SUPPORT PROJECT



99.     In sum, the economic analysis suggests that application of unsubsidized fertilizer as
envisaged under this project (i.e., predominantly in areas with reliable rainfall) is profitable at the
farm level under reasonable assumptions with regard to prices. Risks are significant, and largely
associated with weather as well as farmers' expectations and input decisions about changes in
relative fertilizer grain prices. At the aggregate level, the opportunity cost of not securing the
needed foreign exchange would be on the order of $500 million conservatively estimated, and the
cost would be felt quite immediately rather than at a future time; i.e., not diminished by application
of a discount rate.

            ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


 ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION

I. Projects with Savings

1.      Cultural Heritage Project (Cr. 3632): The project objectives of this LIL are to test and
develop approaches to integrate the conservation and management of cultural heritage into local and
national economic development efforts. After 7 years of implementation, the project has closed on
October 15, 2008. Although the project had implementation difficulties, progress toward meeting the
learning objectives has been largely on track.       The project has completed most of the planned
activities, and the lessons learned will inform the design of the proposed Tourism Development Project
(FY09/10). The cost savings at the end of the project period amount to around US$0.5 million.

2.      Capacity Building for Decentralized Service Delivery (Cr. 3698): The objective is to
enhance decentralized service delivery performance by initiating long-term public sector capacity
building at the federal, regional and municipal levels.       The Project has supported a coordinated
program of implementing civil service reforms, restructuring and empowering local governments, and
strengthening the Ministry of Capacity Building.         The objectives have largely been achieved,
especially in regard to capacity building in 18 municipal governments, and laid the foundation for the
recently approved Urban Local Government Development Project, which will provide significant
funding to these 18 municipalities for improving infrastructure services. The project will close at the
end of December 2008 after 6 years. The cost savings is US$2.0 million.

3.      Public Sector Capacity Building Program Support Project (Cr. 3899): The objectives are
to: (i) improve the scale, efficiency, and responsiveness of public service delivery at the federal,
regional, and local levels; (ii) empower citizens to participate more effectively in shaping their own
development; and (iii) promote good governance and accountability. The project is in its fifth and
final year of implementation and progressing well. Government capacity to plan and deliver gender
sensitive services has improved. Service delivery to citizens has been improved through: one-stop
shop centers, specification of service delivery standards, introduction of complaints handling
mechanisms, improved regulation in taxation, business registration, investment licensing and court
administration. Public financial management capacity has improved through reforms to budgeting,
accounting, cash management, procurement, audit, asset management, financial information systems
and financial regulations and directives. The civil service has introduced a legal framework for
decentralization, an enhanced civil service law, a code of conduct and an improved human resource
management system based on merit-based recruitment, promotions, rewards and sanctions. A culture
of customer-focused and result and performance based delivery is developing in the civil service.
About 60 percent of the project funds have been utilized so far and the project is expected to be
completed by July 2009. The Project is also being cofinanced by several donors (primarily CIDA
US$13.6 million; DFID US$43.6 million; EC US$11.43million; Irish Aid US$8.5 million). The
cancellation of US$20 million will affect the purchase of equipment and some consultancy services,
which are expected only at the end of the project period. Hence, it is clear that the core capacity
building objectives of the project already been met by now, and hence in a narrow sense, the
cancellation will not affect the project objectives.      Given that the underlying capacity building
program, coordinated by the Ministry of Capacity Building, will be a long-term endeavor to which the
Government is firmly committed, there is little doubt that resources (own or external) will continue to
be allocated.



                                                    113

           ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION



4.      Financial Sector Capacity Building Project (H.2390): The project will assist in building the
foundation for a more transparent, well-governed, well-regulated, and competitive financial sector that
can allocate resources to the private sector more effectively and efficiently, and help ensure better
access to finance for all. Implementation has been slower than expected but has improved after the
appointment of key consultants. Nevertheless the pace remains significantly behind schedule on
several key project activities such as drafting terms of references and recruitment of consulting firms
and contractors to assist the central bank with capacity building. A key challenge has been the highly
cautious and conservative culture of the regulatory authority that has been resistant to change. Overall
performance is moderately satisfactory. Overall disbursement ratio is around 20 percent and the
project is slated to close by June, 2009. With the next supervision mission, consideration will have to
be given to downgrade the project. Given the relatively low interest the counterpart is showing, it is
reasonable to limit the outcome objectives and focus attention on attaining those in the limited time
remaining. The cancellation of US$7 million of potential cost savings is consistent with this approach.



II. Projects with Revised Financing Plans

5.      Irrigation and Drainage (Cr. 4333): The development objective of the project is to
sustainably increase agricultural output and productivity in project areas. The expected overall project
results include: (i) increase in value added per worker; and (ii) increase in value added per hectare.
The project became effective in January 2008. Hence progress is limited. A review of the project
costs indicates that the IDA cancellation of US$10 million from the unallocated category is not
expected to affect project objectives.

6.      Private Sector Capacity Building (Cr. 4027; H 1410): The key objective is to facilitate
increased participation of the private sector in the economy by creating conditions for improving its
productivity and competitiveness.      The project has been under implementation for 3 years, and
following the restructuring in January 2008, there seems to be some improvement in implementation.
Most of the procurement activities have been completed; and the Retrenchment Package for the
Privatization Component is now completed and will soon be implemented.                     The Ethiopia
Competitiveness Facility, a key instrument to provide technical support to private businesses with a
matching grant system, is on track with a Manager in place now. Other smaller components are
moving as planned.       Based on observed improvements, the project is making progress towards
achieving its development objectives. Overall project implementation is rated moderately satisfactory.
The cancellation of US$7.0 million of IDA resources, which is primarily related to local currency
expenditures, for activities such as severance pay, will be borne by Government resources.

7.      Water Supply & Sanitation (Cr. 3901; H. 0850): The objective is to increase access to
sustainable water supply and sanitation services for rural and urban users through improved capacity of
stakeholders in the sector. The project is in its fourth year of implementation. The project is on track
to achieve its development objective. All regions have taken ownership of the National Water and
Sanitation and Hygiene (WaSH) Program for villages, towns and cities. Rural WaSH Programs have
been introduced in 200 woredas (districts), each having its own Woreda wide WaSH Plan. Some 801
water supply schemes and 195 institutional latrines in schools and Health facilities have been
constructed.    In addition, 12,674 improved household latrines have been constructed from



                                                   114

            ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


communities' own resources. Planning, capacity building and immediate service improvement is
underway in 87 small towns and preparations are being made to start planning and capacity building
activities in 30 bigger towns. However disbursements are lagging behind the plan, with only a third of
the resources having been disbursed and the project expected to be closed by March 2010.
Undisbursed balances currently amount to US$69 million. The Project has also received cofinancing
from DFID recently for nearly US$140 million ( 70 million equivalents) with the aim of scaling up
investment in the existing beneficiary woredas and towns and to extend to additional 100 woredas.
Given this and the Government's expressed commitment to fill in shortfalls in local currency
expenditures, the cancellation of US$13 million will not affect project outcomes

8.      Multi Sectoral HIV/AIDS Phase II (H: 2790): The objectives are to: (a) increase access to
prevention services for youth; and (b) sustain access to care and support for people living with
HIV/AIDS (PLWHA) and orphans. The implementation of activities is progressing well towards the
universal access to HIV prevention means, care and support in Ethiopia.         The major challenges
identified included scaling up prevention to reduce incidence of new infections and prevention of
mother to child transmission. The massive community mobilization being undertaken appears to have
reduced stigma and discrimination as indicated by an increasing numbers of communities supporting
PLWHA and orphans and an increasing number of people participating in Voluntary Counseling and
Testing. The project is in its second year of implementation. The overall implementation is rated
moderately unsatisfactory as there are some financial and project management issues to be resolved.
Overall disbursements have been about 20 percent so far. Project is expected to close within 18
months. The cancellation of about US$5 million will be covered by Government funds, in the event of
a shortfall and hence the project objectives will not be impacted. The Government is also keen to
integrate HIV/AIDS related interventions into a comprehensive health-sector program and other sector
programs (e.g., education) as soon as possible. For this reason, an extension of the closing date is not
contemplated.

III. Major Project Restructuring

Ethiopia- Food Security Project (Cr. 3646)

9.      Rationale for Restructuring. The Food Security Project (FSP), co-financed by CIDA and
Italian Cooperation trust funds, was approved on May 30, 2002 and became effective on November 26,
of the same year. It was designed as a community driven development (CDD) project with five
components: (i) grants to communities/kebeles for asset building and income generating activities
(IGAs) and for child growth promotion (CGP); (ii) capacity building for woredas, regions, and federal
ministries serving the project's beneficiary communities; (iii) food marketing initiatives; (iv)
communications and public education; and, (v) project administration and impact evaluation. The FSP
operates in four regions of the country: Amhara, Oromia, Tigray and the Southern Nations
Nationalities and Peoples Region (SNNPR) and in 93 (out of a total of 274) food insecure woredas.

10.     To date the Project has reached about 300,000 food insecure households with direct support
and a further 70,000 households through investments in community assets. Nevertheless, the number
of households reached is lower than intended because disbursements on the grants component has been
low (53 percent of the allocation to grants in six years of implementation) and revolving funds
established through community grants are not yet being effectively rotated. Moreover, while as a CDD



                                                 115

           ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


project, the FSP seeks to empower its beneficiary communities to address food insecurity, there have
been only modest achievements in this respect.

11.     Hence, progress towards the PDO is therefore only moderately satisfactory. The proposed
restructuring seeks to enhance the Project's achievements by inter alia deepening community
participation and decision-making and improving management of revolving funds by extending its
capacity building activities to community level institutions.

12.     The FSP contributes to the Government of Ethiopia's (GoE) larger efforts towards food
security. Its design adopted a rather wide-ranging approach to addressing the needs of food insecure
communities including interventions to promote stronger livelihoods, to help improve access to food
from the market and to engender behavioral change to improve nutrition of children and women. Over
time, additional programs to promote food security and improved nutrition as well as to support the
development of markets have been introduced.               Programs ­ such as the Federal Food Security
Program; 2003, the Productive Safety Nets Program (PSNP); 2005, the National Nutrition Program
(NNP); 2008 and the Ethiopia Commodity Exchange (ECEX); 2008 ­either complement the FSP or
have taken over some of its objectives. Recently, the GoE has embarked on a process to develop a
National Food Security Program (NFSP) that brings together different interventions to support food
insecure households under one framework. The proposed restructuring will position the FSP better
within this framework and link FSP interventions more coherently to complementary programs;
thereby enhancing the Project's long term impact.

Proposed changes.
  a. Change in the PDO:            The revised PDO would be: "to build resource base of poorer rural
     households, increase their employment and incomes and improve nutrition levels for their
     children less than five years of age, pregnant and lactating women".                  As such it excludes
     reference to improving access by poorer food insecure households to food from the market as this
     element of the PDO has been achieved outside of the Project. The Project's outcome indicators
     are accordingly adjusted and a revised results matrix is provided below. (Table I).
  b. Cancellation of a small "food marketing initiatives" component: Under this component, FSP was
     to undertake studies that would inform reforms and institution building for (a) improved
     management of food aid to secure a stable price environment for domestic producers and traders,
     (b) establishment of a food market information system, (c) development of a warehouse receipt
     and inventory credit system for traders, and (d) the development of a competitive and efficient
     market in warehousing services sufficient to support a warehouse receipt system.                    These
     activities are being achieved outside the FSP103 ­studies to promote related policy and
     institutional change would be redundant.
  c. Extending capacity building efforts to grassroots institutions and beneficiary communities ­ this
     would allow community grants to be properly managed at the kebele level and the project's
     achievements to be sustained over the longer term. It would also allow community involvement
     and decision making over the project's resources to be deepened..
  d. Adjustment of implementation modalities to: (i) increase responsibility of line bureaus and
     agencies such as regional bureaus of health, the federal cooperative agency and its regional
     counterparts in the oversight of relevant project activities, (ii) introduce better performance and


103Progress on these activities is documented in the consultancy report: Assessment of Performance Component two
(Capacity Building Support) and Component Three (Grain Marketing Initiatives).


                                                       116

            ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


      impact monitoring mechanisms, (iii) introduce more flexible credit disbursement arrangements,
      and (iv) definitions related to community grants would be further clarified to indicate
      management of such grants at the kebele level.
  e. Cancellation of US$35 million from the IDA allocation. FSP is entering its final phase of
      implementation during which it will focus on local level capacity building to sustain
      interventions to date; i.e., to ensure proper management and use of community grants already
      provided to beneficiary communities, rather than to continue replenishing such funds. This will
      allow the cancellation of US$35 million from the IDA allocation which would be reallocated to
      the Ethiopia
  f. Extending the credit closing date by one year to June 2010 to properly implement grassroots
      capacity building initiatives and to effectively link the Project's interventions to the newly
      formulated National Nutrition Program (NNP) and the second five-year National Food Security
      Program (NFSP) currently under formulation.

Ethiopia-Rural Capacity Building Project (Cr. 42010)

13.     Rationale for Restructuring. The basis for the restructuring of the project is to increase the
focus on results by strengthening the M & E system and to simplify the design of the project and
reallocating funds among components so as to strengthen important and well-performing activities.
The implementation of the project is in its third year of implementation and behind schedule, largely
due to the complexity of the original Project design as well as the weak capacity of the executing
agency.

Proposed changes.

(i) Change and simplification of PDO.         The original PDO was "to assist Ethiopia to strengthen
agricultural services and systems for improved agricultural productivity, make them more responsive
to clients' needs, and enhance the capacity of producers to become aware of and to adopt economically
viable and environmentally sustainable technologies and practices". The proposed PDO is "to assist
Ethiopia to strengthen agricultural services and systems and make them more responsive to clients'
needs". This is a more focused and more easily measurable objective; the simplified wording
contributes to greater clarity and fits well with the Government's own objectives for the sector.


                                                     118

           ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION



(ii) Revision of results framework The number of indicators will be reduced together with better
aligning the indicators with the Government's own monitoring and evaluation systems; the outcome
indicators are: (a) Difference in income change of households (M/F headed) between project and non-
project woredas; (b) Difference in productivity changes of main commodity between project and non-
project woredas: (c) Number of new agricultural activities adopted in project kebeles. The revised
intermediary results indicators are shown below.

(iii) Restructuring and reallocation of components and activities: While all Project Components will
remain part of the Project, the design by will be simplified through the cancellation and merging of
some project activities under specific components, specifically:
     a. Component 1: Agriculture Technical Vocational and Education Training: The Component
        remains unchanged.
     b. Component 2: Agricultural Extension: The Farmer Advisory Service Fund (FASF) and the
        Advisory Service Development Fund (ASDF) under Sub-component 2.3 Institutional
        Innovation will be replaced by a Farmer Innovation Fund (FIF) that would fund small scale
        innovations at the request of farmer groups.
     c. Component 3: Agricultural Research: Funding for region-specific research is proposed to be
        channeled through the already established National Agricultural Research Fund (NARF)
        mechanism instead of establishing a competitive fund for each participating region. In addition,
        the capacity building activities under this Component are proposed to be reduced (by about
        US$5.4 million) as the National Agricultural Research System is still undergoing an internal
        Business Process Re-engineering and will have access to other funding sources.
     d. Component 4: Improving Information and Communication Systems within MOARD:                      The
        Component would be completed after the installation of ICT equipment that is currently being
        procured for MOARD. The other activities are proposed for other funding and are cancelled
        under the funding for this Project.
     e. Component 5: Development of Agricultural Market Institutions: The activities for Market
        Policy Support sub-component 5.1 a) are proposed to be cancelled. Sub-component 5.1 would
        only comprise of support for Technology Solutions to the Ethiopia Commodity Exchange
        (ECX). Sub-component 5.2 will focus only on the support for a quarantine facility for the
        export of live animals and not include any activities related to phyto-sanitary standards. The
        total allocation of this Component is proposed to increase (about US$3.0 million) in order to
        respond to the need of the ECX.
     f. Component 6: Project Management: The Component is estimated to be over-budgeted and a
        redeployment of some resources (about US$0.6 million) is proposed.

14.     The project cost savings of about US$13 million will be cancelled and redeployed to the
Ethiopia-Food Crisis Response Program. The reason for these cost savings are: (i) given the slow
implementation progress to day it is unlikely that the project can disburse its funds until its closing date
and `unallocated funds' (about US$7.4 million) can be redeployed; (ii) cancellations from the (net)
redeployment from the Components (about US$3.8 million); and depreciation of the ETB against the
SDR (for IDA funds) and Canadian Dollar (for CIDA funds) (about US$1.8 million).

15.     Analysis. The proposed restructuring will not impact in any significant manner the economic,
financial, technical, institutional or social aspects of the project as originally appraised.           The



                                                   119

           ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


Environmental and Social Management Framework of the Project will continue to being implemented
to assess and mitigate negative environmental and social impacts.

16.    Risks. The critical risks mentioned in the Project Appraisal Document remain valid. However,
the proposed restructuring of the project would help to further strengthen commitment and ownership
by the Government and its implementing agencies and thereby reduce the risks to achieve the project's
development objective. Given the experience of implementation to date, capacity constraints that delay
financial reporting and audits are high.

Ethiopia- ICT Assisted Development Project (Cr. 3985)

17.     Rationale for Restructuring. The Project will be restructured and the objectives redefined to
take into account the narrower (simplified) focus of the project. US$10 million will be cancelled and
reallocated to the Food Crisis Response Program. During the Mid-Term review in March-April 2008,
the Government requested that the rural connectivity sub-component be dropped from IDA financing
and the corresponding funds (US US$7.3 million) be reallocated. The Government had identified an
alternate funding source for this sub-component. Since then, in response to the food crisis in Ethiopia,
the Government has proposed the redeployment of US$10 million from ICTAD funds (inclusive of the
US$7.3 million above) to the Food Crisis Response Program. The additional US$2.7 million that is
being cancelled from the project will also be substituted by Government funds.

Proposed Changes.

18.     Revision of PDO: The current Development Objective of the ICTAD project is "To assist
communities improve their livelihood through the use of appropriate Information and Communication
Technologies (ICT) that facilitate increased access to markets, development information, and delivery
of public services."     In light of the Government's request to drop the Rural Connectivity sub-
component and in line with the PASDEP it was agreed that, that the revised PDO would be "To
increase the use of ICTs by communities in project target areas", where a community is defined as
persons living in a specific area or who possess a common interest; and target areas are defined by
geographic locations where project interventions take place. This is a more focused and more easily
measurable objective.

19.     Removal of Remaining Dated Covenants:           The project included three Dated Covenants
pertaining to: (i) the licensing of Community Radios by EBA (fulfilled); (ii) licensing of ISPs by ETA
(partially fulfilled ­ ISPs are licensed but cannot operate due to ETC's network technical service


                                                  121

              ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


limitations)105; and (iii) licensing of Rural Connectivity providers by ETA based on public-private-
partnership (PPP) arrangements between ETC and local service providers. The rural connectivity
covenant is no longer relevant since the sub-component is being dropped. Therefore, it is proposed
that there be no dated covenants in the re-structured project.

20.       Revision of results framework:           It is proposed to reduce the number of indicators, and better
align them with monitoring indicators used by Government systems as follows:
          · Increased number of satisfied ICT users in project areas
          · Increased number of ICT-based businesses in project areas

21.       The revised intermediate results indicators are below.

22.       Project Restructuring and re-allocation of funds: The design will be simplified through the
cancellation and merging of some project activities under the two Components, The specific changes
are as follows: (i) the rural connectivity sub-component will be dropped; and (ii) the Training of
Trainers (ToT) for ICT/renewable power equipment maintenance and providing student training
laboratories in existing TVET centers will be scaled up.

23.       The restructuring also include redeployment of US$10 million to the Ethiopia-Food Crisis
Response Program. The reasons for these cost savings are: (i) cancellation of the rural connectivity
sub-component (about US$7.3 million); and (ii) the Government's agreement to swap US$2.7 million
in IDA funds earmarked for local expenditures with their equivalent in ETB. The revised Expenditure
categories are provided below.

24.       Analysis. The proposed restructuring will not impact in a significant manner the economic,
financial, technical, institutional or social aspects of the project as originally appraised. The potential
impact of dropping the rural connectivity sub-component will be compensated for by the Ethiopian
Telecom Corporation's (ETC) ongoing roll-out of national backbone infrastructure and its provision of
telecom services in rural areas, with financing from the Government of China.

25.       Risks. The critical risks mentioned in the Project Appraisal Document remain valid. However,
the proposed restructuring of the project would help to further strengthen project ownership by the
Government and its implementing agencies and thereby reduce the risks to achieve the project's
development objective. Given the experience of implementation to date, capacity constraints that delay
procurement and staffing of implementing agencies are high. An updated risk table is provided in
Table 3.

Ethiopia-Post Secondary Education Project (Cr. 3984)

27.    Rationale for Restructuring:       The project became effective on April 4, 2005 and will be
closed in September 2009. The restructuring proposed below will allow the cancellation of funds that
have not been utilized and are not expected to be utilized before project closing. Implementation
progress has been unsatisfactory for over one year given considerable delays in implementation of the
University Development component and lack of any progress under the TVET component.                The
project disbursement rate is about 27 percent with only one year of implementation remaining.
Furthermore, institutional capacity has been weak, and inadequate provision of monitoring and
evaluation and technical assistance at the university level have minimized results. The cancellations
combined with the restructuring amendments are designed to strengthen the M&E system, simplify the
design of the project and focus on better performing activities.

28.    The long term objectives of the project will continue to include: (i) strengthening the quality
and availability of post-secondary education (i.e., university and technical/vocational education); (ii)
providing medium term budget support to ensure budgetary allocations in other education sub-sectors
are protected during a capital intensive transition period for post-secondary education; and (iii)
stimulating innovation and modernization at the level of institutions, faculties and departments that
will lead to improved teaching and learning as well as to the realization of self-defined strategic
objectives. These objectives are not expected to be modified or changed.

29.    The project has two main components: (1) University Development and (b) Technical and
Vocational Education (TVET).           The University Development component includes three
subcomponents: (a) Institutional Development Grants (IDGs); (b) System Support Agencies; (SSAs);
and (c) Development Innovation Fund (DIF).            The TVET component consists of the three
subcomponents: (a) Skill Development; (b) Monitoring, Evaluation and Research; and (c) New
Program Development. This second component addressing TVET will be cancelled and all references
to TVET removed.

Summary of proposed changes.
(i)    Cancellation of funds (SDR10,350,000) to be redeployed to the Ethiopia - Food Crisis
       Response Program).
       a. Cancellation of SDR900,000 from Category 1 (b) Goods.
       b. Cancellation of SDR1,850,000 from Category 2 (b) Consultants' services and training
           including audits
       c. Cancellation of SDR3,500,000 from Category (3) Institutional Development Grant
       d. Cancellation of SDR3,000,000 from Category (4) DIF Subproject
       e. Cancellation of SDR1,100,000 from Category (2) (b) Consultants' services and training
           including audits.
(ii)   Percentage of Expenditures: Change the percentage of expenditures to be financed to 100% of
       foreign expenditures and 100% of local expenditures for all categories, thereby cancelling the
       counterpart financing obligation.




                                                  124

           ANNEX 3: BRIEF ON PROJECTS WITH PROPOSED IDA RESOURCE REALLOCATION


(iii)  Change of Implementing Agency: The implementing agency will be changed from the "PPD" to
       "HEPCO"; "HEPCO" means the Borrower's Higher Education Projects Coordinating Office.
(iv)   Clarification of Implementing Arrangements: Schedule 2, Part A, Paragraph 2 will be change
       by adding the following: "strengthening the capacity of MOE for management of expanded
       higher education functions, including support for the Policy and Policy Analysis Department,
       and establishment of three new higher education system supporting agencies, including a
       quality relevance assurance agency, a higher education strategy institute, a national pedagogical
       resource center and institutional pedagogical resource centers, all through the acquisition of
       goods and provision of technical advisory services"
(v)    Revision of results framework. In order to better capture the impact of the PSEP and reflect the
       ongoing activities, the KPIs will be amended to delete references to the TVET component.
       Although some project level indicators were established at the outset of the project, the
       completion of the matrix was delayed because the outcomes of the Five Year Plan (ESDP3)
       were not fully determined at the time the project was taken to the Board. When finalized, they
       were recorded, but not until December 2007. The revised indicators matrix will be included as
       an amendment to the DCA and will include:
           (1) Number of pre-accredited and accredited institutions and programs
           (2) Number of comprehensive Development Innovation Fund proposals submitted and
               successfully implemented, disaggregated by level
           (3) Number of MA and PhDs awarded annually, by gender
           (4) Number of faculty/instructors upgraded through short-term and degree training, by
               gender, with PSEP funds
           (5) Number of university administrators and managers upgraded through short-term and
               degree training by gender, with PSEP funds
           (6) Annual intake of students disaggregated by undergraduate and graduate levels
           (7) Number of students enrolled in undergraduate and graduate programs disaggregated by
               gender
           (8) Percentage of entering undergraduate students finishing on time, disaggregated by
               gender

30.    Analysis. The proposed restructuring will not impact in any significant manner the economic,
financial, technical, institutional or social aspects of the project as originally appraised.      The
Environmental and Social Management Framework of the Project will continue to being implemented
to assess and mitigate negative environmental and social impacts.

31.    Risks. The critical risks mentioned in the Project Appraisal Document remain valid. However,
the proposed restructuring of the project would help to further strengthen commitment and ownership
by the Government and its implementing agencies and thereby reduce the risks to achieve the project's
development objective. Given the experience of implementation to date, capacity constraints that delay
financial reporting and audits are high.
